39471003.review:
I'm mostly talking as an XCOM fan

I'm trying to like this game, it looks good, the tone is right, but I can't enjoy the fights:
-The combination of skill and turn-based feel clunky/cluckdgy
-You still has all the randomness when the enemy is shooting at you, but there's no easy way to evaluate the best position for your troops
-The 2-D level are way less interesting in terms of possibilities of movement
-Interfarce is annoying when buying (can't compare with what you already have)
-Can't change hat without starting a mission
-Rooms feels too cramped during fights
-No ways to mitigate (as in reduce chance of enemy hitting you) enemy fire (no hunker down, smoke grenade, suppression)
=> It feels as if Alpha striking is the only valid answer.
-Object choice is not very interesting
-Timers are annoying (whereas they didn't bother me in XCOM 2)

But after a few hours I realized something, I was having fun, LOTS of fun, in fact this game has such good gameplay that I found myself strategizing and thinking of good team compositions without just googling the most OP setup.

You see, the Steamworld series is one of a kind, it draws you in with an amazing art style and keeps you playing with fun and addictive gameplay, no matter what kinda game they make you know it's gonna be good.

39101779.review:
Wow, what a game. From the beautiful and stylish designs to the finger-clicking music, this game was an amazing experience! The level of polish for this game was so damn high for such a small talented team and the music felt so in tune with the environment and overall aesthetic.

As for the gameplay itself, I'm not one for turn-based stratergy games like this but hot damn, did it feel satisfying lining those shots up and blasting steambot heads off! It felt faster than usual turn-based games similar to this, primarily the Worms series. Also, the weapons and add-ons all felt balanced and unique enough.

Having just finished the game, I am sad that the game felt so short (at least for me). I played on experienced difficulty, which is above normal but I felt experienced should be the normal difficulty. I'm also a little hurt that there isn't an option for choosing to listen to the amazing songs that comes on after certain events, instead of the default music.

Overall, this game was an amazing find and I now I gotta try their other games and I can't wait to see what they drop next!

39089961.review:
I enjoyed this game immensely, it's the same aesthetic as Steamworld Dig but completely different gameplay, the basic way to describe it would be a 2d X-Com. The setting is pretty charming, it's like a futuristic wild west pirate clusterfuck but it was the actual gameplay I enjoyed the most. There was a much wider variety of classes and guns available that fundamentally changed how you played than I expected and I got good use out of nearly every option throughout the game. It's not like X-Com where you pick an enemy to shoot and get a % chance to hit, you have to aim your gun in the 2d environment and the characters hand wavers up and down slightly so you have to pick your moment to shoot. One of the classes has a laser sight which obviously makes this way easier, but they do lower damage as a compromise, so when you manage to nail a headshot from across the map on one of the high damage but completely manual aiming classes you feel like a fucking badass. One complaint is that it was quite easy, I played on the difficulty level above normal from the start, got 3 stars (max) on every level, then realised at the end of the game when it gives you your stats that I'd only failed one mission throughout the whole game. Guess I could have turned it up at any point, but I didn't, so maybe that's my fault.

You could also choose from a huge collection of hats that do absolutely nothing but look cool for each character before mission. All of the enemies wore hats too and if you shoot through the hat but not the head it knocks their hat off and you add it to your collection which is  just delightful - [b]7/10[/b]

39089455.review:
Hoy, en "Manqueando"... "Stimguorl jeist"

Esto va a ser breve. Aun no lo he terminado, pero dudo que la cosa cambie mucho.

La cosa es un juego de estrategia por turnos, con naves que se generan aleatoriamente y en las que tenemos que entrar a eliminar a los enemigos y recuperar los recursos que haya en las mismas. Y ya.

En cada misión tendremos una cantidad determinada de unidades (de 1 a 4 hasta donde he llegado),  y usaremos nuestras armas para farciar a nuestros enemigos ya sea directamente o por medio de carambolas. Cada unidad puede llevar X tipos de arma, y tienen un inventario limitado donde pondremos hasta 2 objetos más que nos ayudarán (botiquines, granadas, condones...).

Gráficamente es vistoso (si has visto steamworld dig ya sabes de que va), y cumple bastante bien en todos los aspectos.

Lo cierto es que aunque no tengo nada memorable que decir, es un buen juego. 

Como notas negativas... hombre, puede hacerse algo repetitivo, pero vamos... no como para hacerse aburrido, y te puede servir para echar un par o 3 de misiones cada vez que lo pongas. Y luego está lo de los sombreros. Vaaaale, que son un "coleccionable", que si, que está muy bien pero... ¿a que coññño tanto bombo por los jodios sombreros? Evidentemente, este ultimo punto es muy subjetivo, y si eres una persona adicta a los sombreros te parecerá genial que estén. A mi me da igual.

Y nada, le cascaremos un 7'5 y recomendado. Especialmente de oferta, como casi todo :D

Y en el proximo "Manqueando"... "Song of the Deep"

38964384.review:
Well, I'm not entirely impartial when it comes to squad-based turn by turn tactical games since I love them.

For me, Steamworld Heist is a perfect blend of familiar and novel. Tying the aiming and shooting mechanic to an actual player skill and not a random roll is just perfect!

The whole game takes about 11 hours to complete, and it's always a pleasure to try a new one, a little bit harder at each time, to test out new strategies (team composition, item selection, field tactics).

It's a very complete and satisfying game, and I had something to wish, it would be non narrative adventure, where you start with all the characters, and build up your team on several missions. But that would be a cherry on a top of a cake :)

38941405.review:
I didn't expect to like this game so much! The gameplay itself has enough variety to keep the game fresh for a long time. So many weapons and bonus items, plus the variety of playable characters makes for practically a new game every time. A lot of randomization in the level design and enemy placement, which did result in impossible odds on a few of the difficult levels.
As far as the turn-based strategy genre, I found this to be unique in the way that the targeting system works. It gives this game a distinct feel.
If you like turn based strategy then you will love this game!

This game is a great 2D Turn-based shooter. The story is fun and continues from the Steamworld dig 1 and 2. The mechanics are fun and the actual story is long.

People complain that this game get repetitive fast. But those people are wrong. If you take the time to check, they only have 1-4 hours played. Of course it's easy if you are at the easiest difficulty and you just rush in one-shot headshot everyone and take barely any damage. But like most game, when you crank the difficulty up, it forces you to developpe a new playstyle. Take cover, retreat, ricochet bullets off walls, shoot enemies in the legs to cripple, ect. 

Make no mistake that this game is excellent and definitly worth it, especially when it is so discounted as it is now.

소개영상에도 보이듯, 곳곳에 배치된 벽과 장애물들에 총알을 튕겨서 진행하는 것이 전략의 핵심. 쓰리쿠션으로 벽에 튕긴 총알을 적에게 명중시켜서, 슬로우 모션으로 산산조각나는(로봇이니 가능) 적의 모습을 보는 느낌이 참으로 상쾌하다. 전체적인 아트 스타일, 이펙트, 연출 들이 수준급. 러시안 근육마초 발레리노라거나, 고래오타쿠 선원, 블럽블럽 등 캐릭터 설정도 깨알잼. 타 전략게임 대비 아군이 사망시 패널티가 적은 것도 장점. 그냥 산산 조각난 아군의 부속품을 바구니에 담아와서 조립만하면 OK.
난이도는 적절해 보이지만, 후반으로 갈수록 딜량 때문에 중화기병의 활용도가 늘어나는데, 중화기들의 조준이 힘들어 자꾸 아군 피해가 나오는 것이 약간 스트레스.
클리어후 진행 가능한 뉴게임 플러스에서 계승 요소가 유닛 언락과 모자 뿐인 것도 아쉽다. 계승 요소가 더 많으면 2회차도 충분히 해볼만 한 게임인데…

38802134.review: Honestly this game was such a pleasant surprise. I was expecting a half-decent strategy game with some nice graphics; I ended up playing something much more than that. The strategy here is excellent with lots of enemy variety, environmental stuff, great level design, and the perfect amount of difficulty (I played on experienced.) On top of that the story was surprisingly fun with some nice moments and some twists, it wasn't amazing, but it was just what it needed to be, good enough to keep my interest, but not something that takes away from the rest of the game by being too complex. The characters are fun, the graphics are excellent, the music is great, the atmosphere is on point. There isn't much negative I can say here. At worst, the game begins to feel a little repetative, but it never feels like a grind.

38759061.review:
[h1] Overview [/h1]
[i] SteamWorld Heist [/i] is a fantastic game. For $4.49 (as of Steam's 2017 Winter Sale), you get a [b] serious [/b] bang for your buck. The gameplay is fluid, the controls are solid (and even if you don't like them, you can change them), the dialogue is comical, and the combat is intense.

[h1] Difficulty [/h1]
This game clearly expects you to be one thing: [b] PRECISE. [/b] Seriously, if you make one mistake, you might not hurt too badly. But more than that, you better pray to survive the late-game levels playing on Regular difficulty. (Speaking of which, you can change the game's difficulty to one of [b] five. [/b])

[h1] Combat and Ricochet [/h1]
[i] SteamWorld Heist [/i]'s combat is no joke. If one of your crew members dies, it's a nearly guarunteed lost mission. Strength in numbers is VERY important when combatting enemies. You're unlikely to defeat three enemies with only one crew member, even if that crew member is powerful.

Now, the [b] ricochet mechanic [/b] is so FUN to use! Are you in a really bad spot and can't move any further to take a shot? Well, use ricochet to your advantage. I'd say that 9/10 times you'd be able to do some decent damage with some good aim.

[h1] Verdict [/h1]
[list]
[*]I highly recommend it.
[*]19/20

38308084.review: Having a hard time seeing the "strategy" to this. Your options are move and shoot. Every encounter is the same. Use up your move to open a door, 5 enemies behind it. Take cover as your team scrambles in, try to take out as many baddies as possible, and then wait for enemies to suicide into you, because all they care about is getting close for the free hit. Not only that, almost every encounter comes with a "countdown", forcing you to move quickly or deal with endless waves of enemies and/or security turrets that spawn all over. Pretty repetitive if you ask me. Can't really compare this to XCOM as many other reviewers have, as XCOM was not only more challenging, but provided other options than run and shoot, namely Overwatch (take cover and shoot at whatever moves). Characters get abilities later on, but these are underwhelming, i.e. "shoot for more damage" or "waste your action to do blah". May give it another chance as it's not a bad game, but not as great as the reviews made it out to be.

38201916.review:
[h1] 海賊船のクルーを指揮して、敵の船に乗り込むサイドビューのターン制ストラテジー [/h1]

蒸気駆動のロボットが主人公という独特の世界観や、良質なBGMもあいまって、なかなかに面白い作品。

ゲームの流れは、ミッションごとに1～4人のクルーを選択し、敵の船に潜入するというもの。
すべての敵を排除する、特定のオブジェクトを破壊する、ボスを倒すなどのミッションをこなし、脱出に成功すると面クリアとなる。

各クルーは手番ごとに「移動＋射撃」、あるいは「ダッシュ移動」（2倍の距離を移動できる）のいずれかを実施できる。
また敵に隣接すると、格闘攻撃を繰り出すことが可能。

クルーにはそれぞれ得意な武器があるほか、「効果範囲の広いミサイルを発射する」「ダッシュ後に射撃を行う」「煙幕を張って敵の射撃を防ぐ」などのスキルがあり、これらを駆使していくのが面白い。

射撃はアナログスティックで銃の照準を合わせる必要があるのだが、一部の銃を除いて照準線が表示されないため、遠距離の敵へ命中させるのはなかなかに難しい。
なお、壁やオブジェクトに銃弾が命中すると反射するため、慣れれば遮蔽物に隠れた敵を跳弾で倒すこともできる。

1度クリアしたマップでの経験値稼ぎや、ゲーム途中での難易度変更にも対応しているため、ストラテジーとしては比較的カジュアルな方か。

38162683.review:
I wanted to write a long review focused on the wasted opportunity of the game's story and character interactions, but I decided there's no point in doing so, especially since the game's worldbuilding and humor are amazing, while the designers were also making a great job combining various distant tropes and making creative graphics and sound. To say it's "style over substance" would be fair, but it's necessary to admit the developers were definitely aware of it and didn't bother. So as long as you remember to keep your storytelling expectations low, you should be fine.

Fine, because the game has it all - fantastic gameplay, solid structure, great jokes, unique music and mood. I mostly play weird, heavy games, but this time I just wanted to have FUN and I enjoyed every hour of it. 

Especially since there are many comfortable design choices - flexible mid-game difficulty settings, an option to team up various characters and the ability to level them up / gather resources for them without any limits, an option to re-play every mission after finishing it, clear tutorials. Additionally, since most levels have some healthy sections that are randomized, you don't bother that much if you fail a mission and have to play it again.

What a great piece of entertainment.

One of the best turned-based games, in my opinion. Simple, futuristic, space-pirates, and entertaining.

SteamWorld Heist has an interesting and addictive gameplay which makes you want to play it all over again since the beggining and still captures you.  SteamWorld Hesit encourages you to level up the difficulty, making you think carefully before ending your turn and let the enemy shoot. Without the DLC's, the game still has a fair amount of content, changing the background stages, new enemies, challenging boss fights, a great inventory of weapons, the characters with unique abilities and of course, plenty of HATS.

I highly recommend this game to anyone, it's a great start to know turned-based games.

38068307.review:
Beautiful game, smoothly animated, never crashed once during two playthroughs.

Only negative aspect: it feels like it could have been even more: 
* Apparently the devs are able to generate levels randomly at will, so it's not quite clear to me why it ends so soon. 
* Except for maybe two weapons, I never bought one from the shop as they were all sub-par. Seems you either find a good one in a crate or you wont get one at all.
* Why is there no upgrade path for weapons? There could have been hours of farming for resources to level up your favourite weapon, remove negative natures, add good ones etc.
* Same goes for the characters, you get a predetermined stats upgrade once you reach the next level. Why not let the player spec into certain abilities?

I know this would have taken some serious time to even out the characters and weapons and make sure nobodys under- or overpowered, but it could have made the game 10x more time consuming (which in this case just equals fun) :)

37942081.review:
Are you actually fucking kidding me? THIS game only costs 15 bucks, has a lengthy campaign (far longer than I initially expected after the first 3 or so hours), great gameplay, a great art style with good animation quality, some humour and even replay value. Oh, and probably one of the best game soundtracks you've ever heard.

So, this game is set in the same universe as Steamworld Dig...and boy, I hope they continue to expand this universe.
What you get here essentially combines some aspects of the by now often used XCOM combat gameplay, just in 2D and with shorter levels with some minor crew management and upgrading through levelling up and finding/buying new weapons.

Every level has you invade an enemy vessel (or station, doesn't matter) that is partly randomly generated and consists of various "rooms" with loot and enemies in them. Enemies are not just triggered by opening doors though. Your goal in every level is to gather as much loot as you can and reach a certain objective to be able to trigger the retreat mechanic, which has you gathering all your steam driven combatants in one area of the vessel. Destroying generators, reaching areas, destroying all enemies are all objectives at one point or another. You go in with 1 to 4 of your 10 bots strong crew (with the DLC it's 10 I think). In many levels you will also have to deal with a steadily increasing alarm level that's on a timer and spawns new enemies periodically as well as fixed gun turrets.

Everything you've collected after successfully escaping an enemy vessel gives you resources and/or items for your crew. With the resource water you can buy new items (or hats, cosmetic items) as well as additional storage space, so you can have even more items. And items go on your characters of course. Every character gets to wield one weapon, but they are restricted to certain weapon classes, i.e. handguns, sharpshooters, shotguns, assault rifles or SMGs and heavy weapons like miniguns or rocket launchers. Each weapon type and weapon has different stats and characteristics like bullet spread, two shots, no shots after moving, arcing shots, etc. Two more slots are occupied by various support items like armor, damage powerups, healing items, etc. and last but not least you get to choose a hat for your character (did I already mention enemies also wear hats and you can shoot them off to loot them?!?!?).

You'll also gain stars (prestige) for collecting loot, reaching the objective and making it out without any casualties. You need those stars to unlock later stages of the game, as well as recruit some new bots or buy certain items, but it's a fair system. And lastly your bots earn XP after every mission, unless they die. The XP simply gets split among all bots.

The gameplay then plays like XCOM: move, attack or sprint and take cover. The biggest difference here is that it's not 3D, so you can only be flanked from one side...as well as above and below of course, so it's still three sides in the end. The biggest difference, however, is that you have to manually aim your shots. While you can target an enemy with the shoot command, the weapon sway doesn't guarantee a hit...or full hit, which is especially problematic with short range weapons that don't have laser sights. With the latter you can also perform ricochet shots and hit enemies from interesting angles. Think grenade bouncing in "Worms".

The enemies in the game vary quite a lot. Every enemy has its own stats and characteristicts, from cannon fodder to exploding melee bots to teleporting or flying enemies. Additionally you have to take low and high cover as well as environmental hazards into account when planning your moves. I can't stretch how much fun the combat is and getting increasingly better and cooler weapons. There's also some boss fights at the end of a chapter that are really well done and require a good strategy. In short: They're well done and fun.

And of course there's the phenomenal soundtrack in the hub areas and also during combat. If you think space country could be your thing...grab it!

Now to a few negative points:
- Item management is a bit of a chore, even though there is a sorting feature, but at least you can always see who carries what items when selecting them.
- Crew progression is too linear in my opinion. While every crew member is distinct and has unique traits, they simply level up and get one new skill or stat increase. This is something that could very well be improved upon should there be a sequel.
- Controls with mouse and keyboard are well done for the most part, but it should not be possible to shoot with the left mouse button since that will always mess up your shot. Took a while till I realized that using space bar is the way to go.
- Fen the Outsider is probably the most interesting (and arguably the strongest) character in the game, but is locked behind a DLC, despite integrating seamlessly into the story. Steam says he was released the same day the game was released, so that is something that annoys me quite a bit, since it's a whopping 5 bucks, a THIRD of the whole game price. I got it in a bundle, but still. That's unfortunately a big minus.

All in all though I had a blast. It's one of those games I just wanted to continue playing for some reason. And after you beat the campaign you can go at it in New game plus and choose a higher difficulty (there are 5 after all). That means you keep all bots and hats, but start at level 0 with no items. Definitely something to consider when you want to know how much value you get here for 15 lousy bucks. Other games barely offer 2 or 3 hours of gameplay for the same amount of money. A 9/10 if not for the outsider DLC...which brings this down to a 7/10 imho.

37854429.review:
What a ridiculously fun and charming game.

I first got into the Steamworld series from Steamworld Dig (Origins gave it out free) and found the robots to be quirky and the gameplay interesting, but I'm not a huge "dig" fan.

What I do love is strategy games, especially turn-based.

Heist is a turn-based strategy game that involves hat collecting, trick shots off of walls, and saving the world. The base game isn't overly long and can probably be completed in 10-12 hours. If you want max ratings on all levels, and maxing out the levels of your characters, you'll be looking to about 16-18 hours (two levels away from beating the game!).

Just like in the other steamworld games, there is a huge penalty when you die, ranging from 25% to 75% of your funds. Luckily you won't really need those funds, since its fairly easy to get new and powerful guns from replaying levels. And, of course, the less funds you have, the cheaper the penalty is.

The characters are all cute in their own ways, from an aggressive farmhand to an old bot who is sick of retirement. If you're familiar with Steam Powered Giraffe, their band makes many cameos and is featured in the OST.

Honestly, theres no reason you shouldn't have this game. It's fun, plain and simple.

37706897.review:
SteamWorld Heist: Primeiras impressões!

O cenário do jogo é um mundo Steampunk misturado com Spacecowboy e de Robôs. A água é a principal moeda de troca nesse universo movido à vapor.

Você joga com uma capitã robô de uma nave contrabandista, Capt. Piper Faraday.

O jogo tem todo um clima de velho oeste, os personagens, em inglês pelo menos, falam com sotaque e lembram aqueles estereótipos dos filmes de bang bang.
Tudo com um toque de humor e uma arte muito bonita, cartunesca e muito bem feita!
Você vai coletando chapéus e pode ir mudando de acordo com sua preferência, tem todo tipo deles e a partir deles podemos abordar a gameplay que é onde o jogo brilha.

É um jogo tático, por turno, 2D.
A grande sacada é o ataque, os tiros são skill based, ou seja, não tem aquela parada de porcentagem de chances de acerto igual a maioria dos jogos táticos, a "respiração" do personagem faz a mira não ser estável, portanto você precisa apertar no momento certo para o tiro ir aonde você quer!
Os tiros quicam, permitindo tiros dos mais diversos ângulos e tem uma câmera lenta que ativa quando você vai acertar na cabeça do adversário ou passa muito perto, nesse momento o tiro pode acertar apenas o chapéu do adversário que sai voando, criando toda aquela sensação de um bang bang clássico dos filmes de velho oeste!

Existem diversas armas de diferentes mecânicas, até agora vi uns 5 tipos diferentes, mas acredito existirem bem mais, o que fornece uma dinâmica foda em como abordar os mapas.

O jogo é separado por missões que você vai liberando de acordo com o desenrolar da história principal, em que você pode tirar de 0 a 3 estrelas ao finalizá-las.
O mapa da missão é gerado de forma procedural na maioria das vezes, o que fornece uma dinâmica bem legal, existe um sistema de cover, com as covers podendo ser destruídas e já vi por volta de uns 5 inimigos diferentes.

Estou jogando no hard e já falhei algumas vezes nas missões, tem que se jogar com cautela e de forma inteligente, como um bom jogo tático deve ser.

Recomendadíssimo, pelo pouco que joguei valeu muito a pena, jogo redondo e a um preço baixíssimo pela sua qualidade!

TLDR: Peguei esse jogo na promoção da steam por R$9,89 e vale cada centavo.

37487561.review:
SteamWorld Heist is a Cowbot's tale in the Wild Space where you invade the bad guys(tm)'s ships and take their loot and hats as you go along for the epic loot in each stage.

Starring Piper Faraday and her trusty crew of Seabrass and the pilot whose name I forget and their plant Earnest, who's helping out by being labeled and vegetable. Oh and as you go along you get more friends to help you shoot out the bad guys.

Aim your sharp shooting skills with that shot gun grenade lobber and watch the bad bot's bits fly all over the place! Kapew!

EDIT: I realized this isn't very helpful, so I'll clean up a little under here

The game play is much like a 2D XCOM or Invisible Inc., but unlike XCOM you don't have a hit percentage. You need to line up your shot with your controller or mouse, depending on how you play. And even then the aim isn't static; The gun bobs up and down to add a bit of challenge and timing to when you fire the shot. 

There are various guns that are available in the game and they are divided into various classes, namely:
The sharp shooter: Your regular sniper-like gun. They are the only class of guns that come with a laser sight to assist with aiming, but most of them require the user to not move before firing. Excellent guns to use for crazy skillshots around cover

Shotguns: Fires a spread of projectiles that only richochet on short range, but are very powerful up close

Machine guns: Rapidfire guns that shoot several projectiles in rapid succession. Typically more accurate than the shotgun at a distance, but don't richochet, much like the shotgun

Grenade lobbers: Fires an arching projectile that explodes on impact with enemies or cover, and bounces on non-platform surfaces. These are typically adequate for dealing with groups of enemies, or enemies behind cover. However, they also do friendly fire, so watch where you aim them!

Rocket launchers: Fires a projectile in a straight line that explodes on impact with any surface or enemy. Good for busting covers and bad bots hiding behind them, but also does firendly fire, like the grenade lobber. Don't aim it at me, you dingus!

Handguns: The most basic form of weapon that just about anyone can use effectively. With their decent range, you can richochet these projectiles they fire much like with a sharpshooter, but almost never come with a laser sight. These are reliable and powerful weapons, and makes and excellent replacement for the sharp shooters that makes your crew sitting ducks in order to fire.

As you play and succeed missions, your crew gains experience and levels up, unlocking new skills and perks each level. Each crew member has their own favoured kind of gun, so their skills will reflect that, and each crew member compliment each other in various ways.

37201143.review:
This game was my biggest pleasant surprise for the entire 2017. I don't think there's anything that could trump it in the remaining 5 weeks or so. I got it as part of a bundle (if I remember correctly) and fired it up just to see what it's all about. By that time, I'd played [i]SteamWorld Dig[/i] and expected a similarly fun but standard ramble up and (mostly) down spaceships. My oh my, was I in for a big knock on the old gourd!... Three hours later, I realized I'd dropped all the stuff I was doing that evening to play juuust a liiittle bit further.

It all begins with a simple story about steambots who gotta scrape together a living. Then you're thrust into a shoot-out and you quickly grok that the way forward must be careful tactical positioning, shooting, item-using, moving, always on your toes. Then come upgrades and shops and the magic of RPG character improvement. Then come crazy environmental and weaponry diversifications + complications. And on top (literally!) of all that come the hilarious hats, and the feisty gang of steambots whom you gather and upgrade over time. There's balance here, and depth, and laugh-out-loud moments, and also many dimensions to the characters, all of the above crammed into a seemingly innocuous side-scrollingy-platformy tactical team shooter.

That's precisely the beautiful thing about [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i]; it's so tightly packed with enticing bits and at the same time so smoothly flowing that I never had the feeling I was forced into the next part of the journey. Hell, I hate procedural generation, and I still played a bunch of randomly generated ship raids 5 or 6 or 7 times just to level up my cool steambot gang! And get some exercise with my new shooty toys, of course. Because in this particular SteamWorld, you gotta remember: always aim for their hats! ;-)

Happy heisting, steambot friends, and don't forget to lob the occasional grenade at an oil drum.

37069693.review:
Csodás 2D képregényes grafikájú, körökre osztott lövöldözős játék, egy poszt-apokaliptikus jövőben. 

A Föld darabokra robbant és az űrben lebegő maradványok között, robotok alakítottak ki maguknak életet. A víz a legnagyobb kincs, egyben fizetőeszköz, melyet az űrkalóznak szegődött robotok, illetve a stabil kormányt kialakítani igyekvő Royalisták igyekeznek begyűjteni. Ebben a környezetben egy kalózkapitány, Piper Faraday igyekszik túlélni, kicsi csapatával, miközben egy ellenséges kalózbanda épp át akarja venni a területét.
A célunk Piper és csapatának életben tartása, miközben felgöngyölítjük az ellenséges kalózok és a Royalisták titkos terveinek történetét. 

A játékmenet kisebb missziókból áll, melyek 5-10-15 percet vesznek igénybe, a feladat nehézségétől függően. Egy nehezebb pályán akár 20-30 percet is eltölthetünk, ha a maximális teljesítményre törekszünk. A feladat, kifosztani az ellenséges hajót és/vagy megsemmisíteni a kijelölt célpontokat. Mindezt egy X-COM-hoz és WORMS-höz hasonlatos harcrendszerrel, oldalnézetből. Látványos trükköket is végrehajthatunk, ugyanis a lövedékek legtöbbje visszapattan a felületekről. Megoldható, hogy a falról visszapattanó gránát, berepüljön a sarokba és látványosan megöljön egyszerre 3 ellenfelet. :)

Sztori, karakterek és főként zene szempontjából, különleges, kellemes játék a Steamworld Heist. Piper és legénysége vicces, kellemes társaság, akár csak a világ, amiben élnek. Hamar belopják magukat a szívbe. Az "Outsider" DLC-vel bekerült Fen karaktere, szintén ajánlott, mert sztori szempontjából is többet megtudunk általa, plusz rendkívül erős, jól összerakott csapattárs, aki minden megölt ellenfél után gyógyíthatja magát, vagy energiafegyverével egyszerre több ellenséget sebezhet.

Összességében: egy kellemes rajzfilm, akcióval, és taktikázással, rengeteg begyűjthető fegyverrel (és a legénység tagjainak csinosítására szolgáló sapkákkal ;D). Csak nagyon nehezen nem lehet szeretni.

When I first began, I figured "this is probably going to be one of those games that I bought for a good price but only play for an hour or so." And about an hour in, I was going to put it down.
I am soooo glad that I didn't.
The story is fun. The gameplay is enjoyable. The characters, with the little that you learn about them, have so much depth and personality. The mythology, while not particularly explored, is very interesting. You have an array of different characters to choose from, and the collectible hats are a nice touch. The combat styles are varied between characters, which lets you play to your style. It's easy enough to play on normal, but it still fun to play at lower difficulties. Those who enjoy a challenge will love the hardest difficulty, and the achievement hunting.
Would reccommend getting the Outsider DLC before you play it though, unless you intend to play multiple times. It unlocks new story missions and a cool new character.
Story: 9/10. Music: 10/10. Sound effects: 7/10. Controls/gameplay: 10/10. Enjoyment: 9.5/10. Replayability: 8/10.
Put-down-ability: 2/10.
All in all, would rate this game 9/10.

36654821.review:
As excellent as a 2D turn-based strategy action game can be. Worms-like combat in a single player story setting.

You unlock different characters as you advance through the game. Some use pistols and get bonuses if they hit enemies from the back, some are snipers and can ricochet bullets off walls to get headshots or hit enemies that are behind cover, some use explosives for area damage, some have more health and deal more melee damage some use close range weapons. Then you can level them up and gear them as you like to create a party fit for your play style.

You also find hats which are purely cosmetic, but it's kind of addicting to try and find them or shoot them off of enemies' heads and pick them up for yourself.

The level design is very clever, letting you approach most situations in multiple ways... except on a few occasions near the end of the game. I especially found using snipers and killing enemies with crazy trickshots using the curves and walls in the level.

It's a great game just like the first Steamworld game even though they have very little in common, mainly the aesthetics. Also recommend the Outsider DLC which includes a unique character and some new levels.
[i] Do not miss the sale [/i]

36216047.review:
這款橫向的回合制策略遊戲（戰棋類）在各方面都拿捏地恰到好處
雖然與Steamworld Dig是採用相同的世界觀，不過時間點相距過大，沒什麼銜接上的問題
劇情我沒有很認真看，大略是盜賊團在搶財寶時無意間給自己挖了一個坑，最後再填坑救世界


- 船長有雙美腿

真心不騙，跟其他女角相比她的腿最修長



- 以遠距離武器攻擊時，由玩家親自控制彈道的走向

每次射擊都能帶來新鮮感，而且射哪裡都可以[spoiler]可能會不小心「啊~~~嘶」一聲[/spoiler]
無論是直接射擊，以牆壁反彈子彈，引爆附近的易燃物來打倒敵人都是可行的
也不會因為不知道何時會捅你一刀的機率而冒出無名火
子彈射偏或是誤殺隊友就真的只能怪自己啦XD



- 有五種不同的難易度，還可以在進入各關卡前隨時切換

由易至難的排序是：休閒，普通，熟手，老兵，精英
就我個人第一遍玩老兵，第二遍玩精英的感覺是，如果你常玩這類遊戲直接選精英難度就行了
開發人員的建議難度是老兵，我想就算是不擅長的玩家也可以在休閒難度體會到樂趣

**要挑戰以某種難度通關的玩家請注意，若在最初選定難度之後有在遊玩時更改過任何一次難度，則通關時會以較低的難度為基準
譬如我玩老兵，但有一關我改成了休閒，則通關時會得到的是以休閒模式通關的這項成就



- 不空虛的三星挑戰

也許三星挑戰會讓人聯想到一些玩起來不怎麼有樂趣的手遊，但這款並沒有這個問題
部分隨機生成的地圖，與不知道會搜括到什麼樣的財寶的期待感，提高了不少再次挑戰的意願
在這裡要提的是，人物等級與敵人強度和寶藏稀有度無關，一切都是取決於關卡



- 很多很多的帽子

在戰場上如果把敵人的帽子射落，撿起來之後沒有陣亡，便能永久擁有那頂帽子
雖然僅僅只是外觀改變而沒有實質用途，卻也添加了一點趣味
看見很少見的帽子出現戰況又很嚴峻的時候會陷入兩難



- 太空酒吧聽好曲

本遊戲帶有人聲的演唱是由樂團Steam Powered Giraffe（蒸氣動力長頸鹿）所製作
冒險途中所經過的太空酒吧所看見的樂團成員，便是現實歌手實際登台演出的造型
無論是遊戲製作方或是樂團，兩邊都是蒸氣龐克粉呢



小到可以無視的缺點


- 物品欄過少

製作組不允許玩家成為裝備收集強迫症患者
就算在商店購買物品欄擴充仍然是不夠用，不得不在槍枝與配備當中取捨
雖然影響程度不大，但少了一些讓船員搭配裝備的自由度還是有點可惜


- 重玩要素較薄弱

New Game+可在一開始使用所有角色，但人物等級重置，物品只保留帽子，無新增的劇情或關卡
NG+比較像是為了想收集所有的帽子（有些帽子要從NG+購買）跟想要挑戰成就的玩家而準備的

[b] You might remember[/b] that scene from "Alien 4" where Ron Perlmans character ricochétes a bullet?! 
Well in this game Bullets do just that, and let me tell you, it is a [b]BLAST[/b] to see your bullet bounce off a wall and hit your target.
Also quite like the "VATS" targetting system from the Fallout series. It sort of never gets old if you ask me.

For me though it wasn´t a HARD game in particular, just somewhat random in some cases, which made me a bit frustrated at points.
Like when you do not play as a sniper and will have to rely on your IRL luck to just hope that the bullet riccohéts in the right path.
Ultimately, I lowered the difficulty and had an absolute blast! Since I could play around more with a litte less threatning attitude from the game.

I quite liked this!
And if you are a suckerfor turned-based-cowbots-in-space-games...I think you´ll have a jolly good time!

Very fun turn-based tactics game that is played from a 2d platforming perspective.  It has a lot of charm and personality and the tactics are fun, rewarding and challenging.  Some guns allow richocette shots which is unique and fun from this perspective.  Each bot on your team (maybe 9 or so of them eventually) is unique with it's own stratgeties and there is a nice variety of enemies that won't wear out there welcome before introducing new kinds.  The mission layouts are (mostly?) randomized so replaying a mission can still be fun.  Each mission is short so this is a good game to play when you only have 30 mins of time to spend.  Overall there is still lots of content though and it is well worth the money from that perspective.  There are lots of difficulty settings so it should be playable by almost anyone.  There is even a new game plus mode, but I didn't play it so I can't speak about it's value.  Although fun I didn't have any desire to play the game again (I almost never do so nothing against the game).

For negatives, the leveling and customization is quite stream-lined and basic, could be stronger but that is not what this game is going for so not really much of a negative.  Also the controls aren't the greatest.  I played the game using a mouse and it is a bit unwieldy.  The game says a controller is recommended so I can't hold that against it much though.  I also didn't have any incentive to try and collect the hats which the game seems to place a lot of importance on.  They are just a collection, cosmetic, time waster thing that I had no interest in.  It can be completely ignored though.

35754025.review:
This game has good music, nice art style, an okay story and character personalities (story/characters are probably the weakest part), and very nice gameplay. It's rare that I find a turn-based strategy game I enjoy, but this is one of them. The key feature mentioned on the store page about the difficuly is quite true, as you can adjust the difficulty to make it really rough or quite easy depending on what you are after, and you can adjust the difficulty between missions, in case you find it's too tough for you, or too easy.

The gist of the game is that you're a steampunk robot space pirate with a ship. You dock with other ships, boarding them with 1-4 characters, and go through, collecting loot and shooting enemies in turn-based combat. Each character has passive and active skills, and you can take the characters you want, who have a pretty good spread of decent abilities and passives to help you make a variety of good teams. Instead of XCOM Enemy Unknown's percent-to-hit chances, SteamWorld Heist has you aim the gun yourself, lining up shots, and some guns even have laser sights and you can ricochet the bullet to pull off headshots for extra damage, or even wild trickshots to hit enemies behind cover. Some missions count down before automated turrets power up and reinforcements start showing up, but I found the game was pretty fair with the time you're given, and you can push forward to escape in time.

Once you finish a mission, you're rewarded with loot and water, which acts as money, and you can even replay missions if you want more currency and loot, which is randomized (certain loot pools per level, of course). Your characters level up and gain new passive and active abilities, and you move along to another mission. The ships you invade have procedurally generated room layouts, and unlike a lot of procedurally generated games, I found this one worked well, because the idea is to invade a ship with an unknown layout, run room to room checking for and grabbing loot and taking out enemies, and then escape. The map variations make replaying a mission less repetitive to some extent.

I have not completed the game, and likely won't, but this is one of those rare games I don't care to finish but liked virtually everything in the game that I experienced. This is a solid game, and I think it's pretty darn good stuff.

35455596.review:
Irgendwann in einem Sale oder Bundle gekauft, weiß ich im Nachhinein nicht mehr, warum ich dieses Spiel überhaupt je gestartet habe. Vielleicht war es das Heist im Titel. Vielleicht fand ich das Artwork mit der Revolver tragenden Cowboy-Roboterin Piper irgendwie ansprechend. So genau ist mir das nicht mehr nachvollziehbar. Es ist vielleicht einfach der gesamte SteamWorld Heist Mix, der anspricht. Weltraum-Setting, Steampunk Roboter, Überfälle auf Raumfrachter. Irgendwie hat diese Formel schon immer funktioniert. Von Cowboy Bebop bis zur Firefly, ist es immer ein großes Vergnügen gewesen, wenn in den Tiefen des Weltraums einmal andere Geschichten erzählt werden, als die von Fortschritt, Erkundung und Ungewissheit. Zwar lässt sich auch in SteamWorld Heist eine unbekannte Bedrohung bekämpfen, die Prämisse des Spiels aber auf der die Mechanik beruht, nämlich das Ausrauben von Raumschiffen, durch taktische und geschickte Kämpfe, hat seinen ganz eigenen Charme.

SteamWorld Heist steckt voller liebervoller Details, die durchaus einen kleinen gesellschaftskritischen Impetus mit sich bringen. Beispielsweise ist die Währung des Spiels nicht etwa Gold oder wie man bei Robotern vielleicht noch denken könnte Öl oder Benzin, sondern Wasser. (macht ja auch irgendwie sinn bei der Titelgebenden SteamWorld) Damit machen Somit machen die Entwickler auf abstrakte Weise auf die Wichtigkeit von Wasser aufmerksam. Wenn sogar die Maschinen es für sich brauchen und klar ist Wasser ganz faktisch wichtiger als Geld oder Gold. Allein die verfügbare Masse lässt es im Bewusstsein der westlichen Gesellschaft in den Hintergrund rücken.
Als eine zweite kleine Spielerei empfand ich die Namens- und Geschlechtergebung der Robotercrew. Irgendwie kommt fast die komplette Crew sehr androgyn daher. Nicht alle Namen lassen sich eindeutig einem Geschlecht zuordnen, nicht alle Gesichter lassen sich eindeutig einem Geschlecht zuordnen. Damit bricht das Spiel Geschlechterkonventionen und das ganz nebenbei, ohne dass man etwas davon mitbekommt.
Und ganz kurz möchte ich auch noch die Hüter erwähnen. Vollkommen irrelevant fürs Gameplay lassen sich Hüte der Gegner herunterschießen und aufsammeln und schließlich beim nächsten Heist auf die Köpfe der eigenen Crew aufsetzen. Genau so sollten Collectibles behandelt werden, nicht relevant fürs Spiel, aber nett zu sammeln. Andere Spiele ermöglichen einen Fortschritt durch das Sammeln. Dadurch verkommt der Spieler immer häufiger zum Sammeler, denn es stärkt ihn. Hier ist es einfach eine nette kleine Spielerei und nicht essentiell.

Ich habe das Spiel so sehr ins Herz geschlossen, dass ich es gleich zweimal durchspielte. Das Zusammenstellen der Crew und die Auswahl der verschriedenen Waffen, sowie die zufallsgenerierten Innenräume machen dieses kleine Spiel unglaublich Variantenreich und liebenswert!

35433470.review:
SteamWorld Heist is without a doubt one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had all year. The game is an absolute blast to play through; personally, I don't think there's a single thing to hate about it. 

What this game has going for it.
The first thing that will grab your immediate attention is how beautiful this game looks; the choice of colors in combination with the unique art direction they took all cumulated into a visually striking game that will leave you awestruck. The music is also fantastic as well, and it gives off a strong Borderlands vibe, and I wouldn't be surprised if they took it as their inspiration. Lastly, the gameplay is also enjoyable to play. As the developers describe, it feels as if you're playing XCOM but in a 2D landscape with a unique twist to turn-based strategy and likable characters. All of them have their strategy and playstyle, and it allows for a whole bunch of variations to combat ensuring that you will almost never get bored. The story is nothing spectacular, but I would be lying if I said I didn't find it charming, entertaining, and humorous. 

What I think it could have done better:
There are three gun classes in Steamworld Heist: Sharpshooters, Assault, and Heavy. Assault weapons are by far the most underwhelming type because it gets outperform by practically every other classes. It trades accuracy and consistency for raw damage; however, the damage that you would get in return is so minuscule that the tradeoff will never be worth it. You are better off using a regular handgun in almost any situation. Fortunately, this is my only real gripe, But, if I could add one more thing to future sequels, then having Overwatch just like in XCOM would be hugely beneficial for the players. There are countless moments where you would find yourself being engaged by enemy reinforcements, but because of circumstances staying where you are is better than actually moving away, It will always give the players something to do and remedy all of those turns where you passed doing absolutely nothing. 

Some advice for beginners:
Positioning is crucial especially on higher difficulties as well as appropriate inventory management; not equipping the right gear and utilities for the appropriate characters will significantly prohibit their potential and usefulness in combat. Make it a habit to always think twice before selling an item and prioritize buying inventory upgrades before anything else. Hats are the glue that holds this experience together.

In conclusion, this should be in everybody's library. Buy it. Play it. Love it. But most importantly, don't forget to play while wearing your favorite hat!

35326656.review:
Steamworld Heist

This game was one of the best surprises in gaming I've had recently. Steamworld Heist is essentially a 2D Xcom style game, a strategic, turn based shooter. Unlike XCOM, where you get a % chance to hit the enemy based on your position, this game forces you to actually aim your gun in the direction of the enemy. It can get difficult if you're trying to eyeball a long range shot, or a ricochet shot off the wall.

The music was immersive and often pretty tense. The art style is fun and colorful, often using steampunk and cyber-robotic art themes. The story was silly but easy to follow. The gameplay is easy to learn, but it takes a while to find your best playstyle through experimentation. All the normal shooter classes are here; Sniper, Demolition, Assault and...the general pistol shooter guy. I'll call him the Soldier class for the hell of it.

I deeply enjoyed beating this game, and then going back to mop-up all the stars I missed. In order to get all the stars, you can't let a single character die during a mission, which is challenging as hell sometimes. It should be noted, permadeath is NOT in this game. If you die, that character comes back after that mission is over. It makes it for a more casual, enjoyable experience over XCOM.

I played this game for 14 hours and I can't think of anything bad to say about it. I suppose that means I give it a....
10/10

35204841.review:
1. I dig what Image & Form Games seem to be doing w/ their SteamWorld IP. They built the world and the lore and are now making games in whichever genre they see fit, each w/ its own uniquely SteamWorld twist. Specifically, they are having pretty remarkable success giving games a casual, approachable sheen and then still providing deeper gameplay for those who want it. You know, cool people like us. *High five*


2. The way they do this w/ SteamWorld Heist is to take X-COM-style turn-based combat and flip it to a 2D plane like a platformer. The change this makes is more psychological than it is practical. Really, most movement in most strategy games is only on two axes. Having those two axes match w/ the two used in Super Mario Bros. makes the whole thing seem a little more familiar.


3. This game is probably the closest we will likely get to a game based on Joss Wheaton's Firefly. It goes as far as to subtitle the game "You can't take the swag from me" when the credits roll.


4. You play as a motley crew of smuggler ro-bots. As you go about you mild mannered piracy, it is revealed that the government is up to some funny business, which you unravel to find yet more insidious machinations underneath the surface.


5. Combat is mostly gun-based w/ some melee and ranged explosive attacks mixed in for good measure. The characters have different special abilities and can only use certain guns, making them each serve a unique potential purpose in your crew.


6. Characters gain experience and become more powerful as the game progresses. You can replay levels as much as you want which lets you grind power-ups for your character. However, this process is pretty slow going and that encourages you to try new strategies rather than just tank up and take everything head-on.


7. It's easy enough to just roll through w/ your initial default crew but most new characters prove useful right away because you can give them current level gear even if they're at a lower level themselves.


8. In addition to the turn based aspect of the combat, there is an added real-time element when aiming your guns. Your hand wavers just a little bit and you have to hit the shoot button at the right moment. It turns combat into a bit of a mini-game w/o breaking flow.


9. This was originally developed for the 3DS and its turn-based nature make it a great fit for that platform but I personally enjoyed playing on the PC simply because the larger screen really showed off the beautiful artwork. It is not pixel-art quite but does have something of a nostalgic vintage gaming tinge to it, though of course in modern resolutions.


10. I can't say enough good the music. It's all done by Steam Powered Giraffe, who are a group that seems built from the ground up to make music for light-hearted steampunk video games. A really nice detail is the band is included in-game and is shown performing unique tracks at each of the bars you visit on the way--complete w/ vocals. You can buy the SteamWorld Heist sountrack off their Bandcamp page and you should.


11. Difficulty is adjustable before each mission and it does more than just give the enemies more less hit-points or add or subtract enemies from the game. Upping the difficulty changes the strategy you will have to use to beat each level. You have to leverage your team's strengths much better on higher difficulties because most levels have additional waves of enemies that come after a countdown and those can be pretty beastly as they get more powerful. For what it's worth, the default difficulty, "experienced," is well-chosen as it allows you to play somewhat carefully, make some mistakes and still win. It gives you a stiff punishment for failing but not one that will ever become insurmountable.


12. Most of the replayability here is going to come from either wanting to try higher difficulties or play through w/ different combinations of ro-bot combatants. To this end, it offers an new game+ mode that allows you to use all additional characters you acquire on your first play from the very beginning of the next.


13. This game is what I would describe as deceptively good and can really provide a lot of things to a lot of people. You can knock the difficulty down and get a pretty, light game to spend some spare clock cycles when you have an extra moment or you can dig in and get some pretty dense strategy going--and SteamWorld Heist is actually good for both.

35016217.review:
Космический тактический казуальный стимпанк с робоженщиной в качестве капитана. Шапки прилагаются…

[h1]На что это похоже?[/h1]
Космопера, где капитан — женщина. Даже лучше, потому что она — [i]робот![/i] В очень похожей паропанковской стилистики авторы уже выпускали вариацию диггера [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198084019881/recommended/252410]SteamWorld Dig[/url], но здесь пошли дальше. Тут по прежнему озвучка в «робостиле», зато есть весьма неплохая музыка и музыканты, даже лучше: музыканты-[i]роботы![/i]

[h1]Геймплей[/h1]
Игра разбита на три звёздные локации с разным оформлением и противниками. Каждый тактический эпизод начинается с того, что на  борт чужого космического корабля доставляется команда из 1-4 роботов под вашим управлением. Далее в пошаговом режиме нужно будет разобрать вражеский экипаж на запчасти. За время путешествия вы соберёте свыше десятка разного рода [strike]уникальных[/strike] ненормальных личностей. 

По владению оружием роботов можно разделить на снайперов (снайперские винтовки), штурмовиков (дробовики и автоматы) и специалистов по тяжёлому оружию (гранотомёты и тому подобное), пистолетами могут пользоваться все. Команда и её вооружение формируется непосредственно перед боем. В зависимости от собранного арсенала и команды стиль прохождения может серьёзно меняться. Ничего сложного особого нет. Посоветовать могу разве что не выбирать в качестве оружия то, которое требует на стрельбу все два очка действия, доступные роботу за  ход, так как постоянная смена позиции и непрерывный огонь — ключ к успеху.

Сюжетные эпизоды разбавляются необязательными, а также барами и магазинами, где можно прикупить оружия и обмундирования в обмен на отобранную у врагов валюту. Процесс обстрела оживляется требованиями закончить диверсионный акт за определённое количество ходов и задержка карается вражеским подкреплением. За убийство ничего не даётся, то есть все бонусы, кроме гарантированных за эпизод, придётся собирать самостоятельно, отвлекаясь от резни. Опыт распределяется только между выжившими участниками захвата, поэтому волей-неволей приходится опираться на одних и тех же членов с максимально раскаченными характеристиками.

Кроме стандартных для звёздной локации противников будут встречать и боссы, а также супербосс в самом конце. Game+ отличается от первого прохождения  только тем, что вся собранная команда будет доступна с самого начала, правда  вооружение и опыт будут утеряны. Хотя шапки останутся. Зачем роботам шляпы, да и вообще одежда — загадка. Приятная ни к чему не обязывающая игра на пару недель.

[h1]GNU/Linux[/h1]
Игра проходима от начала и до конца в среде Ubuntu 16.04 на ноутбуке со встроенной видеокартой от Intel® HD Graphics 4400. В игре используется «самопальный» игровой движок, но встреченные мной проблемы примерно те же, что и в случае «стандартного» Unity3D, а именно игра «вешалась», если переключаться из полноэкранного режима по Alt+TAB или на экране игры показывались «всплывающие окна» от сторонних программ и даже от информации, что получена карточка. Особых проблем это не вызывало. После убивания игрового процесса из терминала, игра без проблем восстанавливалась с последнего хода.

[h1]Обзор входит в список [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1103944566]Игры, Linux, Steam, обзоры[/url].[/h1]

34990449.review:
[h1]简介[/h1]
《Steamworld heist（蒸汽世界：劫掠）》是挖矿（大概是？）小游戏steamworld dig的一款外传性质作品。
本作舍弃了原本的挖矿玩法，转而尝试了一种“横版战棋2D射击”模式，简单说游戏基本采用回合制，玩家小队人数1~4人，在横版地图上先移动后攻击/射击/冲刺移动，射击类似平面台球游戏，基础的枪支都会有反射能力，其中狙击枪反射能力最强，也有榴弹或者火箭炮等武器，有着不同的弹道和反射特性。
主要剧情是玩家指挥Piper船长以及他的萝卜船员从打强盗抢钱到打外星文明抢武器顺便拯救了世界然后他的故事还在继续之类的冒险故事。

[h1]真·游戏简评[/h1]
+++新鲜的类战棋战斗模式配合颇有意思的横版射击
+掩体
+重玩性尚可，可以尝试更高的难度和不同的组队
+关卡数量比较多，关卡具有随机生成功能
+多个有趣而有性格的小伙伴，各自具有不同的能力，通过升级来加强他们的能力
+酒馆音乐好评
+多种类型的装备，个别稀有枪支有特殊的属性
+多种可选难度，适合各种玩家
+艺术风格
+挑战性

-相比起有趣的游戏模式，剧情稍显简单，很多地方似乎想营造幽默的感觉但是实际上不是很好笑……
-帽子系统，游戏可以射倒敌人头上的帽子收集，很多相关的成就，但是实际上帽子不提供任何属性。对于不感冒的人来说是个鸡肋的存在……
-人物等级很容易满，但是因为人物能力不是很平衡，通常我都不会更改小队成员，经验溢出……
-个别时候AI会犯傻，就算再最高难度也是这样

·顺便一说这个游戏，船员是有可能永远挂掉的，而游戏是每个回合自动存档一次，这意味着你需要作出或者大胆的射击，或者龟在掩体后面寻找更好的机会的选择。同时很多关卡有威胁等级，时间越长，威胁等级越高，就有越多的敌人增援蜂拥而至。

[h1]总评：[/h1]
《SH》是一款偏小游戏性质的类战棋游戏，以其游戏模式为主要卖点，假如喜欢玩战棋和平面台球游戏的可以试试，你依然可以在这款小游戏找到屏息射击的紧张感和巧妙利用场地优势的策略感。而且它不贵，等打折更便宜。
[h1]8.5/10[/h1]
DLC：The outsider给了一个新角色和一些新的战斗地点，喜欢本作的也值得一买。

[h1]推荐人群：[/h1]
战棋玩家、平面台球玩家、休闲玩家

[h1]不推荐人群：[/h1]
突突突玩家

[h1]有关语言[/h1]
没有中文，PC貌似也没有汉化，微妙的是本作的3DS版倒是有汉化……不过其实剧情不理解也可以玩下去。

[h1]难度评价[/h1]
中等难度允许有经验的战棋玩家用自由的组队方式攻略，最高的Elite难度个人觉得还是要选些强力角色并且还要小心翼翼的过关……

34908249.review:
Excellent game!

Pros:
- Unique setting
- Good writing
- deep enough tactical combat
- nice trickshots!

Cons:
- A little short (finished it with 31.3 hours on record on the highest difficulty)
- Some messed up achievements (see below)

First up, i really, really enjoyed the game - so much that i am replaying it now with a NG+, although i already finished it on Elite difficulty. Sadly, the game didn't recognize my first playthrough as Elite Playthrough because at the very start i selected "Experienced", played the tutorial in "Experienced", but after that selecting "Elite" for the first mission and never changed it back. Is it really supposed not to count as Elite playthrough just because you selected the wrong difficulty for the darn tutorial?!? That should be really changed.

Other than that, if you like games like X-Com, give this one a try. Putting a slight skill element where usually randomness decides if you hit or not is really a nice concept that made this game a lot less frustrating (and probably easier) than X-Com and similar games. Especially the sniper-trickshots in this game are amazing and allow skilled players to really hit targets others wouldn't hit...

I definitely would recommend this game to everyone who like turn-based strategy games. It's probably a good game to start discovering this great genre as well, since it's relatively easy to get into. Thumps up, would buy it again (and i hope it will have a successor!).

34799782.review:
SteamWorld Heist is a charming and enjoyable 2d turn-based squad tactics game. Think: XCom as a side-scroller, with the projectile trajectories of Worms and the story of Firefly.

Basically, you play as a band of smugglers ("Cowbots") who give up their life of crime to, well, save the world! The gameplay takes the form of a series of maps, some of which are shops or neutral bars, but most of which are combat maps. To complete these you must fulfill an objective such as 'Collect all swag' or 'Disable generators' or 'Kill the boss' or something similiarly straight-forward. You get a 3 or 4 star rating for completing the objectives & collecting the epic swag, without losing any steambots. To do this, you can field anywhere from 1 to 4 cowbots who have a regular weapon attack and a couple extra abilities, either from their class or from equippable utilities.

[h1]Are the base game mechanics fun?[/h1]

The most important question! Yes the game is fun to play.

Because you're making skill-shots, the game demands (and rewards) careful positioning and attention, and you're constantly having to make tactical decisions about whether to move and shoot - or sprint for a superior position, perhaps behind some nice cover.

What's more, the game has a decent variety of map-types. In some maps, you might have to defend a central room and stay alive for X turns. Others are timed affairs, in which you only have 15 turns before the ship explodes. Others are 1-bot commando-style affairs.

Furthermore, the game is very well-paced. In the likes of XCom, if you advance too swiftly, you might alert too many pods than you can handle. Here, however, you pretty much decide when to open the next door. But that doesn't mean you can just take it easy! Most maps have a countdown and as you spend your turns, reinforcements will arrive and turrets will start to come online to make your job tougher. It's enough to keep the edge on - but not so crazy that playing the game becomes too stressful.

[h1]How's the story?[/h1]

It's not compelling in its own right as something like the Witcher series, but then, so few games are. It does well to provide context and motivation for why you're doing stuff. As I said before, it clearly takes its direction from Firefly, including some clear allusions (e.g. "You can't take the swag from me").

[h1]What difficulty should I play on?[/h1]

The game offers a good variety of difficulties: Beginner, Normal, Experienced, Veteran, & Elite.

To give some context, I beat XCom 1 on Ironman Classic & XCom 2 on Ironman Commander. I decided to play Steamworld Heist on Veteran. It was a good fit. On the roughly ~40 or 50 maps, I got max stars 85% on my first try. I had 9 failures, including 4 on one map. I had a couple rage moments - but most of them were my fault, for being too impatient when making shots. I played maybe 5 or 6 repeat missions to level up some of my alternative characters.

Given this, I don't think anyone should play Beginner. Probably too easy. Normal would be for those who are bad at tactics games or really want to take it easy. Experienced is probably equivalent to 'normal.' Veteran is good for those who are experienced at these games. Elite will require multiple attempts on some maps and perhaps some grinding.

[h1]Anything else?[/h1]

I was pleased to find so many songs with vocals. I was doubly pleased to discover that Steam Powered Giraffe, a rather well-regarded geek band you can find at the likes of, say, Dragoncon, had done Steamworld Heist's soundtrack. Their sound is unique and unapologetically geeky and added a lot to the game. Do yourself a favor and listen to a few songs from the soundtrack.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]

Great game. It totally deserves its high reviews and was absolutely worth the money and time I spent on it.

34761839.review:
Steamworld Heist is a fun, reasonably casual game with a pleasing art style and mechanics that will appeal to fans of turn-based strategy.

The steampunk aesthetic, gentle humour and Worms-esque side-on tactical turn based combat kept me entertained for about 20 hours, which is what it took me to complete the campaign at a leisurely pace that included replaying a bunch of missions to max out a few different crew members, just so I could test out their various abilities.

Personally I don't think I'll bother going back and running through again, as I have so many other games to spend my time on, but I feel I got value for money so I have no regrets. It's definitely worth picking up on sale, and I will be checking out other Steamworld titles by the same devs in the future!

34700360.review:
Do you like robots? Do you like guns? Better yet, do you like robots shooting guns? If so, Steamworld Heist is for you. 

The story of Steamworld Heist is simple: You play as Piper Faraday, who is what's known as a steambot. After losing all but two memebers of your crew, you must go on a quest to build new crew and collect tons of treasure. But watch out! Along the way you'll run into a myriad of baddies that you and your crew will have to deal with. Ranging from scrappers to imperials, to even aliens, there's never a lack of things to shoot.

The gameplay is in the style of a 2d turn-based shoot-em-up sidescoller. At first, you may say: "But PotPi, that just sounds like insanity!". You'd be correct in this assumption. However, there is a method to the madness. Once you learn what crew members use which weapons and utilities, and how to richochet the bullets correctly, it becomes much easier. Each crew member has 4 slots: One for a firearms (the shooty thing), two for utilities (the powerup and healing things), and one slot for a hat (the head thing). Weapons, utilities, and some hats can be found or bought with in-game currency called Gallons.

Hats are cool. You can buy some of them in shops, but those aren't the cool ones. The cool ones are retrieved by shooting them off of the heads of your enemies and stealing them from their lifeless corpses. Some hats are more rare than other, so keep an eye out for the good ones! :D

Pros: 
1. Easy to grasp gameplay that still has depth for experienced players
2. Many crew members to choose from (10 total, I believe)
3. Customization is almost limitless with the combinations of weapons, ultilities, and 100 bajillion hats

Cons:
1. Story could be a bit more fleshed out, but the gameplay makes up for it
2. Don't play Elite difficulty. Just don't.

Overall, this game was well worth the $4.99 I spent on it during the summer sale, and I'd say it's still worth $14.99 when not on sale.

8.8/10

34671382.review:
Habiendo jugado a SteamWorld Dig, tenía ganas de probar su secuela no directa. Y aunque solo comparten universo, la verdad es que SteamWorld Heist me ha gustado mucho.

Jugando la campaña directamente en difícil, puedo decir que no es un juego complicado, aunque penaliza el ir sin cuidado y los errores tontos como cualquier tactics. 
Lo mejor, el toque de acción de los tiroteos y los rebotes de las balas. Llega a ser muy satisfactorio alcanzar a un enemigo con un rebote bien calculado y una moderada dosis de suerte.

La jugabilidad es muy buena, yo he jugado con mando (Xbox One) y me ha resultado muy cómodo adaptarme a los controles. Todo resulta intuitivo y responde estupendamente.

Las misiones y los enemigos son lo suficientemente variados como para resultar siempre entretenidos. Los mapas se generan de forma aleatoria, y aunque me ha ocurrido, ha en un par de escasas ocasiones en las que se ha generado una situación injustamente peliaguda. Normalmente, funciona muy bien.

Los gráficos son excelentes, con un estilo artístico sobresaliente, colorido y vibrante. Los efectos especiales añaden impacto a las armas, que resultan francamente satisfactorias de usar.
La música y los efectos sonoros están a la altura del apartado gráfico, y aunque el country no es mi género favorito, las baladas cantadas son interesantes. Si te gustan de verdad, te recomiendo que pilles la B.S.O.

La mecánica de los sombreros es entretenida y aunque es puramente estética, pica lo suficiente como para intentar hacerse con todos esos sombreros raros que aparecen por el juego. Una adición interesante, que le da color al juego, y es totalmente opcional (excepto quizás para los logros).

En resumen, SteamWorld Heist es un excelente juego no solo para los amantes de los tactics, sino que lo recomiendo también a aquellos y aquellas que deseen dar sus primeros pasos por el género. Resulta accesible y muy divertido. 100% recomendable.
Y si no lo habéis probado, SteamWorld Dig es otro gran juego.

PD: escribo este análisis sin haber comprado el DLC. He quedado satisfecho con el contenido básico del juego (que no es poco) a falta de conseguir las cuatro últimas estrellas. No tengo claro si me haré con el DLC, pero si lo encontráis en oferta, seguro que merece la pena.

34637871.review:
Quick Summary: Steamworld Heist is a side-scrolling turn based strategy shooter game with simplified gameplay and weapon/hat collecting to spice things up. If you’ve played Steamworld Dig (you should, it’s pretty fun), Steamworld Heist is completely different in terms of gameplay, but the graphics/storytelling are similar. I think the 2 games may actually take place in the same “universe” but the stories don’t overlap so you can play one without playing the other and not miss out on any important plot points.

The story follows a group of pirate steam bots (robots that run on water/steam) some time after the destruction of Earth, as they fly around on their rickety space ship hijacking other space bots to steal their water. Water is the “money” of the game and you can use it to purchase weapons/items/hats in numerous shops found throughout the game. However, the best stuff is usually found as loot during missions. All the gear has tiers, for example tier 2 is better than tier 1, and when you find a gun during a mission, often it’s a higher tier than you can currently buy. The game allows you to replay missions over and over for water and loot, so you can grind endlessly to level up or equip yourself for difficult missions (one boss in particular is a nighmare). 

During each mission, you control between 1 and 4 of your steam bots (each of your bots has unique skills) in horizontal/vertical scrolling levels where you fight varying numbers of enemies in turn based combat. Generally speaking enemies die in 1-3 shots, but like the Worms games, you need to aim your gun yourself, so there is at least some skill involved. As with most turn based games, you should take care to kill enemies during your turn rather than leave several with partial health (killing 1 enemy while leaving 3 undamaged is better than leaving all 4 near death). 

In terms of inventory management, each of your bots has a slot for a weapon, 2 slots for items such as repair kits or armor, and 1 slot for a hat (purely cosmetic). Most of the enemies you fight are wearing hats that you can blast off (“wasting” a turn because knocking off a hat does no damage) and you can collect the hat for your own future use. Most of the hats are common (enemies of the same type almost always wear the same hat) but there are a few “rare” hats that you see once every 100 enemies or so. These are usually the hats that are tied with Steam achievements, and can take hours and hours to collect.

Reasons to play Steamworld Heist:
+You enjoyed Steamworld Dig, especially the art design and music sound track.
+You like turn based strategy but don’t want to play “hardcore” games. XCom was too difficult for my liking, so something more casual like this fit me well.
+You have a low end computer but still want to play something fun/relaxing in short bursts (30 min to 1 hour at a time) for a long time. The campaign took me over 15 hours to complete (because I went out of my way to level up my bots), and the game is not demanding in terms of hard drive space or other system requirements.

Reasons NOT to play:
-You’re looking for a real challenge (like XCom Iron Man Mode) and not a casual game
-You want super modern graphics (this game looks hand drawn, sort of charmingly cartoony)
-You really care about your Steam achievement completion %. If you don’t own the DLC for this game (I don’t) you can’t “easily” get more than 60% of the achievements without a great deal of grinding for hats. When they say a hat is rare, they mean REALLY rare. 

Overall the game is great fun and you may already own it from the $1 tier of a Humble bundle. Lucky you because Steamworld Heist is definitely worth playing in my opinion.

Great game. Basically 2D XCOM with a focus on trick shots. Instead of the bullshit RNG accuracy stat that plagues most of these tactical RPGs, you aim your shots and pull the trigger. And for extra flavor, you defeat cover primarily by bouncing shots off of walls or ceilings. Landing headshots on targets behind cover via a round that you intentionally bounced off of 2-3 surfaces is pretty damn satisfying.

I honestly don't have any complaints truly worth mentioning. But I feel like I have to say something about the music. I hated it. Most of it was fine, but everytime that guy started singing I thought about turning it off in the options. Literally the first time I've had that reponse to a game's music before. Nothing against whoever that is, but man was it off putting.

Music aside, good game. Would love to see the core mechanic in this game used elsewhere

[h1] Apartados: [/h1]

[list]
    [*]Jugabilidad: 5/5
    [*]Apartado visual: 5/5
    [*]Sonido: 5/5
    [*]Innovación: 5/5
    [*]Argumento: 4/5
    [*]Optimización: 5/5
    [*]Dificultad: 5/5
    [*]Multijugador: N/A
[/list]

*Veredicto del Gober: 97.14

[code]
[b]-Jugabilidad: En este mundo no hay lugar para los humanos, las máquinas de vapor no recuerdan su extinción y son quienes gobiernan el sistema solar, uno asolado por piratas, la realeza y otras creaturas, su Jugabilidad es básica, nada elaborado, su simpleza lo hace rico,  diriges un escuadrón pequeño de máquinas a vapor, tripulantes de una nave cuyo destino es salvar el universo conocido, variedad de armas, armaduras y habilidades para los protagonistas, hacen que este simpático juego, pese a su simpleza nos pueda encantar.

[b]-Apartado Visual:[/b] Para ser un indie, tiene un apartado visual bastante llamativo, digno de otros grandes títulos como Limbo, su ambientación está bien cuidada teniendo en cuenta la naturaleza 2D del apartado.

[b]-Sonido:[/b] Una banda sonora digna de un título de primera categoría, los robots no hablan pero los sonidos de la ambientación y las armas están bien cuidados.

[b]-Innovación:[/b] La temática que tiene este juego es única, por lo que no le será difícil alcanzar la máxima calificación en este apartado, es innovador, simple y los robots tienen un encanto excepcional.

[b]-Argumento:[/b] Simple pero suficiente, se trata de un indie, pero cada partida terminada nos deja con ganas de más, de saber que sigue o que secretos esconde el próximo objetivo, además de gozar de una extensión apropiada, no hay que subestimar los títulos idie, aunque se podría haber añadido una que otra cosilla al argumento.

[b]-Optimización:[/b] Al igual que con el apartado visual, se recalca que es un título 2D, no es exigente, con un video integrado de primera generación se puede correr el título con una calidad adecuada y sin ninguna clase de problemas, creo que eso dice suficiente sobre que tan bien optimizado se encuentra esta obra.

[b]-Dificultad:[/b] No posee nada negativo en cuanto a dificultad, si se juega en los niveles más altos, será un verdadero reto, para ser un indie, y se que lo he recalcado, debo decir, felicidades, buen buen buen trabajo.

[/code]

[h1] Conclusión: [/h1]

Este tipo de títulos categoría indie, nos traerán de vuelta viejos recuerdos de la antigua escuela, sin embargo, no he visto antes alguno que posea un espíritu tan propio y una temática tan singular, lo que hace que se gane verdaderamente la calificación que se le otorga. Un gran trabajo creativo.

[h1] Veredicto del Gober: 97.14 [/h1]

[i] – “SteamWorld Heist es ese juego retro que andabas buscando si te gusta la acción táctica” – “Singular, con una esencia que lo hace especial”. [/i]

Me enamoró este juego y tengo miedo volver a él por engancharme fuertemente como me pasa con juegos como el X-Com.

34343171.review:
As far as turn-based tactical strategy games go, this is among my favorites. For the third installment in Steamworld series, the devs have been doing a great job at making very fun and addicting games. I liked Steamworld Dig because it was very relaxing and was reminiscent to Super Motherload, which is a game I adore. I was surprised that their next game was once again completely different in every way despite being a direct sequel. By tackling this genre in their own steampunk fashion, they struck gold yet again. 

Steamworld Heist's gameplay is essentially a 2d XCOM. There is no base management or perma-death, but the similarites come from the combat and character classes. Gameplay is also similar to Worms in terms of using your aiming skills to line up shots and bounce grenades. With the added effect of ricocheting bullets to kill your targets hiding in cover, it all makes for a very satisfying experience. Each character has 2 action points per turn which you can use to move or attack. Each character also has their own set of specific weapons and abilities. Leveling up unlocks more skills for that character. Mixing and matching your team is crucial for each battle. You can earn money from pickups to buy more weapons and items from shops, which can be accessed via the world map. There are also TONS of hats to collect and wear, usually earned by shooting off the enemies head with precision aiming, which is very rewarding.

All the characters are extremely likeable. You get to learn more details about your crew in between missions with some added quirky humor. This connection with your team really builds up and adds development to make them memorable. The music is also done by an authentic steampunk style band, there were a few songs I thought were really good. I wholeheartedly enjoyed this game, and highly recommend if you like turn-based tactial strategy games similar to XCOM and Worms. Can't wait to see what style of game this company will make next.

34231838.review:
As the name suggests, you are a group of steampunk heisters. In this case, you are a group of robots pulled into a scheme to save the universe (or at least get the heat off your own backs). you play through procedural generated levels trying to gather as much loot as possible, grab the big box, and get off the ship while killing any robots that get in your way. You level up your robots and gather loot, allowing you to increase in strength.

This game is a perfect example of when NOT to use procedural level generation. As a heist game, you should seek to prepare a plan ahead of time, choosing the best robots from your group for the task, and implement a carefully crafted plan.  However, the randomness of the levels means, if you fail the first time, you cannot plan for the next time as everything from the layout of the ship to the enemies you might face will be completely different. Essentially, you load up your highest level robots with your best gear and bash away hoping that you get a lucky draw on the level. At one point, I had planned out a level, sending my tanks to hold off the enemies while I sent my fast guy to deal with the objective, a destructible object that, for the past three goes, had not had an enemy in the room. Of course, this time the room had a very durable, high damage enemy causing my quick robot to die and force me to move back one of my other robots leaving a hole in my defenses and causing me to lose the level. I realized at this point that planning was futile and I had to hope the dice rolled in my favor. 

This type of rogue-like levels wouldn't be so bad if you either gained something from lost levels or simply were thrown back in. Sadly, the designers decided to punish you for your bad luck with a loss of in-game money with every loss and no experience or loot. Meaning that if you hit a brick wall level that is too far above you, you must grind past levels until you stand a chance or get a lucky break. 

I don't recommend buying this if you want a solid turn-based tactics or heist game as it is a poor example of either. If you like grinding and luck-based gameplay, I suppose you could do worse than this game. It is a good game hampered by poor design choices.

34226979.review: What a gem of a game. Steamworld Heist is easily one of the best games I bought during the summer sale, and everything from the challenge to the soundtrack blew my expectations out of the water. That isn't to say that this game is soul crushingly difficult, but more so that it's challenging enough to feel quite rewarding without endlessly punishing the player. (Certain levels have more of this quality than others.) On top of all of that, the art style and writing enrich the world and give it a surprisingly unique feel for a game that on the surface seems fairly run of the mill as far as the steam market is concerned. If you enjoy a moderately challenging strategy game, buy this. If you hate strategy games with all of your heart but still appreciate the art, music, and effort put in by the creators, watch someone else play this game while you smirk reading the dialogue and buy the soundtrack. Just give these guys some type of reward. They've earned it.

33995688.review:
9/10

Much has been said about Steamworld Heist, a game featuring sentient robots where you ride around on a space pirate ship as Captain Piper, collecting items and crew and attacking other ships and space stations. It's a party-based, turn-based title that reminds many of a 2D X-Com: Enemy Unknown. However, in Steamworld Heist, there's no researching, building bases, or selecting abilities. You either find items outright or currency used to buy them, and your characters gain abilities automatically when they level. The player decides which weapon classes are their favorites, and then takes characters into battle that can use those weapons and have complementing supporting abilities. Personally, I was a fan of sharpshooter class weapons (some of the most satisfying moments in the game involve bouncing bullets off of walls to hit enemies in cover), shotguns, and missile launchers.

Although in some ways Steamworld Heist is simpler than XCOM: EU, I actually found that I didn't miss the base-building or research elements. The only thing I can think of that might make this title better would be a little more focus on the backstories of the different robots you've recruited. The bottom line is that it's a lot of fun to take a crew equipped with your favorite weapons into a ship and slowly dismantle all the enemies by making accurate shots and taking advantage of explosives, holes in cover, etc.
