Finally finished this game today and it sure is great! The combat is great, dialogue between characters is interesting and humorous. I deeply enjoyed experiencing and playing through this game! The DLC is definitely worth it as it adds more missions, weapons, a new character, and more dialogue!

33982155.review:
This is a game I have bought on multiple platforms now (3ds, Wii U, IOS and now PC) and once again I have not remotely regretted it. I could rant about how much I adore this game (or the kickass dev's) for hours but I’ll try keep it brief.

Story - What can I say about this, it’s not too complex and you don’t need to play the previous Steam World game so you can jump right into this one (though I would recommend playing Steam World Dig as well as it is quite a fun game), You are basically just a Robot Space Pirate who has had enough shit so it’s time to take down whoever really pisses you off e.g. an entire Space Robot Government. Granted it is kind of straightforward and could be more fleshed out but hey for what the game is it works quite well. (7/10)

Gameplay – At times yes, the gameplay can be difficult and yeah, a little bit repetitive but hey, that’s possibly just cause I’m not too good at games like this. One big issue I do have with this game is the Inventory management as it is quite harsh and you absolutely will have to get rid of a useful item here and there to make room. The straightforward combat is very pleasing and satisfying and feels just like a western shootout… well most of the time at least. (8/10)

Characters – Oh man… I adore almost all of these characters so much (not you Sally Bolt) They all have vastly varying skills, designs and backstories and I found myself always grinding to have all crew members around the same level so I can swap them out depending on the mission (Though I usually use a crew consisting of my favs Piper, Sea Brass and my main girl Fen.) (10/10)

Soundtrack – MmmMMmMMmmMMm Good shit, the ambient backing tracks go from creating a great feel for the coldness and emptiness of space all the way to the excitement of battle, then there’s the vocal soundtrack created and performed by the band Steam Powered Giraffe. Them creating the soundtrack is how I found this game and oh MAN I am glad they did, the feel of their music is great and it fits so well and oh man that Main theme is dope as fuck. (9/10)

All up this game is super enjoyable and is really good because you can just jump in play a few levels and jump out or you could play for hours, the addition of the DLC is fun and I literally cannot use the Character from it (Fen) she is just too fun to play as. So as a conclusion I would say definitely get this game if you are remotely interested in Robots, Steampunk, Space or Turn Based Shooters.
 
 8.5/10

33887021.review:
Dopo Dig, Image&Form torna alla ribalta con un altro titolo della serie SteamWorld.  
Avete presente Dig, no? Quell'indie col robot che scava. 
Ecco, scordatevelo perché Heist non c'entra un tubo, almeno come gameplay.

Pur prendendola larga, è ambientato nello stesso universo narrativo di Dig con rimandi più o meno evidenti, ma qui seguiamo le vicende di Piper, un'intrepida robottina a capo di una piccola astronave con la quale fa scorribande in lungo e in largo attorno a ciò che rimane della Terra (rip), saccheggiando astronavi di altre fazioni di canaglie spaziali. A lei si aggregano presto un nutrito gruppo di ribelli, reclutabili via via, e tutti assieme si imbarcheranno in un'avventura per risollevare le sorti dell'umana stirpe (cit.).

Invece di essere un breve platform/"simulatore di arricchimento tramite picconate" o in qualunque altro genere vogliate inquadrare Dig, Heist è invece uno strategico 2D sparacchino più dalle parti di X-COM, in cui a ogni turno dobbiamo decidere attentamente come muovere i personaggi, se farli sparare, riparare dietro qualche barriera o usare un oggetto, ma con un'importante differenza: mettere a segno o meno i colpi non dipende da fantasiose e improbabili percentuali sulle quali bestemmiare e farci i meme, bensì dalla nostra mira vera e propria. 
Molte armi hanno infatti un mirino incorporato che - pur ondeggiando, altrimenti è troppo facile - mostra la traiettoria del proiettile, per cui ci si deve spesso ingegnare con millimetrici rimbalzi sui muri per colpire il nemico alle spalle o alla testa. 

La parte ruolistica gioca un ruolo importante in questa struttura: in ogni missione si possono portare 1-4 personaggi, ognuno con 3 slot per gli oggetti e le sue skill specifiche sbloccabili salendo di livello, capace di impugnare un tipo o l'altro di arma e in grado di muoversi di un certo numero di caselle. Vi sono armi da cecchino (col mirino), da mischia, a corto raggio, pesanti (che fanno danni ad area) e una mezza infinità di oggetti da comprare o trovare quali armature, granate, medikit, jetpack e quant'altro permetta di sopravvivere più a lungo o di dare vita a tattiche specifiche. 

Ogni livello (generato semi-casualmente) ha un obiettivo specifico, che va dall'eliminare tutti i nemici alla raccolta del bottino, ma sono presenti anche alcuni boss piuttosto impegnativi. Oltre a un tesoro dal contenuto fisso e unico, il resto del bottino consiste in un certo numero di sacchi sparsi in giro, che al termine della missione possono conferire galloni d'acqua (la valuta del gioco da spendere nei negozi), equipaggiamento non comune oppure raro, ovviamente il più utile e difficile da trovare.

La trama mantiene più o meno la stessa idea di base di Dig ma è senz'altro più lunga, sulle 10 ore. Ci sono poi 5 diversi livelli di difficoltà, missioni sfida e un sistema di valutazione finale con le solite stelline d'oro, che incentiva a rigiocarlo più volte anche alla difficoltà più alta, dove è sì impegnativo ma neanche troppo sleale. 
Menzione a parte per la raccolta di cappelli, grande classico che non dovrebbe mancare in nessun gioco: oltre a comprarli in appositi negozi, si troveranno raramente in testa alle varie tipologie di nemici e una volta colpiti con attenzione per farli volare via, si potranno raccogliere, collezionare ed equipaggiare sui nostri robot. Come farne a meno? 

Heist non è però esente da alcuni minimi difetti che almeno la prima volta mi hanno dato un po' fastidio: uno è la gestione dell'inventario, non troppo intuitiva e un po' caotica, con la possibilità di equipaggiare gli oggetti solo all'inizio di ogni missione e che vengono rimossi se dati a un altro personaggio. 
Secondo, una certa tendenza in una buona metà dei livelli a far partire subito l'allarme (con conseguenti rinforzi), che costringe a fare le cose di fretta per non venir sommersi da nemici/torrette e soprattutto a sperare che, nella casualità del tutto, non spawnino in posizioni sfavorevoli e non vadano a chiudere all'istante un ignaro personaggio che aveva come unica colpa quella di trovarsi nel posto sbagliato senza saperlo. In questi casi la tattica va un po' a farsi benedire, e avrei preferito la prevalenza di un approccio più calmo e ragionato. 

Anche la grafica è sostanzialmente la stessa di Dig, con un adorabile stile western/steampunk e un ottimo design dei personaggi/nemici e delle ambientazioni, mentre la colonna sonora è affidata agli Steam Powered Giraffe, gruppo folk-rock composto da tre tizi squinternati che nessuno ha mai sentito, ma che ha realizzato dei brani cantati (nei vari bar o dopo gli scontri coi boss) così belli ed azzeccati che sono quasi invogliato a comprargliela. 

In buona sostanza Heist è un titolo dal gameplay estremamente solido e divertente, ma soprattutto la dimostrazione che gli sviluppatori sono senz'altro maturati dal pur buono ma ancora semplicistico Dig, riuscendo a passare per due generi così diversi senza problemi e alzando nel contempo anche la complessità e la qualità delle loro produzioni.

33736231.review: I love this game. It's 2D XCOM, and honestly, I enjoy it much more than I enjoy XCOM. Everything from the aesthetic to the audio makes me love this game. I got it from a pay what you want bundle, and if I knew how much I would enjoy this game, I would have gladly paid the full price, if not more, for it. There are so many different options to do a playthrough of, as there are about 10 characters, and usually you only bring 3 or 4 into a mission, and it is just so unique. You can customize each character with different item sets, and play completely different styles depending on what you as a player like to do. I absolutely hate grinding, and I generally try to find ways to avoid it, and this game let me do exactly that. If you play smart and actually use strategy, you don't have to grind ever. It does get a little hard playing this way, but the fact that it allows you to do that is fantastic. I set out to achieve 3 star ranks (the highest) on every single mission available because I wanted to really get everything this game had to offer. Also, Cowboy Robots in space as a theme? 33663040.review:
Reviews for this game are Overwhelming Positive. That puzzles me a bit. While I'll add my thumbs up I don't see this game being much more than decent. It's certainly not one that I'm likely to gush over. 

Steamworld Heist is a turn based game where you go from mission to mission (which so far have just been randomly generated ships) and flight aka worms style combat. You move, fire and then watch the other side take their turn. Repeat ad nasuem. Eliminate the enemies and you move on. If you don't, well...more on that later. 

The positives, and the reasons I'm giving it a thumbs up, are that the game works, has a solidly-built premise and decent mechanics. The art style is unique though in motion I find it less charming than in the screenshots. The firing and aiming mechanic is fairly well done and creates a sense of skill (that I may not possess). The game has been solid without any bugs after 4 hours of gameplay.

Okay, so why the tepid recommendation?

1. I hate the sounds and the music. These are not the types of things that usually bother me but in Steamworld Heist I really despise both of them. The sounds are mechanical like "grunts" and I find them just annoying to the point that I'm skipping as much dialog as I can so I don't have to hear it. If there's supposed to be something interesting in the dialog I'm missing it because I don't want to hear the GRUNT BOOP GRUNT character noises.

The music...well, it was so bad that I finally turned it off. It's like fingernails down the blackboard to me. I can't remember the last time I had to turn off the music for a game but in this case their sound designer and I are on polar opposite pages. 

2. It's punitive. Fail a mission and you have to give up about half your "water" (money). The layouts are randomized and I've run across a couple that were a bit unfair. It's not really fun to have most of your stuff wiped away because you ran into a bad layout. I freely admit that I'm not very good at this game but I shouldn't be forced to play on casual just to continue the game. The same goes for missions where there's an alert in "X" turns. I've run into many missions where the ship layout simply won't allow that to happen. So I keep getting respawning enemies behind me because...why?

3. It's repetitive. In fact, it's grindy. You do the same thing mission after mission, ship after ship. With no overarching meta game and a story I couldn't care less about, the game is reduced to just one combat mission after another with no break. I'm fairly bored after 4 hours and I'm just now getting to the second area. I held out hope that this would be different and got into the area and....not really. New enemies. Same exact gameplay mechanic.

4.  Frankly, I'm not very good at this and don't really like the aiming mechanic. Your robots' hands sway as they aim and this makes lining up that perfect angle frustrating. My twitch reflexes aren't what they once were due to age (arthritis sucks, folks) and that makes this game overly challenging for me. It's groan inducing to miss a shot because you simply can't possess the motor control you did when you were young. 

Again, there's no reason to give this a thumbs' down because it executes what it set out to do. But I'm not feeling this one and I'm not sure I'll ever return to it. So as always, YMMV but Steamworld Heist is one I'm going to buck the trend on a bit and give this more of a tepid half a thumbs up rather than an enthusiastic recommendation.

33662382.review:
Mientras que Dig nos bajaba a las profundidades de una mina, Heist nos eleva al espacio y transcurre cientos de años después. La gran protagonista es la capitana Piper Faraday, una steambot (robot a vapor) que desertó hace un tiempo del ejército real y ahora viaja por el espacio en su nave en busca de galones de agua, el bien más preciado de la galaxia ya que es lo que hace funcionar a los steambots y al resto de tecnología de esta sociedad steampunk. Es un mundo habitado por robots con consciencia propia, en el que la Tierra voló en pedazos y la vida robótica se ha establecido en el espacio.

A lo largo de la aventura vamos ampliando la tripulación de Piper con personajes jugables que nos encontramos en bares especiales entre misión y misión. Algunos de ellos se nos unen sin pedir nada a cambio mientras que otros lo hacen a cambio de cierta cantidad de galones de agua (que actúan como moneda en el mundo del juego), y algunos sólo nos acompañan si hemos reunido la reputación suficiente (nuestra reputación depende de los resultados que obtenemos en las misiones).

Disparos tácticos
SteamWorld Heist es un juego de estrategia por turnos con jugabilidad 2D lateral, con elementos de acción shooter. Las misiones de desarrollan en las naves enemigas que abordamos, las cuales (al igual que la mina de Dig) se generan aleatoriamente y con una distribución de elementos diferente en cada partida (un gran punto a favor de su valor rejugable). Dependiendo de la misión, participan entre uno y cuatro de los miembros que escojamos de nuestra tripulación.

Controlamos por turnos a nuestros steambots, que consiguen experiencia al completar misiones y aprenden distintas habilidades cada uno al subir niveles. Podemos moverlos varios pasos y a continuación disparar, o desplazarlos un poco más lejos y acabar el turno sin atacar (hay numerosos puntos de cobertura en forma de barriles y otros elementos). Si nos colocamos justo al lado de un enemigo, también podemos atacarle con los puños de nuestro steambot (hay personajes mejores que otros en el cuerpo a cuerpo; la mayoría de ellos son capaces de hacer más daño disparando pero hay uno que es más efectivo repartiendo "hostias").

Uno de los aspectos que más juego dan es que los disparos rebotan en las paredes y techos, y nuestra puntería es fundamental para acertar en los enemigos. Hay también armas que incluyen una mirilla láser, lo cual nos facilita esta labor, aunque sólo ciertos personajes pueden sostener cada tipo de arma. Y no sólo podemos equiparles con armas: también con otros objetos que potencian algunas de sus características (como por ejemplo la salud y el movimiento), e incluso sombreros para definir un poco el aspecto de cada uno a nuestro gusto. Encontrar estos botines a lo largo de los niveles es parte de la gracia.

Una aventura en el espacio
La aventura se divide en varias partes, y en cada una nos enfrentamos a una amenaza diferente. Empezamos luchando contra los "scrappers", unos locos y horrendos robots construidos con las partes de steambots muertos. A continuación debemos hacer frente a los monárquicos, robots avanzados que funcionan con carburantes diésel y que rinden pleitesía al gobierno cruel y autoritario de la reina. Y también hay cierta fuerza desconocida en el universo a la que debemos enfrentarnos... pero eso ya lo descubriréis vosotros. Cada uno de estos extensos segmentos (que están divididos en un buen número de niveles) finaliza con un épico y emocionante combate contra un jefe.

Estrategia ágil y divertidísima en un juego con una buena duración y muy rejugable. 

Nota: 9,5/10

33598566.review:
I had a lot of fun with this game, my kids have loved it (ages 4 and 5), and I'm eager to play it again.  

At the beginning of each mission you select the difficulty (1-5), pick your crew (typically 3), and go off for a randomly generated boarding action with a specific goal per mission.  What's cool is the difficulty doesn't change your stats, just the AI.  This makes it very easy for you play through on difficulty 5, pass the controller off to your kids and replay the mission right after at difficulty 1 and have different fun experience.  You gain experience and loot everytime you play a mission, so if ever want to level up some different characters or try earning some cool loot there's a lot of replay to this game.

Cons:
This game is short.  I beat it my first time in 15 hours, but that was me replaying a lot of levels so I could get all 7 characters up to level 10.  If you're an experienced gamer and only play the 3-4 characters you really like, you can easily beat this game is under 9 hours.  My kids have played for about 5 hours and haven't beated 5 missions.

There's an exploit where if you miss your shot, you can quit to main menu, load the game up again, and it starts you at the beginning of the round again.  Great if your kid decides to randomly jump in your lap, bad if you miss your shot and feel like cheating (done it for both reasons!) 

Near the end the prices of weapons gets a little silly.  Really this is a result of the earned currency not keeping up with outside prices.  For example in the first map you can usually buy new weapon after 1-2 missions, in the third map unless you sell loot, it can be 4-5 missions for the same result.  This is almost a moot point since you randomly gain 2-3 great pieces of gear per mission.  

Pros:
I beat the game and I want to play it some more.  

I picked it up really cheap (around $10), and I've gotten 20+ hours of entertainment from it (with more to come)

When you beat the game it unlocks New Game mode, where you can try it all again (no equipment) with your characters unlocked and at their current level.

There's 3 sectors, with 10+ locations per sector, great art style, and slightly different tricks to learn in each section.

I can play it with my kids, and have us all entertained.  

Conclusion:
Games great!  If you have an xbox controller give it a shot.  Dirt cheap, no crashes, and no gimmicky enemies, what's not to love?  9/10 easy (-1 for that exploit)

33448751.review:
Steamworld Heist is a turn based strategy game where you guide Captain Piper Faraday and her ragtag crew of steam powered robots through a series of robberies. Along the way you'll steal weapons, gallons (the game's currency) and swag (hats :D) and go from simply being a petty pirate trying to get by to getting involved in things of greater consequence. 

The story isn't anything to write home about. It is fairly par for the course and incredibly predictable. However, it's the rest of the game where Steamworld shines. 

The game has an incredibly interesting visual style to it that expands on Image and Form's previous game Steamworld Dig. The rusted disgusting junker ships through to the highly advanced ships all have distinctive small details that make them visually striking to look at despite simply being a backdrop to the actual game. The game's score is also quite good featuring tracks that feel thematically appropriate for each environment and scenario encountered throughout the game. 

The thing that really got me though was how Steamworld does combat. It's turn based, as previously mentioned, and allows for bullets to ricochet off of surfaces. This allows for a number of trick shots where you can hit an enemy beyond cover by bouncing a shot off of the ceiling or the wall behind them. However, only the sniper weapons will show you exactly where your shot is going. For some people not being able to see exactly where your bullet will go with the vast majority of the weapons will be an annoyance, but I found it really added to the game. It turned what would have been a calculated shot with a clear trajectory into an interesting mechanics whereby the player has to learn how each gun type fires and improve their own skill at aiming and firing the weapon to achieve the results they want. It adds an element of skill and learning to the game where it wouldn't have been otherwise and I found it really gratifying to pull of amazing trick, or clutch shots without what is ostensibly aim assist. To me this was the strongest element to Steamworld Heist and it turned what would have otherwise been a good looking and average strategy game into a fun and interesting experience.

33447605.review:
It's a solid game, there aren't any unfinished bits to it and the whole package is well put together.

That said...

[list]
[*]It's NOT open-world. Missions are unlocked sequentially... and you won't be doing any exploring in this Steambot universe.

[*]Bots' hands sway as they aim... this makes lining up that perfect angle frustrating and HEAVILY reliant on twitch-reflexes. Some may call that a plus, but I've lost way too many battles because the reticle moved a microsecond before I clicked.

[*]There's not really anything in the way of plot or character development. Sure, they have some dialogue now and again, but it's definitely not a focus of the game. Only a handful of NPCs can talk, and most of them either introduce a generic quest or repeat the same line indefinitely.

[*]As far as I can tell, the soundtrack is just a looping "Ambient Outer Space" theme.

[*]My biggest complaint: There is no indication of an enemy's movement range. That means there's no way to know if that wrench-wielding Crusher Bot will need 2 turns to reach you... or only 1.
[/list]

So... it's not a bad game, and it's certainly well made.

... but I wouldn't recommend it over similar games with better gameplay. The lack of talking NPCS, music and story make the world feel totally dead.

33415499.review:
A very well made turn based tactical game. A pros and cons list has been done to death in other people's reviews, so I'll leave some parting remarks now I've completed the main questline missions. 

 Firstly, playing with a controller is recommended by both the game and myself. I used KB+M throughout and got annoyed a few misclicks I made, however the controls are still very agreeable. 

 Secondly, collecting loot for random weapons and utilities is fun but perhaps suffers from a lack of variation or real true uniqueness. There's also the issue of just hoping to randomly get the next weapon tier for your favourite bot. If you're unlucky you may not use said bot/s for a few missions until you get them or will need to grind. 

 Lastly, my major annoyance with the game is the alarm timer aspect wherby after a certain number of turns the alertness of a ship goes up. This means that new enemies will spawn and turrets will turn on. For a few levels this is fine, where the alert will begin at a major fight or when you're going to extraction but when I heard the alarm blaring at the start of a map I found myself sighing in knowing what is to come. By the time I'd reached the end of the map I'd inevitably be at a fairly advanced alert level even if I had rushed since some enemies just aren't one hit kills. Sometimes it felt like playing whack-a-mole as a new enemy would pop out near me each turn as I was ready to go to the next room. So kill that one, get ready again and...oh wait, another enemy. It was frustrating, especially as the game demonstrated time after time it could introduce new ways to add difficulty or variation.

 Putting my rant aside, I did enjoy this game and I feel others will be satisfied at what the game has to offer. Fun mechanics (my last point aside), different classes, weapons, enemy types, hats, plenty of maps and great aesthetics.

SteamWorld Dig was an enjoyable game, but oh boy is Heist a great one! 

A creative approach of the 2D tactical genre, it reminded me of Worms and the new XCOM at the same time, which might sound weird at first, but it works like a charm. A big variety of abilities, items and enemies gives it real tactical depth, while the aiming and ricochet mechanism require some true dexterity from the player's side, often resulting in epic kills that makes you throw your fist up in the air!

The game's universe and its visual representation is another of its strong points: the funky steam robots and the cartoonish villains are fun as hell, not to mention the crew's personality (Seabrass rulz!). The soundtrack strengthens this mood as well, and I especially liked it when after a successful bossfight there came a song about my steam-powered heroes. Better than any of the rewards came in the chests afterwards, that's for sure. :)

Overall, this is one of the best turn-based games i have played in a long while. The intricate strategy and placement of your characters throughout each level could mean the difference between not being hit once and instantly dying. But it's not just strategy that plays a key role in this game, there's a little bit of skill involved in the actual shooting element of the game. You have to time the shots to perfection to get a headshot, not to mention the ricochet shots you have to pull off to hit your enemy when they are not in your direct line. It is definitely a unique style of game that i would recommend to anyone looking for a turn-based, strategy crossed with delicate aiming mechanics that require precision and accuracy to master. 
Pros
.Unique genere of game that involves easy to learn, hard to master aiming mechanics and fundamental strategy implications
.There is a story to this game with multiple cut-scenes that will have you hooked until the end
.Different levels and experiences each time you play through (different drops, you can focus on leveling up different characters etc.)
.The diversity of accessories, hats (for your characters to look cool =P) and weapons that you are able to equip to different characters
.Different passive and active abilities that each character has (once you level them up)
.The different strategies you have to employ once you make it to the next stage
.Graphics are pretty good and will run on most computers
.The outcome of each battle is different every time
Cons
.it's too short

33265640.review:
What a remarkably good little title this has turned out to be. So often these indy games that try to merge genres are interesting for the first few hours but they very quickly plateau and become repetitive. Not so with SteamWorld Heist! The genres of turn-based strategy, RPG and 2d platformer are seemlessly interwoven in such a fashion that you can't help but feel that the gameplay belongs entirely to itself, and isn't at all the child of other better games (as is so often the case).

The gameplay is simple - you travel from space hulk to space hulk with your band of steampunk robots deploying the team that you think is best suited for the task at hand. At first, your pool of bots to choose from is small but they quickly grow into a roster of characters with very different playstyles. As is standard with many turn-based games, you get 2 actions per turn per character. You can either stay still and have an action, move a short distance and have an action or move double distance and not get an action. Shooting demands you get good at eyeballing your aim in a manner that is similar to Worms, however there is a gentle yet slightly erratic bob which means even the most well-aimed shot can go awry. Conversely, pulling off a crazy shot that bounces off a number of walls before hitting a baddie in cover in the back of his head is air-punchingly pleasing.

As your team levels and their distinct skillsets grow, you begin to see how they synergise both with the lovely loot you pick up (of which there is plenty) and with each other. Also of note is how most of the maps are randomly created and all of them are individually skill-level customisable, meaning there is great replay value.

And it's awfully pretty to boot! This isn't a game that masks it's indy status with faux 8-bit graphics, it's actually very nice to look at with each SteamBot on your team looking characterful with their chosen loadouts clearly displayed. Of final note is how pleasing the on-ship banter is between the bots - each character feels distinct and I found I warmed to each and every one of them.

I'm giving this a solid 9/10. I was expecting a fun diversion, something cheeky and casual, and it easilly succeeds in being both of those things - however, on the harder settings it becomes a well-honed finely-balanced strategic challenge and a very welcome addition to the turn-based genre.

I normally don't like turn-based games all that much, but this one was addictive.  It's pretty simple and straight-forward, but still requires good skill and planning.  The art style is nice and the game has a reason for enemies to get stronger; too many games have enemies that get more powerful as you level up for no particular reason other than "this needs to happen for the sake of making the game more challenging".  I also appreciate some of the small jokes in the game, like how a lot of the treasure is modern-day household appliances, that the Steambots think are ancient powerful relics.

33214465.review:
Gameplay

Steamworld Heist is a 2D turn based shooter, that allows the user to aim their weapon each turn. This allows for headshots to induce critical attacks, use the environment, and to ricochet bullets. You are also suppose to recruit new team members with different abilities, and develop them to unlock their powers. In order to complete the game, it is almost essential to have four characters fully leveled up, and at least someone with a top tier weapon. 

Tactics

Success will be determined by how you strategically place your Steambots to allow for maximum defense and attack position. Levels are randomly generated, but rarely did I encounter a level that felt unfair. There are a variety of ways to find cover, whether it's a destructible barrel, sturdy plasma shield, or an indestructible steel support. Similar to XCOM, you can choose to move to a point where you can attack post movement, or sprint to a location where you won't be able to attack that turn. The environment also provides explosive objects that can be used for or against you. At times, you may be required to ricochet a bullet to an explosive barrel in order to avoid disaster, combining to mechanics into one action. These moments really make you feel like a badass, but at the same time the game expects you to be intelligent enough to recognize when you're suppose to do theses things.

 


On the standard difficulty, the enemy AI is rather forgiving. They are rarely in the open, but at the same time they are not the most accurate when firing back at you. The most devastating enemies are ones with forward facing indestructible shields that rush and melee you. About half of the levels have alarms, which require you to beat a level in a certain amount of turns. While alarms are active, more enemies appear and have to be disposed of. When the enemy outnumbers you significantly is when you'll run into trouble. At that point it doesn't really matter how smart they are when they outgun you. 

Story

The story starts off with self interests in mind, but then leads to you wanting to save the world, like any great story. Technically, you and your crew are pirates. There are other pirates in the system that are causing trouble, and you don't want the Royal Fleet coming in and disturbing your pillages, so you try to end it so things calm down. From there it progresses and you'll end up facing three different enemy races each with distinct abilities and personalities. The art style in combination with the script brings this game to life and they work well together. As simple as the story is, it is fulfilling and feels original. 

 

 


Classes

The following classes are available during gameplay:

Sniper - Weapons have laser sight which allows for great accuracy, and for seeing the trajectory of a bullet when it ricochets, allowing for complex shots to be taken. However, snipers can't shoot if they move during a turn (unless the weapon they are wielding allows for that). 

Assault - Weapons consist of sub machine guns and shotguns. Assault class can be used in close up or mid range situations. Depending on the weapon wielded, it will usually be inaccurate and high in damage, or moderatly accurate with moderate damage. Assault classes usually have average health as well. 

Vanguard - This is the close range class that can wield shotguns or submachine guns. Usually posesss abilities that regenerate health or have high defense to support their close range role. Equipping with a shotgun is recommended. 

Heavy - Contain explosive type weapons or mini guns. This class isn't unlocked until the middle of the game, but I found it to be very essential. Like a sniper, sometimes can't fire a weapon after they've moved. The heavy will deal the most damage of any class, but may have low health and defense. I would not have beaten the game without this class.

 

Art

The 2D art is very good and original. There aren't too many animations, but the ones that are executed are done very well without any noticeable flaws. I particularly liked when enemies were killed they would explode into a bunch of parts that would fall on the floor, because they are steambots. It was usually done in slow motion as well, so you would be rewarded visually each time you killed an enemy. The bullet impact would also be in slow motion, allowing for you to register the location of your bullet and if you got a critical hit which contributed to the kill. The backgrounds of the galaxies, interior of the ships, and weapons all have details about them that show a real effort was made to make each item in the game be apart of the world. 

 


Summary

I had more fun playing this than I did XCOM: Enemy Unknown. The control I had hitting enemies, while also using strategy makes it superior in my opinion, despite the game not being in 3D. I spent about 15 hours playing this, but each moment I was progressing and being pushed to purchase new weapons and armor. The story was advancing in each moment as well, at no point did I feel like I was wasting my time. The final boss is extremely hard, but I was able to win in two tries, with a mix of luck and skill. This game is a must play, and you'll likely be able to get it on sale.

33175413.review:
For a long while, I totally tossed this game aside as being not worth attention. It has that sort of "Mm, why, good show, sir! You win 3 internets, and you are a gentleman and a scholar!" type of humor/presentation which feels completely high-school-ish to me. However, remembering that Cool Ghosts and Extra Credits both recommended it, and seeing as it was on sale for a mere 5 bucks during the summer, I decided to give it a try anyway.

13 hours later, I can comfortably say that this game is well worth checking out. That childish humor only shows up in a few places, standing in odd contrast to writing which is otherwise surprisingly solid. The game doesn't take itself too seriously, but still sets up a solid story that's easy to follow. Many of the crew members are quite likeable (I'll exclude Sally), and the cast you meet along the way are archetypical but not dull.

Mechanically, this game is brilliant. The shooting feels consistent, and the different types of guns really set themselves apart. Leveling up feels good, getting new equipment feels good, but neither out does the other. Movement can be a touch slow and floaty, but being able to tab between characters during movement is a nice touch.

Music and graphics were, for me, nothing to write home about, but the sound design is generally solid and I almost never found any inconsistencies between what I saw on the screen and what was actually happening. The hats are neat, though some like the unicorn and goat add an unwelcome splash of lolsorandom humor.

Overall, definitely recommended, and I'll be looking out for more from this crew.

33089754.review:
I really expected to like this game, based on the art style, turn-based tactics, having enjoyed SteamWorld Dig.  Sadly, the game is overly focused on grinding levels, due to the bizarre loss mechanic.

Completing missions normally gives you water (cash) and experience for the bots that participated.  If a bot is "killed" (perhaps "junked" would be more accurate) in a mission, then they gain no experience.  If you lose or abort a mission, you lose half of your total water.  This leads to annoying situations where a bot gets killed, but you must press on with the mission to avoid the water hit... then still have to replay the mission to get experience for the bot that died, plus a full star rating for the level.  Want to save time and just abort so you can replay immediately?  Well then, say goodbye to half your water for wanting to save yourself some grind!  All of which could've been avoided with the simple option to restart a mission at any time (losing any loot and experience picked up on that level only), or with a turn rewind option to even out the random ricochets that cause unintended bot losses.

Far too frustrating to play because of this loss mechanic, but otherwise a good game.  If you don't mind wasting your time grinding, consider this review a positive, but otherwise I'd suggest looking at alternatives like Invisible Inc., XCOM, or Shadowrun.

32936110.review:
If you don't like being rushed, this game is not for you. I chose to play Steamworld Dig (not Heist) at the time instead of Spelunky because I like to take my time in video games. 

In this game however, "Countdown" mechanic forces you to hurry up by sending waves of enemies until you complete a level. This is not my main problem. Real buzz killer is that these enemies are infinite in numbers. On top of that, after a number of turns their spawns become doubled and any level with countdown just becomes impossible to finish without casualties. Unfortunately, in every two levels, there is a countdown. 

So, if you linger, you lose. Sometimes money, sometimes completion stars, sometimes the level. Exact opposite of my game taste. I could be fine with the game, if the number of enemies were somehow standardized. In this case, I think it is a cheap attempt at making the game more challenging. This game didn't deserve such shoddiness. I wish there was an option to disable it. Other than that, it is really a great game, I would play the heck out of it, but I can't recommend because I am extremely dissatisfied. A tasty soup with a fly on it. 

I hope you don't desecrate Steamworld Dig 2 with similar design choices.

[h1]SteamWorld Heist 是款橫向的戰棋RPG，戰鬥樂趣高，沒太多經營與養成元素。[/h1] 

[b]蒸氣世界是一個充滿機器人的世界，水是這個世界最重要的資源，多數的機器人是靠水生活的蒸氣型機器人；但並非所有機器人都是如此，女王旗下的機器人靠柴油為生，因此比傳統的蒸氣機器人更為強大，四處霸佔水資源來控制這些蒸氣機器人。而玩家將扮演蒸氣機器人中的俠義走私團 - 派珀小隊，為了保護其他的蒸氣機器人，派珀船長將與她的船員們四處對抗女王的機器人大軍！[/b]

[b]遊戲分為三個章節，每個章節由數個關卡組成，跟手遊常見的副本設計相似[/b]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=936719844 

[h1]優點：[/h1]

[olist]
    [*]絕佳的遊戲性，可以滿足戰棋遊戲愛好者
       橫向的戰棋遊戲不常見，遊戲內子彈反彈的設計很有意思
    [*]很棒的遊戲配樂，樂團的歌曲很有特色
    [*]各種稀奇古怪的帽子可以收藏
[/olist]

[b]冒險的過程中，可以招募新的船員，每個角色都有不同的職業定位[/b]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=940408252

[h1]缺點：[/h1]

[olist]
    [*]任務與關卡數量少了點，角色還沒練滿就破關了 XD
    [*]帽子出現的機率太隨機了，要完成一些特殊帽子組合成就，會很吃運氣
[/olist]

遊戲其實沒什麼缺點，是一款很出色經典獨立遊戲

[b]所有角色都可以更換不同的帽子，很多都很逗趣，但要收集齊全蠻難的～[/b]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=942510649


[h1]結論：很適合喜歡策略、戰棋的用戶，如果想玩點輕鬆的戰棋小品，[strike]而不是某個99% Miss的大作[/strike]，這款很適合你 XD[/h1]

推薦給下列玩家：

1. 喜歡戰棋、策略
2. 喜歡XCOM，但又想玩的輕鬆點
3. 想接觸新鮮的遊戲玩法

遊戲最後結局有埋伏筆，很期待二代的推出！

[b]推薦程度：★★★★★[/b]

32895948.review:
The mechanics of this game are an unique combination, combining the tactical turn-based style of X-com, turning it into a 2-D version, and letting the player make every shot, allowing the player to take more control than in the previously mentioned X-com games.

The animations are beautiful. The weapons are each unique and can have many different types of configurations. The sub-slots are genius and can make for a lot of fun combinations. From increasing a character's speed and jump height to be able to easily flank an enemy, to having an extra sidearm for just that little bit of extra damage. The hats are also a nice addition and are fun to collect.

All in all, the game has some unique mechanics, that, and the astonishing animations make this game an absolute steal for this price.

32885621.review:
Ever play a SteamWorld game? Fix that. Heist or Dig. Either one is fine. You'll get the other soon afterwards anyways.

Impeccably made games. Mechanics are simple, but they give more depth than you'd expect. They have fantastic skill managing the player's ability to progress, and the art and sound design is perfect and distinct.

The stories give no pressure, and easy goals to understand. You're here and there is only one way to go. You don't progress because of the story tells you to; you progress because it feels good to do so. The stories are enough to guide you, but you play for the constant mild puzzles that keep you engaged and not stressed. There is always progression, you never lose progress. Sort of like a Kirby game with steampunk robots for how it feels to play. Easy to pick up for a few minutes when ever you need a break from something else.

Oh, and this game gives you the ability to shoot off and pick up enemy hats to wear yourself. Gotta be careful though, as they can shoot off yours too.

32792863.review:
[b]TL;DR at the end of the review[/b]

You don't like shooters because you need more freakin' time to think before making your move?

You don't like turn-based tactics because they usually have that horrible habit to rely too heavily on luck? 
[spoiler]Hey, hello X-COM[/spoiler]

Whatever the case, by playing SteamWorld Heist there's a less-slim-than-you-think chance you will come to like both genres. [spoiler]Or maybe not, since they are too different[/spoiler] 
Even if you won't, you will definitely love this game, since it does with the utmost elegance something so stupid it is actually brilliant: merging shooter mechanics with turn-based, with an RPG twist. 
I know, it just sounds like I'm throwing around random bull**** in order to show the poor reader how cool a gamer I am, 
but while such option feels very [spoiler]not[/spoiler] appealing, I actually mean what I'm saying.

In SteamWorld Heist you play as a team of way-too-edgy rogue robots - CowBots, I mean - who fight for control of their own territory and end up finding themselves involved in a dark case of NecRobotmancy, as I like to call it. I will say nothing more about the story [spoiler]because I have to finish it yet, but it doesn't matter because my review is still great,
 right? ...Right?[/spoiler], but it definitely does its job while being nothing over the top, thanks to its all-encompassing irony in particular.

What really shines in this game is the gameplay: [spoiler]quite obvious, since a game not shining for its gameplay is probably a book or a film[/spoiler] every mission requires you to delve with 2-3 of your CowBots in procedurally generated - which isn't as in "completely random" but more as in "the general layout is fixed, what is inside changes a bit every time" - enemy spaceships filled with enemies and boons and achieve one or more objectives; each member of the quite diverse cast at your disposal will be able to bring on missions two utility items and a very welcome firearm to defend themselves/cull their enemies, depending on how you like to see it [spoiler]the result is the same, dead RoBodies everywhere[/spoiler]. Each game turn, each character in sight will be able to make its move, starting with your CowBots. You will be able to move them a short distance and shoot, or you will be able to sprint a longer distance and rest afterwards, or you will be able to stand still, or everything in between. 
The shooting part is not just a click-the-shoot-button-and-watch-your-character-miss-randomly-and-die-horribly, it actually requires you, the player, to aim with your mouse and shoot in the direction you decide to, which is what makes this game actually genius. The player is not just a god-like figure (not so god-like since you actually exist but whatever) looking at the characters and directing their actions from above, he also gets to take the role of every single character and fine-tune his actions! What's not to like about that? Plus, this allows you to exploit walls and covers to have your bullets ricochet on that damn monster bearing a shield bigger than himself [spoiler]good luck with getting good ricochets without a sniper weapon though[/spoiler].

Concerning the "artistic" aspects of the game, this is all about personal tastes, but I really appreciate the cartoonish, colourful graphics a lot. The background music is great too, even though there're way too many tracks with vocals, in my humbly humble opinion. This being said, the few instrumental tracks are nothing less than great and actually manage to build up a quite immersive ambience.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
This game has the originality, has the atmosphere, has the gameplay and - most important - has the fun. I wouldn't give it a 10/10 [spoiler]just because I'm a freakin' bast***[/spoiler], but it definitely deserves a noice 9. Try it whenever you can, it would be worth it even at full price. Must have if it is on sale.

32777785.review:
Thumbs up for SteamWorld Heist with it's simple and engaging game mechanics.

A turn based tactical with it's own flavor. You recruit more team members (robots; by the way, you lead a team of robots), you participate in fights and collect "swag".  Only the surviving bots receive experience. And you MUST have hats for your robots. All the goodies/swag that you collect - besides the much needed weapons and upgrades - SHALL be used to buy hats. Or even better, shoot them from the heads of your enemies. That shot will not damage the enemy, but you will get one hat and that is all that matters in the end, after winning the fight so the hat will be yours, of course. Don't forget to pick it up, don't leave it in the dust.
Another important hint, you definitely need all the storage space that you can buy. This comes before the bare necessity of having an imposing hat collection.
So: 1) better guns (100% you will obtain those from fights) 2) storage space 3) HATS. Many-many hats in many forms.
Grinding: it depends. You need more swag? Replay the fights and don't loose the fights. You need better firepower, better guns? If you are not in the third episode, it does not matter too much unless you are playing on elite difficulty. But let's say that you need more firepower now. Well, some grinding and a little bit of luck is required.

Hopefully you will find your hat, you will be well hatted, and enjoy the experience, BLUB!

I played on veteran difficulty, I restarted a few times but in the end I got the rhythm and I finished/won the game. On elite difficulty it looks like grinding is a necessity (the better firepower is an absolute necessity from the start) and some dialogues seemed a bit changed.

Overall I am very satisfied with the experience. A nice little game that is professionally well done and your point and shoot skills matter. And God forbid, do not ever go into a fight without a hat! Your best achievement evah is to shoot 3 hats off from your enemies, with only one bullet. Been there, done that, achievement obtained.

The characters are fun and likeable, and the plot is campy and cliche in a very fun way. Gameplay is immensely satisfying, especially when you pull off a crazy ricochet with no aiming. Would happily recommend this game to anyone looking for a solid 8+ hours of high quality entertainment

SteamWorldDigといっしょにセールで購入。
スチームパンクというジャンルがあることをこれで知った。
Digのほうを先にプレイして、あちらは珍しくクリアまで行った。
こっちのほうが自分的には期待していたのだけど、
15時間くらいプレイしてからちょっと飽きが出てきた。
きらいなわけじゃないから、またプレイすることにはなるんだろうけど……。
いちばんの問題点は……難易度を選べるということだろう。
５段階だったか、６段階だったかの難易度があるのだが、
いつでも難易度を変更してプレイをやり直すことができる。
そのために、
・緊張感がなくなってしまう。
・低い難易度でクリアしていると常に不満がつきまとう。

クエストでキャラが壊されても死んでいなくなるのではなく、
何事もなく復活してしまう（その戦いの経験値はもらえない）。
ということなんかもあいまって、
さらに緊張感がなくなる。

ゲームそのものは自分の好みなだけに、非常に残念な仕様だ。
そこが気にならないのなら、買い。

32735324.review:
The Good & Bad review

General Description of the game:
> Battles are turn based, its like 2D version of XCOM
> Loot based, got different weapons such as sniper, shotgun, etc.
> Requires basic level of aiming
> Player can shot down enemies' hat and collect it
> Can shot robots into pieces ;)
> Teamate does not have perm death

The Good
+ No time limit (You can grind level if you cannot pass through). This allows me to play without having the pressure to rush to fight the boss
+ Unlike XCOM, you can control the aim of the gun. Added a layer of challenges to player


The Bad
- Tiny problem but every time when I leave the game inside my own ship, the game won't save. If I did something like inventory management work before I leave the game, I may need to do that again when I start the game next time. (Developer Patrick Baitman has replied a workaround for this situation: "A workaround is to dock with a bar afterwards, which makes it save.")
- The game may get repeatitive
- Difficulty does not improve the AI, they only get better damage and health instead of becoming smarter

Verdict
- Its satisifying to see your plan executed perfectly and killed every enemies
- This is like a casual version of XCOM
- Hat system is fun

I got this in a Humble Bundle, and decided to play it simply to avoid the idea of having something but not appreciating it.

At about one-third of the way through the game I realised how much fun I was having, which carried through to the very end. I'm tempted to do the New Game Plus on Elite difficulty, even. 

Put simply: it's 2D XCOM with a story and set of characters that won't win awards for writing but don't need to, simply because it's all so charming and such a good time both on and off the battlefield. Clearly crafted by some wizened people to be worth every penny of it's price tag.

32649028.review:
Занятная, надо сказать, вещица. Я так понимаю, она является продолжением (или скорее спин-оффом) платформера SteamWorld Dig - сюжет и персонажи (за исключением одного, появляющегося ближе к концу игры...) никак не связаны, но события разворачиваются в том же мире. А мир этот представляет собой расколотую на куски Землю, населенную роботами на паровом и дизельном ходу. Перед нами еще один очаровательный образчик космического вестерна, в духе Firefly и Borderlands. Осколки планеты и космос вокруг них представляет собой этакий фронтир, с колонистами и ковботами, фермерами и шахтерами, космическим королевским флотом метрополии, ну а также пиратами и контрабандистами разной степени отмороженности, разумеется. Собственно, главные герои и являются космическими ковботами-пиратами-паророботами, пытающимися выдворить наиболее аморальных конкурентов и роялистов со своей территории. А с роботами, как известно, все становится лучше. И с пиратами. И с ковбоями.

В плане игрового процесса сей образчик шпиллева сравнивается народом с чем-то средним между Worms и X-COM - это двухмерная пошаговая тактическая стратегия, во многом действительно напоминающая Червячков по принципам боевки, но имеющая счетчик движения и действий за ход, как в других икскомоподобных творениях. Есть здесь и укрытия, которые играют интересную роль, поскольку здесь нет такой вещи, как шанс попадания - целится игрок в двухмерной плоскости самостоятельно, и просто должен учитывать поведение того или иного оружия в своих руках, дабы либо снести укрытие, либо попасть по выпирающей из него части вражеской тушки. Дробь, к примеру, летит хаотично и недалеко, тем самым объясняя, почему дробовики хороши лишь на ближних дистанциях. А, как вариант, револьверы стреляют в точности именно туда, куда их нацелишь и даже способны на рикошет. Отдельные интерес вызывает реализация снайперского оружия, благодаря которому система рикошета стала своеобразной фишкой здешней боевки. Дело в том, что снайперское оружие не просто бьет очень далеко и много рикошетит, но еще и позволяет видеть траекторию полета пули перед выстрелом - с учетом этого самого рикошета. У наших бойцов, кстати, рука немного покачивается в процессе прицеливания (даром, что роботы), так что для идеальной траектории выстрела надо еще поймать момент. Но в результате можно почувствовать себя этаким Дэдшотом, выпустив пулю в ближайший к себе угол и пронаблюдав, как она, отскочив от стен, пола и потолка где-то с десяток раз, влетит в затылок врага, находящегося на противоположном конце комнаты. Этой механике уделено немало внимания, есть даже типы противников, для которых это чуть ли не единственный способ устранения. Еще в плане геймплея можно отметить уже обязательную в наше время прокачку персонажей, со спецнавыками, присущими разным классам, случайно генерирующиеся карты каждого из уровней и относительно богатый по разнообразным свойствам арсенал.

А еще здесь имеются шляпы. Во всех описания игры и обзорах постоянно упоминаются шляпы и по-началу я не совсем понимал, что в них такого. Но да, как в каком-нибудь Team Fortress 2 здесь это - основной способ косметической кастомизации персонажей. Вот только здесь шляпы... можно сбивать с врага выстрелом! И поднимать их во время или после перестрелки, чтобы надеть самому!!! И конечно вашим героям тоже может снести с головы шляпу вражеской пулей, что они непременно подметят, выдав какое-нибудь ругательство в адрес стрелявшего.

Вообще, конечно, игра всячески старается выдерживать соответствующий стиль. Робо-обитетели здешнего фронтира выглядят очень колоритно и разнообразно, вид кораблей тоже по-своему впечатляет, ну и рисовка демонстрирует определенную любовь к деталям. Также это проявляется в таких моментах как, например, стыковка нашего судна к другим кораблям и станциям - мы реально видим, как две карты объединяются в одну, и именно так происходит попадание на миссии и в мирные зоны, вроде баров и магазинов. Так или иначе, рисовка здесь явно запоминающаяся. Лично я испытываю некоторую слабость к подобной стилистике, потому именно этим меня SteamWorld Heist первоначально и привлекла. Плюс, здесь имеются коротенькие, но приятные диалоги между членами команды в перерывах между миссиями. А описание реликвий старой Земли, периодически попадающихся в качестве лута на продажу, всегда восхитительно. Музыкальный стиль выдержан, конечно же, также соответствующий. Однако отдельно в плане музыки стоит выделить момент, который порадует поклонников Steam Powerd Giraffe - дело в том, что указанная группа не просто фигурирует в саундтреке, они... выступает в здешних барах. И им будет что спеть про ваши приключения, включая победы над боссами.

Единственное, что мне по части эстетики не понравилось, так это "язык", на котором общаются местные обитатели: то, что они выдают свой набор звуков из урчаний и шипений само-по-себе совсем даже не плохо, но как результат некоторые из персонажей наделены очень уж режущими слух голосами. И если уж говорить о недостатках, - теперь уже в плане геймплея, - кому-то может прийтись не по-нраву, что здесь на большинстве уровней сложности нельзя просто взять и рестартнуть миссию, хотя в нынешнее время эта функция встречается чуть ли не везде - есть тут такой элемент хардкора, что за отмену миссии, пошедшей наперекосяк, с нас снимут солидный штраф в местной валюте (галлонах воды - мы же роботы на паровом ходу). К счастью, совсем запороть прохождение этот штраф не способен, так как любые миссии можно перепроходить для получения дополнительного лута и галлонов (правда, основная награда за миссию выдается лишь один раз - зато всю стороннюю рандомную добычу можно собирать снова и снова).

Очень неплохая двухмерная пошаговая стратегия, стильная, и, в добавок, с некоторыми необычными особенностями механики.

32625526.review:
I did begin to enjoy the game more towards the end of it, however, I don’t think I can fully recommend the experience. 
 
Gameplay feels slow, and that feels like a weird thing to say about a strategy game. The tedium of watching enemies and characters move around and climb ladders without a fast forward button wore me out after a while. This also made battles draw on forever, especially if it was an area you were re-attempting for grinding. 
 
Early on in the game I made the mistake of starting on a higher difficulty. Tougher levels on this difficulty felt near impossible without only putting my best foot forward, leaving me to abandon lower leveled teammates who never got any xp for dying near the end. I surprisingly found myself grinding for a few levels between boss fights, a frustrating task given that battles move slow and that dead teammates and failed missions give you no xp.
 
Strategy in the game seems straightforward, and this becomes even more apparent on easier difficulties. It mostly feels like there’s only one viable response for most scenarios. Put in the same circumstance in a level, I would probably expect myself to always react the same way. However, on harder difficulties, if you have to improvise, you’ll probably lose a teammate. Once you get an ‘A -team’ together, there’s no point in attempting to train other teammates and without their later abilities, a lot of teammates feel identical.
 
After a few disheartening failures on the first boss, and being in no mood to replay old levels, I turned the difficulty down and then, before the 2nd boss, had to turn the difficulty down once more. From this point, I was just interested in getting the game off my list and, with the help of a completionist drive, blazed to the end of the game on casual mode.
 
The final area is not only the coolest one but contains the best weapons and, by this point, your A-team should have a whole onslaught of tools and abilities unlocked that makes gameplay feel more varied from battle to battle.
 
 
On the brighter side of things, I suppose I ended up enjoying Steamworld Heist by the end of the game. The general view of this game seems to be pretty positive and it does have a decent soundtrack plus the artstyle/world is charming. 
 
Perhaps if I had played it on casual mode from the beginning I would’ve been able to recommend it, but simply based off of my experience, I wouldn’t suggest it to a friend. 
 
 
 
 
Outline:
Feels like a waste of time
Slow AF movement
Deaths have no XP - failing late into a boss battle means you’ve wasted 10 minutes and have to go back and grid
If you play on higher difficulties - not really about skill, more about weapons and trying 
Struggled with anything beyond regular mode
I did end up playing to the end:
Switched off Experienced (assume this meant I’ve played games before) and a breezed through the last world
Dialog is pointless, skipped all of it

32612762.review:
Yea this game is fantastic...

Steamworld Heist is a turn-based, tactical action game with heavy influence from games like XCOM. I'd even go as far as to say that this game plays like XCOM if it played on a 2D plane. It is extremely well made and the mechanics all completment themselves nicely.

So the game's main quirk is manually aiming your unit's weapons. This wouldn't be such a huge thing if your bullets didn't richochet like fucking rubber bullets. Due to this you can pull of some crazy ass trick shots, those of which saved may ass many times. Your first time through you'll probably find yourself in quite a few sticky situations on the battlefield, so being able to pull of these trickshots will be crucial to your crew survivng the scuffle. 

All in all it's a very rewarding game; you're almost always sorting through new loot and gaining more water, which acts as the game's currency and the combat can be very satisfying if you set up your shots correctly. 

I would reccommend this game at full price WITH the "The Outsider" DLC, as it adds a few extra missions, a party member, and new items. Image & Form are great devs and they deserve the money.

32598336.review:
SteamWorld Heist is fun turn-based, steampunk, robot, space game whit RPG elements.

Pros:
-Theme
-Intresting world
-"One more round"
-Skills
-Music
-Hats

Cons:
-Linear
-Skills (you cannot chose they)
-No really customisation options (except hats)

You are steambot (robot) that commands spaceship. You get new grew, weapons, skills and equipments over time.

Game feels like Worms game whit bit of X-Com on it. You have a team that can move on shooting position or sprint. Different characters have some unique skills that you will get when you level up, but basic weapons are already there.

Game is linear and you cannot chose different paths, but it have been done well. Most missions are random generated so it's not so boring to repeat mission.

Music is good but not sure were there more that one song. It did not get boring.

Graphics work well. It's 2D and reminds bit of Awesomenaust. (Same goes whit music)

Note: I did get this game from Humble Bundle montly.

This game is fun and worthwile of time if turnbased games are for you. Theme is fun game can take some time whit "one more round"

32471886.review:
Dicho simplemente, Steamworld Heist es un RPG táctico por turnos con puntería manual. Una combinación que en principio suena extraña, pero que a mi gusto es justo lo que el género necesita. 

Los SRPG, como cualquier juego de estrategia, se basa en la anticipación y la posición. Tus unidades tienen habilidades y debilidades muy claras y el uso óptimo no es el mismo para todos (Intenta usar un francotirador para melee si hay dudas). Eso sí, una vez dominado el sistema puede volverse un juego de estadísticas, o en el peor de los casos, un ajedrez digital. Por supuesto, este género tiene su público y entiendo perfectamente porqué, pero el componente de habilidad una vez pasada la curva de aprendizaje es practicamente inexistente. 

Aquí es dónde entra Steamworld Heist. Sí, los personajes tienen roles muy definidos. Sí, el juego se basa en estadísticas, habilidades e ítems que potencian ambas. Pero la puntería está en tus manos, y la única diferencia entre que tu pistola de nivel 9 consiga un headshot con una trayectoria cuasi-imposible o dispare inofensivamente a 2 metros del enemigo está solo en tu habilidad. Este es el rasgo central del juego, y el resto del mismo esta construido para complementarlo perfectamente.

El apartado estético es genial. Los gráficos y la música están consagrados a crear ese ambiente Western-Steampunk que lo impregna todo y no se toma a sí mismo en serio. Y la verdad es que, sin lucirse demasiado, hacen muy bien ese trabajo. Es innegable que el juego tiene personalidad.

Una dificultad modulable (Con recompensas y penalizaciones), la posiblidad de completar al 100% misiones antiguas  y un NG+ con todos los personajes desde el principio otorgan mucha rejugabilidad a un videojuego cuya mecánica ya es divertida de por sí. También hay un DLC con más misiones  rondando por ahí, por si quedan ganas.

Las convenciones de los SRPG siempre han sido muy rígidas; es un género que se originó en Japón siempre ha estado dominado por un puñado de franquicias que no se atreven a  innovar por miedo al fracaso. Es por esto que ver a un equipo indie europeo dar este giro de tuerca al género, y lo que es mejor, hacerlo tan bien, trae gozo y esperanza a mi corazoncito.

Mu güeno. Tú comprar.

32411333.review:
[h1]総評[/h1]
・爽快感のあるライトな2Dストラテジー。
・XCOMの戦闘部分だけ抜き取って色々とカジュアルにしてトレハン要素を足してストレス要因を全部オミットしたようなゲーム。
・とても面白い。操作していて楽しい。

[h1]GOOD[/h1]
・テンポの良さ。ゲームプレイは快適そのもの。起動時のロードすらほとんどない。
・BGM良し、キャラクター良し。どう見てもジャンク寄せ集め系の可愛いロボットたちを操り、宇宙を荒らしまくろう。
・絶妙な難易度設定。難易度ベテラン（5段階中の4）初見プレイで「（ボス等に少し苦労しつつも）サクっと」攻略できた。ある程度の達成感を味わえ、かつ爽快にプレイができる、本当にちょうどいい難易度だった。
・難易度を上げることで獲得経験値などにボーナスがつくため、チャレンジ精神を刺激してくれる。
・難易度はミッションごとに変更できるので、ライトゲーマーも安心。
・レベル制でありキャラクターが成長する（キャラ固有のスキルを覚える）のが楽しい。レベルが割と上がりやすいのもGOOD.
・エイムやスキルの使い方など、慣れてくると戦い方が分かってきてこれまた面白い。難しいエイムを狙い通りに撃てたときは脳汁もの。

[h1]BAD[/h1]
・難易度は弄れるものの、基本的にはライト向けと言えるデザインのため、ガチ勢には向いてないかも。
・操作可能なキャラクターは多いが、一度に連れていける人数がごく少数に限られるのがちょっと残念。
・トレハン要素が少ない。ミッションごとにばら撒かれているお金か武器を拾っているだけで、あまり「お宝感」が無い。

[h1]OTHER[/h1]
・日本語はない。けどストーリーは割とどうでもいいから全部飛ばした。全く問題なし。英語はアビリティの説明とミッションの目的だけ読み取れればOK。
・基本的な戦術はXCOM同様「敵にターンを渡さない」「ダメージを受けない」なので、体力の高い敵を一撃で殺せるキャラクターが必須。というわけで「速い・強い・脆い」という特性のPayrollくんが優秀すぎてレギュラーから外せない。隣接ユニットの攻撃力を上げるパッシブスキルを覚えるキャプテンPiperさんもほぼ必須と言えるレベル。ただし低難易度なら自由が利くかと。
・なに？インベントリが少なくてアイテムを売らなきゃいけない？今すぐショップで「箱」を買え！銃なんか買わなくていい！まず箱を買い占めるんだ！


以上。
いいゲームでした。おすすめ！

32401152.review:
TLDR: It's simplistic and meant for younger audiences.  Finer pallettes will not be satisfied with this one.

First off, it's not bad. It's probably great for a younger or newer gamer, and that's kinda their target audience, so I have to admit I might be being harsh in my review.  But this is from a 30 yr. old avid gamer, so take my opinion with salt.

It's a solid game for a little while and does many things well. But since I played it for what, three days was it? and now I never care to anymore, I'm not reccommending it.

Story is pretty simplistic, but I've seen worse.  Think NES era story quality. Dialogue is is mediocre, and leaves you wanting more from characters.  A good contrast would be FF7 where I wanted to talk to every character I could just to see what would happen from doing so.  Nothing happens from talking except little tid-bits of lore, which isn't really worth the "effort" of waiting for that text to populate the screen. TLDR: talking to people is boring in this game.

No real penalties from losing other than cash, so there's never much tension to win.  Aside from that it's one of the easiest games I've played (playing on default difficulty).

Tactics are weird, and probably what throws me the most about this game.  It's not very tactical.  If you build out your loadout well there's almost nothing you can't handle.  Bouncing bullets mean that almost nobody is safe from a sharpshooter's ricochet, leaving cover as a nice to have rather than need.  You can shoot enemies behind cover 80% of the time, so they basically just sabotage themselves by thinking themselves safe.  They'll shoot at you fruitlessly from behind cover all day, leaving you to either run up and blow off their heads, return fire from your safe vantage, or simply avoid them.

There's not a level of challanging reward I'd go for.

Characters are actually designed quite well, aside from their dialogue.  visuals and classes have unique and pertinent bonuses that really contribute to the experience.

32374513.review:
[b]You might like if:[/b] You enjoy both 2D Worms and XCOM.

"Quick! He's got a gun! Shoot him"
"But I like his hat"
"Shoot him in the face!"
"But I want his hat..."

An utterly stellar title! Whilst the concept of steampunk robot cowboy space pirates might sound... bizarre. It's a brilliantly imagined and executed concept - boasting cracking graphics, charming humour, great music and, most importantly, really cool gameplay.

The crux is that it's like a 2D XCOM in terms of cover and movement, with the aiming and shooting of Worms. The shooting, in particular, is what makes this game. Instead of dice rolls... it's down to your skill with the not-so-steady hands of your crew. The ability to ricochet bullets makes this particularly fun, leading to some beautiful punch-the-sky trick-shots and eye-wateringly bad misses (my worst being a grenade that bounced over the foe... and back to my feet). A very refreshing and inspired addition indeed. The difficulty is well paced and picks up nicely as you go along, with some really challenging enemies and timed missions popping up. The levels are also enjoyably varied and the randomly generated maps are a really nice touch to keep things fresh.

The characters are also great. Really likeable and brilliantly designed with their unique ranges of abilities and weapons. They each bring a very distinct playstyle to the table, further enriching the game's variety.

The game is also full of hats. You can shoot them off your foes and collect them. They do nothing. They're pointless... yet are somehow strangely addictive. It makes for a silly sub-game, especially where rare ones pop up from time to time. I don't care if that Scrapper has an auto gun and a bad attitude - he has a pink baseball cap and I want it!

My one and only gripe is that the weapon balance feels a bit poor. Most sniper and assault weapons (shotguns / semi-autos) feel far too situational to be reliable, especially where they are barely stronger than most pistols / explosives but come with harsh penalties (cannot move and shoot, short range, scatters...)

But that's it. Everything else ticked all the boxes for me as a champion indie title. Absolutely fantastic and I cannot recommend it enough. And, just as the intro says... Best enjoyed with a controller and your favourite hat. The outsider DLC is also well-worth getting!

¿Me lo compro o no?

Si te gustan los juegos largos... no te lo compres.
Si no te importa la duración puedes leer la siguiente parrafada.

SteamWorld Heist es un juego de estrategia por turnos en el que lideramos un grupo de robots para cumplir misiones que nos permiten subir de nivel y mejorar equipamiento.

El parecido con XCOM es mínimo. Combate por turnos, apuntar y disparar, ganar experiencia, mejorar equipamiento y habilidades.

La parte divertida son las misiones que tienen la siguiente mecánica:

1-Elegimos en un mapa la misión de destino.
2-Seleccionamos los compañeros que llevaremos y su equipamiento
3-Cumplimos los objetivos de la misión 
4-Recibimos recompensas y experiencia
5-A otra misión mas dificil, más larga y con mejorer armas.


Es un juego muy casual, muy cómodo de jugar con mando, yo lo he probado con Steam Controller sin ningún problema. Hay que decir que la jugabilidad es muy sencilla y que está en distintas plataformas y consolas por lo que la compatibilidad con mando es buena.

La banda sonora y los diálogos son entretenidos y lo convierten en un juego que apetece echarte unas partidas de vez en cuando.
En cuanto a su duración, puesto que es un juego casual, no espereis más de 15 0 20 horas como mucho.

32356493.review:
I love every aspect of this game. The gameplay, most importantly, is top-notch. It's easy to learn and hard to master, and there's a ton of tactical choices that give it depth. I can't say much more about that; if you are a fan of classic turn based shooting games like Scorched Earth, Tank Wars or Worms, this is definitely going to be up your alley.

The animation is quirky and the graphics are colorful, which helps to make the unique setting feel upbeat and fun despite it being basically a post apocalyptic dystopia, which could've very easily been presented as bleak and desperate. This helps the game feel lighthearted and enjoyable even when you're getting your rusty metal ass kicked.

That brings me to the challenge level; it can be as hardcore as you want it to be or nice and easy if you're not too serious of a gamer. However regardless of what mode you choose, the game is generally pretty fair. Enemies can sometimes spawn near you but only at doors, so you know where they'll be coming from. Also they can't attack on the first turn they appear. This prevents the game from cheap-shotting you; you've always got time to adjust your strategy when something new comes up.

Overall I think this is really worth a try and is definitely one of the best indie games I've played in a while.

32340494.review:
Io odio gli strategici a turni,
ma dopo XCOM e SteamWorld Heist, mi sto letteralmente ricredendo.
So bene che si tratta di due titoli molto particolari, che prendono gli aspetti sostanziali degli strategici a turni classici e li rendono molto più alla portata di tutti i giocatori.
Per me, l'importante è che siano divertenti.

Cosa rende SteamWorld Heist bello a tal punto da farmi passare queste prime (perchè ci continuerò a giocare ancora per un bel po', senza contare che ho appena acquistato il DLC dell'avventura aggiuntiva) 15 ore senza tirarlo nel cassonetto delle centinaia di strategici che in passato ho provato a toccare? La dinamicità del combattimento.
La meccanica che più adoro è quella di puntamento dell'arma ed utilizzo degli utensili attraverso controllo diretto, proprio come in Worms, dove buona parte dell'esito della battaglia viene deciso da come il giocatore ha gestito il controllo dell'attacco, oltre al posizionamento strategico dei personaggi ed alla formulazione di strategie grazie alle sinergie tra le molteplici abilità dei personaggi disponibili.
Si può dire che questo titolo sia una versione più ristretta, raffinata ed ottimizzata, sia nella grafica che nelle meccaniche di gioco, della ben nota saga Worms.
Un enorme complimento al team di sviluppo che è passato da un titolo piattaforma/spelunker ad uno strategico/dinamico con enorme professionalità nella realizzazione tecnica ed artistica.

Lo stile grafico, inoltre, è ottimamente curato, con dettagli nello scenario e sfumature di colore mai in contrasto tra loro. Ottima anche la soundtrack, sebbene sia quasi del tutto mirata al setting "western" che a quello "metallico".

Lo consiglio agli amanti della serie Worms o a chi vuole cimentarsi in uno strategico senza troppi impegni.

RPG적인 요소가 섞여있어 레벨에 따라 스킬도 생기고 새로운 아이템을 얻어 캐릭터를 성장시키는 재미도 괜찮은 편.

32332078.review:
A truly excellent game. At first glance, it might seem like a nice little platformer, but it has a lot more depth than meets the eye. I played through on Regular difficulty, and managed to get 100% completion in 15 or so hours.

PROS:

+ Graphics are pleasant. Not high-end, but a lot of fun.
+ Music is excellent. And the game features the group Steam Powered Giraffe, a steampunk band that has written some excellent songs. (Confession: I kind of freaked out when I heard one of their songs playing at a location in the game.)
+ Gameplay is very well done. There is a dexterity element, but not too much.
+ Hats. Hats are awesome. I can't get enough hats. 

CONS:
- My one complaint would be that it got easier as I went on. My characters slowly grew in power compared to the enemy bots, so that the only reason I had to replay the final boss level was because I was so careless in how I played. That being said, it was still difficult enough to make me slow down and think my way through to beat the level.

CONCLUSION:
I love this game. Buy it, especially on sale. Get those hats!

FINAL RATING: 7/7

32295396.review:
Nice turn-based 2D combat game with unusual mechanics: Weapons need to be aimed, where some weapons' shots can be reflected off walls or have an arced trajectory and some weapons have a laser sight to help with aiming.

In addition, scenarios/levels are semi-randomly generated, which makes for high replayability value.  (I've replayed some scenarios 3-4 times to level up different members of the crew, and it did not get boring.)

Add to that fairly short scenarios (which adds a "casualty factor" - one can easily play for just 5-10 minutes to finish a level/scenario), a wide range of equipment that can be bought and found (on second play-through I got some items that I had not seen the first time 'round), a wide range of capabilities that crew members acquire when levelling up, and a nice background story.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who somewhat likes what they see in the screenshots.

32292065.review: Fun little turn-based tactical game with a decent sized campaign.

32290891.review:
Steamworld Heist è un titolo indie davvero originale e molto ben caratterizzato. La prima cosa che mi è piaciuta è il design del gioco in sé, tutte le macchine, cioè i robot che andremo ad utilizzare sono tutti molto diversi tra loro, sia nell'aspetto sia nel carattere. Si, perché a differenza di molti titoli indie in cui troveremo dei personaggi anonimi, qui c'è anche un po' di lore ben strutturata in maniera semplice e i personaggi che potremo scegliere (che senza i DLC sono 9), sono tutti ben caratterizzati e con il loro background narrativo interessante, raccontato in maniera semplice ma gradevole. 
La storia è molto semplice, mai banale. All'inizio, questa storia semplice servirà a farci appassionare al gioco, sucessivamente potrà sembrare troppo scontata, quindi non adatta a chi cerca una storia profonda. 
Il gioco risulta essere originale anche perché è uno strategico a turni, pertanto diverso dai tradizionali RTS, ma è originale paragonato anche agli altri strategici a turni, perché sarete voi con la vostra abilità di mira a decidere le sorti di una battaglia, dal momento che gestirete voi la direzionalità dei colpi e avendo la possibilità di far rimbalzare i colpi sulle pareti questa ottima meccanica di gioco viene esaltata ancora di più. All'interno del gioco troviamo pure una componente RPG che io ho apprezzato poiché incide leggermente sui combattimenti lasciando alla componente strategica e di precisione nella mira (quindi, all'abilità del giocatore) come componenti predominanti per vincere una battaglia. Il multiplayer è assente. Le mappe sono procedurali, ed ho apprezzato anche questo perché così facendo non imparerai mai un livello a memoria, ed anche se ripetendo ciascuna missione sarà più facile affrontare la missione, la componente strategica sarà importante per concluderlo con successo. Man mano che si andrà avanti col gioco tutti i personaggi sbloccheranno abilità diverse tipo più movimento, recupero salute, invulnerabilità, modalità Berserk, fare due mosse in un turno, più attacco ed ognuno oltre alla pistola che è l'arma più comune in questo gioco potrà utilizzare solo un altro tipo di arma come i fucili d'assalto, che sparano raffiche di proiettili, ma non sono precisi, fucili da cecchino dotati di mirino laser a lunga gittata e quindi con ottima precisione, alcuni tipi di armi da cecchino hanno un'alta probabilità di critico se i nemici vengono colpiti alla testa ed una capacità di infliggere danni leggermante superiore ai normali fucili da cecchino, ma se in un turno decidi di muoverti non puoi sparare e vice versa, le armi pesanti hanno un danno d'impatto piccolo, medio, grande, comunque più grande degli altri tipi di armi e possono arrecare danni anche agli alleati, molte di esse hanno una traiettoria ad arco, quindi poco precise, mentre solo una minima parte delle altre categorie di armi hanno traiettoria ad arco e fanno danni ad area.
Infine si potranno portare con sé due oggetti a personaggio che possono curare, infliggere più danni da esplosione come (missili e granate), o più danni da mischia quando si è vicini all'avversario o avere più movimento per avanzare di più caselle o invulnerabilità per un turno per incrementare la componente strategica del titolo.
Quindi un ottimo lavoro da parte di Image & Form Games con questo titolo che è interessantissimo sia per gli amanti degli strategici, sia per i neofiti, sia per chi vuole provare nuovi generi di giochi. Io l'ho acquistato su Hunble Bundle a $ 1 assieme ad altri due titoli, perciò a € 0,30 ciascuno. Complice anche una longevità di 25 ore di gioco circa non posso che dare un 8 a questo titolo.
