32262336.review:
5/5
SteamWorld Heist accomplished everything a tactical platformer could do.
Your teammates are varied, as are the weapons and items. There's a very well
done sliding difficulty scale coupled with gradually increasing skills and powers
for your team. While I did feel a bit overwhelmed at first managing all the different
teammates, I eventually figured out each member's unique skill set. The soundtrack
was high-quality and delivered that steampunk vibe. The art and animation was both
nostalgic and beautiful (especially considering how small the development team was).

If you've got a few bucks, or if you picked this up in the last Humble Bundle like I did,
grab and copy or install the copy that's been sitting in your Steam library for the past few
weeks. I had a blast.
I finished the game in a bit over 20 hours, but if you don't repeat any of the missions I imagine
it could be done in half that time or quicker.

Pros:
Fun, tactical game with a Steampunk theme and soundtrack
Progressive experience (meaning you start weak and end strong,
as do the enemies).
Varied items and weapons, and HATS!

Cons:
A few too many teammates for my taste. I always felt like I was
neglecting one of the duplicates (there's two of every type).

The overall idea and base gameplay is pretty fun; aim guns, bounce bullets, get loot.

Everything else manages to fiercely bog this down and make it an unfun mess from top to bottom. Aiming assumes that the robots breathe and becomes a tedious minigame unto itself, further made obnoxious because the only guns worth attempting bullet bounces with have laser sights.

A lot of the missions are fine and enjoyable but every single gimmick mission is never fun: solo missions (aka always take the bot with the kill shot ability), survival/ambush!, level filled with explosive/goo barrels! Rather than interesting level design, it's all about what stupid garbage they can shove in your face and make the entire thing a slog.

Also the plot/dialogue is somewhat endearing but utterly pointless.

32200420.review:
Dal punto di vista artistico, SteamWorld Heist non ha nulla da invidiare alla maggior parte dei suoi coetanei, offrendo una grafica lucida e colorata, musiche particolari, personaggi carismatici ed un intero mondo steampunk che piacerà parecchio agli amanti del genere. Anche il gameplay si presenta abbastanza bene e le battaglie, giustamente punitive, sono brevi ma frenetiche, arricchite da un sistema di mira che prevede lo sfruttamento dinamico dell'ambiente circostante. 
Il problema è che tutti questi ingredienti, pur risultando perfettamente sinergici tra di loro, non riescono a mascherare una banalità di fondo veramente disarmante. Le battaglie richiedono un approccio strategico elementare ed è possibile terminare il gioco sorvolando del tutto sull'organizzazione di equipaggiamenti, abilità e classi a disposizione. In questo modo i negozi appaiono inutili, le stazioni di servizio diventano un pretesto per mantenere in vita l'orribile trama di fondo ed ogni livello inizia e finisce allo stesso modo di quello precedente. 
SteamWorld Heist sarà anche colorato e pieno di buone idee, ma non supera la qualità di un giochino per mobile: chi grida al capolavoro probabilmente non possiede un cellulare.

32191803.review: The way i describe this game to my friends is that is like 2d XCOM lite. Now i realize that description does not do this game justice. Granted there are a few similarities, being that it is a turn based strategy game where you move troops and kill enemies, but that is about where it stops. I've come to realize that everything else that is in the game is why i keep coming back to it. It has a little bit of everything for everyone. If you are into steampunky robots then the aesthetic is right up your alley. If you like a kinda rag tag group of space pirates trying to change the world then the story should have you engaged and laughing the whole way through. If you like compelling turn based gameplay with a decent variety of weapons and inventive gunplay, then this is the game for you. There are, however, some things i don’t particularly like. For example, near the beginning of the game it feels like you're always leveling, changing out your guns, and experiencing new encounters. After the halfway point though this slowed down pretty hard for me. This is probably because i found who i like and kitted everyone how i wanted to by then so the experimentation phase was over and the refining phase had begun. I just kinda wished they had paced out the leveling and loot grabbing a little slower in the beginning and sped it up a little near the end. It doesn’t really hurt the game it is just a small nitpick for an overall great indie title. Oh and one more thing, the music in this game is done by a band called Steam Powered Giraffe, and it is all phenomenal. It is perfectly thematic and very well done through and through.

32180303.review:
Supremely fun and overall simple turn based strategy game. Progress can be a bit slow at times and the story isn't super strong, but the actual gameplay is extemely enjoyable.

The game is definitely easier than something like XCOM, but I find that to just be more relaxing (one wrong move is less likely to ruin your game and you won't lose your best characters forever). It is probably the best balance of fun and strategy I have encountered in a strategy game yet.

Levels themselves are randomly generated (which makes playing them again better), but the overall flow of the game is already set. Replay of the full game isn't really there, but since you will only ever take up to 4 of your characters with on a given mission and many more stay on the ship, there is the possibility of playing in different ways.

The ability to replay old levels also allows you to experiment with different characters and grind a bit if you're having more of a challenge (which is my favorite way of handling difficulty).

Just so very fun.

32136198.review:
Long story short, this game is excellent. Take XCom (or Hard West, if you've played that), make it 2D, and theme it around cynical, steampunk robot cowboy criminals. Then take a Worms-style aiming system and make bullets ricochet in ways that allow some of the greatest trickshots in history, and you've got SteamWorld Heist.

This game is basically the epitome of my aesthetic to begin with, as SteamWorld Dig was before it, but it also happens to be a great game on top of that. It's not too difficult, but the ability to make things harder for yourself by going for secondary objectives like shooting off enemies' hats or grabbing 100% of the loot in a level or using crew members who don't normally see action allows a great amount of replayability.

It's well worth its full asking price, but if you happen to catch this game on sale - like it is at the time of the writing of this review - definitely grab this one!

32121174.review:
Steamworld Heist is #1 in my list of Steam games that deserve more attention than it got. It's what could be described as a combination between Scorched Earth and Fire Emblem... a turn-based strategy game that takes place on a 2d plane where the ability to aim arcing shots is part of the strategy. As far as I know, Steamworld Heist is the first game to try anything like this, and it succeeds quite admirably.

As unusual as the game is, it's very intuitive, thanks in part to its multiple difficulty modes, as well as the general structure of the game. The first mission begins with two playable characters, one of which has a scope to help her aim, and a fairly straightforward quest to pick up a certain treasure chest. As more missions are completed, more characters are unlocked, and and new concepts such as time limits and survival rounds come up, all in an organic way that never leaves the player feeling overwhelmed.

The art style carries over from I&F's earlier game Steamworld Dig, with larger sprites, each character having their own cool, distinctive robotic design. As for the soundtrack, well, it's beyond reproach. Missions are accompanied by adrenaline-pumping beats, while the occasional visit to a saloon (or victory over a boss) will treat you to a delightful vocal tune from Steam-powered Giraffe. I don't buy soundtracks to go with my steam games often, but I did with this one!

As an added li'l bonus, this is one of the few games that adjusts its graphics accordingly if you play it with a Playstation controller in the MacOS version.

This game does just about everything right; if I were to find something to nitpick, it's with the hat collection, which is both the best and worst feature, as while most of them can be simply bought or shot off of specific enemies, there are certain ones (a few of which the achievements require) that require luck and grinding... and grinding just doesn't suit this game all that well.

Buy this game! We'll be seeing a second Steamworld Dig game this Summer, and it'd be nice to see another Heist game sometime as well!

32114781.review:
To sum up SteamWorld Heist is not hard; worms style 2D turn based combat with a little bit of X-Com flair when moving. While at the same time staying its own game and taking only the steam punk esthetic from its predecessor, [b]SteamWorld Dig[/b].

So the game plays as follows: fly your ship between checkpoints in space - a map or hub area if you will. These may be space station bars where you get your drink on (what do robots drink anyway?), buy weapons and other equipment or hire other scrappy robots which can be used as units in battle. Other areas, enemy ships, is where you will be spending most of your time, battling it out and collecting loot to use or money to spend. Sometimes you may come across a lonesome space station selling hats at outrageously high prices...

So the bulk of the game is spent in battles and the combat system is well polished to make that time fly by. You enter a semi randomly generated map (station) with usually two or three teammates equipped with weapons and accessories of your choosing. Each round gives you a movement and attack phase in which you can either hide for cover or attack (sometimes both). Since step count is limited, it is important to find a location in which you will be hard to hit yet still easy to hit your enemy from. It is a simple design that may lack some depth. I would love to have the ability to have one of my teammates just defend a position and shoot whomever wanders into its line of sight but right now all a defending teammate does is cower behind a barrel and get hit if an enemy chooses show who has the biggest metal sack. Attacking is more engaging and rightfully more fun. An assortment of weapons is available all wealdable by its specific class of character. Your everyday pistols, scoped weapons offer bouncing bullets, high spread shotguns, high rate-of-fire multiple shot rifles, AOE line of sight RPG explosions, arching grenade launcher AOE explosion and metal to brass fists all offer different playstiles and entry points to each situation one may find oneself in. I particularly enjoyed scoped weapons which offere laser sights for their easy of use in bouncing bullets off walls to hit harder to hit enemies. Since headshots provide a higher damage output, these were particularly useful. A good combination of different characters with different weapon sets does the job fine while mixing it up just a little bit as to not get too monotonous while shooting only one tipe of weapon (as if it ever could). The reward for clearing out these outposts is usually more gear to use for the next mission or money to buy yet more gear OR a fancy hat or two. Hats are the money sink that makes the economy work as you will soon have enough money to have all equipment you need. It's an alright system that seems to work fine with most virtual macro economies, here being no different.

Each map sector ends with a boss fight in which all your skills will be tested against a fairly stronger enemy. The difficulty of these are nicely tuned and provide ample release of dopamine.

Esthetically SteamWorld Heist reminds me of Firefly (Tv Series, 2002) albeit with a cartoony overlay. Space ships looking like the scifi future movies promise swapped for coal powered furnaces and steam turbines. Ships held together by sheet metal and rivets. A world populated by robots wielding guns, wearing fancy hats and everything generally feeling like the wild west in space. The music consolidates this idea of steam punk wild west robots in space. Guitar, banjo, bass, fiddle and a strong vocal presence that tells stories of robots are exactly what one would expect from a world such as this. The Band [b][url=https://steampoweredgiraffe.bandcamp.com/album/music-from-steamworld-heist]Steam Powered Giraffe[/url][/b] are personified as robots and can be found in any bar in the game playing their music. I sometimes visited just for the music. 

SteamWorld Heist is a great game to relax with and not stress over too much. Core gameplay containing simple tactical turn based gameplay. It clearly defines goals and provides extra rewards for extra work / exploration. A pleasant to look at esthetic and guitar heavy soundtrack with some rather fine folksy vocals. It took me 17 hours to beat the game and I enjoyed every minute of it.

32094737.review: Quando si arriva a fatti, SteamWorld Heist prende vita in uno scenario totalmente bidimensionale, con le varie parti della mappa precluse alla vista, e pronte a svelarsi all'apertura di porte e feritoie. Ogni personaggio può muoversi per un determinato numero di spazi, senza grossi limiti a dire il vero, eccetto che per le azioni da compiere. Mi spiego meglio: se ci si vuole solo appostare in un determinato punto, lo spazio di manovra è piuttosto ampio. Viceversa, raccogliere un oggetto, aprire una botola o attaccare il nemico, limita i nostri movimenti, ricoprendo gran parte del turno. Questa caratteristica è mostrata il maniera decisamente pratica tramite un cursore su schermo: possiamo muoverci e agire fintanto che la linea di movimento rimane arancione; appena quest'ultima diventa blu, significa che abbiamo esaurito il margine di manovra e possiamo solo appostarci. È necessario, quindi, rimanere entro il limite arancione, per ottimizzare al massimo i movimenti e concludere ogni azione con una mossa utile, magari proprio un attacco. SteamWorld Heist è uno strategico a turni dotato di grande carisma e in grado di appassionare per lungo tempo, grazie alla struttura procedurale degli stage e i cinque livelli di difficoltà. Un titolo in grado di dire la propria grazie a una struttura totalmente bidimensionale e un universo Steampunk stilizzato e intrigante

32069664.review:
Blub-blub.

V jednoduchosti a starých principech je síla, řeklo si pár lidí a tak vznikla hra SteamWorld Heist. Pokud běžně tento typ plošinovek nehrajete, nebo dokonce k takovým hrám citíte odpor, vězte že tentokrát se váš pohled na tento herní žánr jistě změní.

Jste součástí již zaniklé civilizace, která po svém zániku za sebou zanechala spoustu bordelu a šrotu a vtipné kaše. Ta totiž dala vzniknout nové formě života, tzv. plecháčům (jakobych viděl dejavú - Oscara ze Syberie :D ). Bender z Futuramy by taktéž rád poznal své staronové bratry, ale shledání bude muset ještě chvíli počkat, náš neohrozený velitel plecháč v jehož roli se nacházíte má totiž ještě kupu práce. Jako ostřílený pašerák ve stylu Hana Sola máte co dělat, abyste stíhali splátky a spolu svým kapitánem lodi (který je k ní chudák přivařený) létáte touto plechovou kysnou a narážíte na první z mnoha problémů. A tak se chopíte práce a vzniklé problémy začnete řešit. Jak se tento jednoduchý příběh začne komplikovat a problémů se hromadí o poznání více, budou se k vám přídávat další plechoví pomocníci do týmu.

Zpočátku vám to ani nepřijde, že se zde děje něco neobvyklého, běžná plošinovka se totiž postupně stává stále návykovější a zábavnější. Postavy které mezi sebou vzájemně v rámci příběhu komunikují vtipem jenom hýří a občas se dá narazit i na nějakou známou hlášku z filmu apod. Srandu zpestří i hovořící ryba, která je opravdu skvělým válečníkem. Hra má celkem 3 kampaně o různých místech a nepřátelé postupně začínají být větší a větší výzvou. Arzenál budete nacházet i kupovat v putykách a to z vás později včetně vyvíjejících se skillů udělá ostřílené bojovníky. Celkem budete moci fungovat s partou o osmi postavách, najednou budou v mapě nejvíce ale jen 4 a tak je dobré si rozmyslet s jakou ostavou s jakými zbraněni a vylešeními budete danou mapu zdolávat. Mapy si užiteje v celé skupině, ale třeba i jen sólo, takže se nebudete opravdu nudit. Je taktéž nutno říci, že mapy jsou stejné jen výjimečně, převážná většina map je generována a tak se toho zase moc opakovat nebude. Postupem času zjistíte, že taktizování přesunů, jakési kalkulování tahů (jedná se přecejen o tahovku) si budete doslova užívat. Budete tlačeni časem, budete tlačeni nepřáteli, budete tlačeni úkoly ale hlavně budete cítit, že tady v této hře je to přesně to, co má být. Hratelnost je taktéž fajn. Člověka sice zamrzí, když ta jeho skvělá zbraň ho trochu omezí v pohybu a nemůže s ní zacházet jako Rambo, ale navadí to, dá se na to zvyknout a zahrnout to do strategie.

Jak se tato hra zdála na začátku fádní a trošku nezáživná, postupem času se díky skvělé propracovanosti, výborným nápadům stala hrou, které rád udělím velmi slušné hodnocení a vřele doporučím prakticky komukoli, kdo hledá něco zvlášního nebo nějakou změnu.

Hodnocení: 9/10

32034073.review:
What an excellent game. Thoroughly enjoyed it from start to finish.

SteamWorld Heist is a great application of Worms-esqe skillful turn-based combat. Sure, no wind speed or power meters or crazy weapons, but having to physically aim the weapons instead of praying to RNGesus is a sadly underutilized turn-based combat mechanic.

Weapon/loot variety is pretty anemic, but on the other hand I appreciated that it minimized time spent gearing up the crew. There was a great progression in environments and enemy types, so I was constantly tweaking my tactics instead of falling into a rut. I really enjoyed the diverse crew members you can recruit. Some characters appeared useless at first, but really blossomed after levelling up. In fact, it was the snipers (of which you can end up with three) which initially felt overpowered, and ended up the most useless by the end.

Perfect length; didn't overstay its welcome, felt fresh from beginning to end. That was even with replaying some missions to go for full gold stars.

32028070.review:
Предыдущая игра студии, SteamWorld Dig, была симпатичной, но простенькой метроидванией, и от новой игры я ничего не ожидал. Но оказалось, что она прекрасна. SteamWorld Heist это тактика с двухфазной системой хода, которая стала стандартом после XCom, в боковой двумерной проекции, как в платформерах. Механика элементарна, но дизайн локаций и баланс срабатывают на тактическую глубину, и дают возможность для множества тактических решений. Хоть эта игра с виду и выглядит казуалкой, на самом деле это фронтир современных тактических игр, и в дальнейшем творческий поиск будет отталкиваться именно от таких игр как эта.

Сеттинг чумовой и многообещающий. В космосе летают сделанные из мусора корабли на паровой тяге, и берут друг друга на абордаж. Графика ярковата и слишком комиксовая. Музыка просто великолепна. Лучше, чем радио пустошей в Фоллауте.

Отдельное обращение к геймерам 30+ (я сам к этой категории принадлежу). Ребята, кончайте тратить время на тактические игры с Кикстартера, где некроманты от игровой индустрии пытаются оживить скелеты 20-летней давности. Игры существуют чтобы получать фан. Никакого фана и тактики в поисках последнего моба на локации и в медитации на десятки дисбалансных статов нет. А в этой игре фан и тактика есть.

31998689.review:
ถึงแม้ว่าจะใช้ชื่อ Steamworld เหมือนกัน แต่เกมนี้เกี่ยวกับภาค Dig แบบบางๆเท่านั้น เนื้อหามันแยกออกจากกันเลย

สำหรับ Heist นั้นเป็นเกมแนว Strategy แบบ 2D ที่ใช้การเล็งด้วยมือและการชิ่งกระสุนเอาชนะศัตรู เกมสนุกมากไม่ว่าจะเล่นง่ายสุด (ที่รู้สึกโคตรเก่งโคตรเทพชิ่งกระสุนกันมันส์ และยังมีบางด่านที่ท้าทายอยู่) หรือเล่นยากสุด (ลุ้นมันทุกรอบเพราะศัตรูยิงแม่นมาก) มีอาวุธมีไอเท็มให้สะสมเพียบ และมีหมวกด้วย

ขณะที่เขียนอยู่ที่ อยู่ในชุด Humble ขั้นต่ำ $1 ถ้าชอบเกม Dig ตรงที่มันขุดก็อาจจะไม่ชอบภาคนี้ (มีคนบ่นใน Forum แล้ว) แนะนำให้รอ Dig 2 แต่ถ้าชอบสไตล์ของเกมที่เป็นหุ่นยนต์/Steampunk/Western รวมถึงชอบแนววางแผนล่ะก็ เกมนี้ตอบโจทย์ได้ดีเลย

31995907.review:
[h1][b]TL;DR: [/b] Something XCom would have been if it had a sense of humor and was about robots.[/h1]

Very talented indie company (one of my favourites, frankly) that makes absolutely brilliant titles. So far it only has 4 games (2 were released on Steam, this one included), but they're just marvelous. By the way, check out [b]SteamWorld Dig[/b], if you haven't yet -- support the real deal in indie game development!

Anyway, back to the game.

Simply put, it's a turn-based tactical strategy with heavy focus on aiming in combat. You can customize your squad with a variety of weapons and items. You can also change your squad members with new members you find throughout the game. Team composition matters a lot -- your teammates have different classes, so each of them is sporting different skillset, can use different weapons and can be very effective in some scenarios while lacking in others. Classes are somewhat close to what newest XCom was offering.

Aim plays heavy role in combat, as it is not % based (like it was in Fallout or XCom), but instead you get to pick a moment and shoot the waddling crosshair yourself, and Missing is very easy, especially on long distances, but hitting that bouncing off the walls shot is very fulfilling, even if the enemy is still alive after that.

Learning curve is pretty good -- difficulty is going up gradually, so you'll have time to learn every nook and cranny. Also, every level that you played already can be replayed to grind some more XP for your crew members (if the upcoming level seems too hard for you).

Story is great, dialogue is heavily affected by a variety of spaghetti westerns. Characters are well-written and occasional phrases by crew members are hilarious.

Graphics and animation are awesome -- if you like cartoonish look and fluent animation, you'll definitely love this.

Sounds and music are fitting and are not distracting at all. OST is sold separately, so if you're into that, buy one for yourself (or listen on Youtube for free, whatever floats your boat).

[h1]Will I recommend this game?[/h1]
Definitely. People that love a good western and turn-based combat are going to love it. Fans of indie games are going to love it as well.

31987138.review:
A tactical RPG with a gimmick of controlling the guns you fire may seem like a strange idea - and it sorta is - but SteamWorld Heist does a good job of hitting the mark while also variating their gameplay enough to remain fresh. Things may burn out near the end but from start to finish Heist satisifes.

So, quick summary, SteamWorld Heist has you patrolling the stars a la Firefly taking on progressively greater threats, starting from lowly (insane) bandits to the local military-government complex. Along the way you get crazier additions to your crew with their own unique abilities, a crap-load of guns, and many many things to shoot. You enter a ship, you use your weaponry to shoot your enemies and perform bank shots where necessary, you finish an objective, you collect loot, you repeat. A randomized ship to conquer along with random drops that supplement many different playstyles, along with various enemy types and objectives keeps you going along. But eventually the repetition does set in. There is a ton to experience in SteamWorld Heist, but it does repeat the same premise just with slightly different scenarios forcing you to stay on your toes. However, it isn't enough to make it really sting until you make it to the end of your ~10 hour quest which means you're getting a lot of fun game to play with. Heist does a great job with difficulty as well, slowly ramping things up until you can grab better weaponry and hone your skills to avoid quick painful deaths because you were on the wrong side of cover. But that's okay, heists are ten to fifteen minutes each, a failure will only hurt your wallet and some of your free time.

So is SteamWorld Heist worth your money? I'd say so. If you're a fan of tactical RPGs and need a little more ingame action then you're in luck as Heist is make or break on your ability to judge your aim. But if you want gameplay that's more actually tactical over aiming and praying for the best then you'll be looking for something else. But even so Heist is worth your time for its concept alone and its large spacey world full of unique life. Recommended for full price for all comers.

31976532.review:
Is SteamWorld Heist worth playing? I could only put down a tentative yes.

Pros:

1. Nicely drawn graphics. Every character carry it's own unique feel and personality.

2. Nice soundtrack. I personally thought the Robot band playing at rest stop is quite enjoyable so much so that I found myself lingering in that area for a few moments just enjoying the music.

Cons:

1. Too grindy. Partly because when you recruit new members they don't sync up to your current level, so if you want to use them you'll have to painstakingly replay and older mission several times to get them up to speed. Also, the drop is almost completely random (save for the epic swag, which are predetermined); although it didn't causes me any trouble during my playthrough, it's possible to get a bunch of lousy gear which forces you to grind for proper gear in order to advance.

2. Difficulty curve is kind of a joke. It is more challenging, but you only get some bonus experience, and achievements if you're into that sort of thing. so in short, there's not much incentive to play it at any difficulty other than casual. Because if you fail a mission at higher difficulty, there's actually a penalty in place, which will force you to grind even more to earn to earn back the credit.

Summary:

In many ways, SteamWorld Heist is kind of plays like a 2D version of XCOM, if all the character in XCOM has been replaced with robots. In SteamWorld Heist, the lousy hit chance is replaced with aiming so even if you miss a shot you'll never feel like the game cheated you out of your win. But on the other hand, there's not much ststus effect in SteamWorld Heist so every stage is just a slow push from one end of the map to the other if you're playing on harder difficulty.

In short. SteamWorld Heist is unique enough to warrant one playthrough. I just don't see any replay value unless you're a completionist.

31890173.review:
It's an excellent, turn-based, two-dimensional, strategy game. To quote TB, it reminds me a lot of XCOM mixed with Worms. Watching gameplay, I wasn't sure that I'd like it, but after a few missions, I started really enjoying the game. It has a really easy learning curve, which saves you from a headache from trying to learn how to play a new game for the first time. The great part is that it's not at the sacrifice of gameplay depth.

There's something to be said about the fun of developing a team composition to optimally take out all the enemies on a ship. You can use less-mobile sniper characters to ricochet projectiles around the ship a million times before it lands between the eyes of an enemy robot, use a tanky melee character to rush down large enemies, and use your captain to support those roles with heals and damage buffs. There are several more character types as well.

If any of that sounds interesting to you, I'd definitely recommend picking this up.

31889040.review:
[h1][b]雖非大作卻是款相當優秀的作品，音樂動聽、遊戲娛樂性十足；除了關卡較少、遊戲時間不長外，沒其他明顯缺點了。[/b][/h1]

終於在 HumbleBundle 入了這款躺在願望清單裡很久的遊戲。
遊戲方式是回合制、射擊，不含 DLC 有3大關約41個關卡，以歷險、軍閥到外星人為主題。以較簡單的難度進行遊戲，通關一輪時間約十數個小時，每個小關卡也大約只要 20～30 分鐘，整個遊戲輕快、順暢好上手，搭配好聽有特色的遊戲音樂，有一種西部風格的遊戲感受。

重要的事要先講，遊戲有通關繼承的設定，但只有一開始就能使用所有角色，還有所有收集到的帽子，其他的像是人物等級、武器、裝備、水貨幣等等，通通都會消失，所以不用特地的花時間練等級、農裝備。
角色在出任務時若不幸陣亡，回到母艦會重生，但陣亡的懲罰是該關卡沒獲得經驗。若是滅團，還會加扣 50% 水貨幣。去過得關卡可以重複造訪，所有物品都可以再次拾取，但曾經開過得寶物箱拾取後不會再次開到物品，只有資源袋可以。收集到的水貨幣可用來買物品存儲格、帽子、特殊武器、招募其他角色都會用到。武器裝備售價很貴、出售的折價卻很高，但買不起也沒關係，運氣要是夠好，在關卡裡都能獲得。
遊戲中有九個角色(不含DLC)，但依關卡限制最多只能有四人上場。基本可用武器都是手槍，神槍手職業可使用狙擊槍，突擊隊員可使用衝鋒槍、散彈槍，重裝兵可用火箭筒、榴彈砲等重武器，搭配特殊裝備進行任務，能有很多種、多樣化的選擇與遊戲性。子彈部份打對地方是可以彈跳的，有的敵人甚至可以神奇的在四面牆壁上彈一圈後才命中人。

遊戲在每回合之間、退出遊戲時都會存檔，方便讓玩家能隨時中斷，這也是回合制遊戲的優點之一。個人實驗，每個關卡開場前，可先回到主畫面，將遊戲存檔複製保存，若是任務失敗或滅團，可回主畫面把存檔覆蓋回來，遊戲進度就會保存在複製當時，也算是手動的SL大法了。
遊戲存檔位置：Win7 \\Administrator\Documents\My Games\SteamWorld Heist\savegame_000.dat (另外還有 savegame_001.dat、savegame_002.dat 依使用的儲存格位置)。

31883614.review:
Exelente titulo, un juego redondo se podria decir.
Tiene todo lo necesario en cada apartado y compensando sus costados mas flojos por decirlo de alguna manera, 
Esto hace dificil recalcar algo negativo mas bien las  cosas que podrian mejorarse.
Se trata ee un juego tactico por turnos en dos dimensiones y vista lateral.
Contrloamos un grupo de robots que vamos a ir reclutando a lo largo de la campaña. Cada uno posee distintas habilidades que van ganando a medida que se les sube de nivel.
Cada mision requiere un numero determinado de unidades por lo que debemos decidir que personajes enviar que tengan habilidades que se puedan complementar o el equipo adecuado a nuestra manera de jugar.
A primera vista parece un juego muy simple, de hecho lo es
en los primeros compases, donde no tenemos mas recursos que cubrirnos y disparar, pero rapidamente el juego agrega elementos que lo hacen muy interesante como disparos que rebotan o daño en area, fuego amigo, flanqueos, ataques melee,habilidades de soporte etc...

***Lo bueno***

-Graficamente es bastante vistoso, con unos graficos en 2D caricaturescos y con animaciones fluidas.
-En lo sonoro destaca la musica sobre los efectos, es muy acorde a la estetica del juego y de gran calidad, inclusive trae algunas pistas cantadas.
-La curva de dificultad es buena.
-El sentido de progrecion,esta muy bien como se amolda a la curva de dificultad. A medida que avanzamos los combates se hacen mas complicados pero a su vez sentimos que tenemos mas recursos y mecanicas que explotar con cada elemento que se añade.
-Es muy divertido jugablemente, este es el factor de mas peso.
-A pesar que se notan algunas influencias como xcom en la forma de movernos o buscar cobertura, o de worms cuando realizamos algun disparo. El conjunto resulta siendo algo original, se sabe distiguir creando su propia escensia.

***Mejorable***

-Podria tener algo mas de variedad en sus misiones, a pesar de que no llega a aburrir.
-La gestion del inventario podria mejorarse. Los items estan todos juntos y tenemos que posar el cursor para saber quien lo tiene equipado a su vez si queremos equiparlo a otro personaje solo se hace en la pantalla previa a una mision.

Для человека, у которого всегда полно разных дел "SteamWorld Heist" будет идеальным выбором.
Забавный экшен, с незатейливым сюжетом и оригинальным ни на что не похожим игровым миром, позволит приятно провести минут 30 свободного времени в день без лишнего врастания в игровые контроллеры. 
Пошаговый геймплей даст возможность отвлечься практически в любой момент. Упрощенная прокачка персонажей и их кастомизация ...шляпами!? %) согреет душу любителям жанра RPG, таким как я ;) 
Положительным моментом считаю возможность не бездумно мочить врагов, а все же применять мозг для построения тактических комбинаций при прохождении уровней. 
Музыкальное сопровождение в игре на высоте. Фолк-рок-группа "Steam Powered Giraffe" создала для "SteamWorld" очень атмосферный саундтрек. Их песня "No More Queen!" - прям хит! :)
По моему глубокому убеждению компьютерные игры призваны развлекать человека, а не заставлять его снова работать, и "SteamWorld Heist" справляется с этой задачей на все 100%. 
Недостаток же у игры только один - она коротенькая, но решается это просто - играйте на уровне сложности "Элита" ;)

Also the menus are great, snappy as all hell, minor thing but I had to mention it.

31869238.review:
Steamworld: Heist is an undoubtedly unique gaming experience; a one that pulls you in and never lets you go. As someone who has never played a single other game from the Steamworld universe (and thus was not particularly interested in the game's overall lore), I must say that I found myself utterly loving every minute of this rusty steampunk space-opera. Steamworld: Heist is an absolutely brilliant amalgamation: it has the atmosphere of Firefly, the gameplay of simplified X-COM (combined with some traditional platformer design), the hand-drawn graphics of a wonderful cartoon and the unmistakable music of "Steam Powered Giraffe" integrated brilliantly within the game's scenery. I cannot but recommend.

TO SUM UP: For a game about a bunch of rusty, steam-powered, oil-filled metal tin cans with a particularly uncomprehensible speach patterns cruising through a rather crazy side of the cosmos, Steamworld: Heist certainly has a surprising amount of soul. Should you ever find yourself thinking about trying something new and a little bit different,  pull the metaphorical trigger and give this adventure a shot! After all, it might just ricochet in the right way and hit you in your soft spot...

If you're like me and you got this for under 1$ on Humble Bundle, its well worth to have and play. Fun little game, might even be a ''hidden gem'' on steam. Yet my review is negative. Well, Its not really a 'negative' but more a: 'Much room for improvement'. Its a fine turn based game but with so manny little annoyances, it ruins the whole. 

The dialogue and writing is so awefull. I stopped reading anything of dialogue entirely after the first chapter, just 'whatever'. Its not intriguing or interesting in any way. It has those meme references that are supposed to be funny, that really isnt my kind of humor. 

Second of all the game gets the award for the most awefull soundtrack ever. Whenever you enter a bar or safe area some kind of new age music album starts playing that is a mix between Michael Buble and some 1970 American country music. I really feel like they got paid to put that in or that they know these guys who made the music, it doesnt fit the steampunk theme AT ALL. 

Gameplay wise? Now if you keep playing this at one difficulty level, the trashmobs and default levels are WAY too easy, and bossfights are WAY too hard. Not a fan of that at all. I hate being stuck at a bossfight. Overal gameplay is fine, guns feel really like they do damage with the slow motion effects and one-hit kills. 

What i'm missing here is that this should be more like FTL. The journey, levels and enemies all randomized. They claim that the levels are 'randomly generated' but its all linear and story driven. I'm also missing upgrades. Yes, you can change the layout of your characters and they will unlock some new (mostly passive) skills, but thats it. Water (The in-game currency) will stack up in no time, to a point where there is no real use for it anymore. 

The game is bug free. + for that.

31845079.review:
Surprisingly fun game. I recommend it for a good 6+ hours of gameplay. A good break from regular PC gaming.

Pros:
- It's a turn based platformer. Oddly satisfying. Didn't know I needed one.
- Steampunk / cowboy / robot / pirate theme. Very nice. 
- Hat collection. (More on that below)
- Sound, graphics and physics all work in favor of the game's flavor and gameplay. 
- Real swaying aim and ricochet physics. 
(It's on sale at HB right now. No excuse not to try it)

Cons - not too bad: 
- Leveling new additions to the crew takes some grinding on old levels, which takes away from the feel of story progress. I'd replay the levels anyway. The issue is pace, and character imbalance, but that goes pretty quickly. 
- Loot is mostly linear. You get a +2 pistol to replace your +1, or it might add a scope, etc. 

--

Character leveling is great, because it advances the whole game, but the new skills are all predetermined for you. You can't see what they are in advance to see who you want to level first. Better for game balance, but less exciting when one character gets 1 Health, while another gets an extra action every turn. 

It trades an X/Y strategy map for an X/Z map, and it works. It would take away from the game if it were top-down instead of side scrolling. 

I didn't get into the hat collection at first. It plays off the aiming and physics really well. When bots are hiding behind barrels, and you try to make a headshot, you may miss slightly and only shoot off their hat in a very cowboy themed shootout style. THEN as you are being chased off their ship .. Well, you can't just leave it lying there on the floor. What kind of robot pirate cowboy ARE you anyway?

31830422.review:
So, this really is a gold mine in the world of single player turn-based strategy games. And I'll admit, I was skeptical when it said "Plays best with a Controller". But my god, this game is fluid, fun, and incredibly endearing.

[b]The Good-Good[/b]
[list]
 [*]This game immediately caters to both kinds of players that would enjoy this: those that want some loveable steam robots heisting with some witty banter, or those that want the nitty-gritty tactical challenge of acing every mission. There are plenty of difficulties available, allowing the player to (inadvertently) set the level of stress they want to endure in each mission of the game. All the dialogue is skippable if you just mash a button, so if you REALLY can't wait to get back into the action, you're set. But on the other hand, you can take the game leisurely and enjoy the robotic banter.
 [*]On the topic of robotic banter, the story is actually pretty enjoyable, and even skipping dialogue I found myself very fond of a lot of the characters. It's witty, clever, and makes the characters very likeable.
 [*]The aesthetics of the game are incredible. Every background, character, enemy, what-have-you looks incredibly good. 
 [*]I was skeptical of a 2D turn-based strategy game at first (how do you incorporate what looks like platforming into a TBS game??) but the gameplay is actually incredibly simple but rewarding. This is not a difficult strategy game to pick up, which rewards the player for getting better at the strategy it [i]does[/i] encourage.
 [*]The music is INCREDIBLE. I'm not much of a fan of steampunk-themed bands, but Steam Powered Giraffe is definitely the right choice for this game. The first time I walked into one of the saloons in the game and realized the music was from an actual band (and one immortalized in the game by playing in said saloon), I found myself looking up the band and singing along to at least Brass Goggles.
 [*]The combat is unique. Most if not all bullets ricochet or can be modified by skills or the weapon your bots use, meaning you can create some impressive trick shots to secure a clutch kill. Sometimes you'll even have the "WHOAH, I DIDN'T MEAN TO DO THAT BUT IT WAS AWESOME" kinda thing, which puts a good grin on your face. Plus, you can shoot off an enemies hat and take it. So hats. We love hats.
[/list]

[b]The So-So[/b]
[list]
 [*]Honestly, I wouldn't mind having a PvP/Online mode to this game. I can see how balance issues would arise based on item tiers and whatnot, but it would be cool to see it incorporated. Maybe not in a turbo-competitive manner, but something where you could hop in and try to square off against an opponent and maybe snag some hats as rewards and such. I don't see this ever being implemented, but it would've been cool.
 [*]The enemy AI is kinda hit or miss, both in the literal and figurative way. Sometimes they'll make some really dumb moves and shoot a wall, and then other times they'll break out some crazy strats and you'll get wrecked by being swarmed or by a trickshot only a twelve-year-old CoD player could dream of. It doesn't feel cheatsy, just that it's sometimes inconsistent.
[/list]

[b]The No-No[/b]
[list]
 [*]Nothing to see here folks, it's an incredible game. Pick it up!
[/list]

-Scrumpy

31786531.review:
Als ich vor etwa 3 Jahren mit „SteamWorld Dig“ (= SWD) in Kontakt kam, hatten mich die schwedischen Entwickler von Image&Form Games direkt als neuen Fan gewonnen. Ich liebte den detailverliebten Comic-Look, ich liebte die witzige Figurengestaltung der Steambots und den dazugehörigen Humor, ich liebte den von Spaghetti-Western inspirierten Soundtrack, und ich liebte diese Mischung aus vertikal gerichtetem Plattformer, Metroidvania und „BoulderDash“-Nachahmung. An sich ein simples Konzept, aber auf seine Weise auch irgendwie grandios. Und leider auch recht kurz. Ich wollte mehr. Ich wollte eine Fortsetzung. Besser gestern als morgen. ;)
Mit der Ankündigung des nächsten und auf den Namen „SteamWorld Heist“ (= SWH) getauften Projekts wurde meine Vorfreude allerdings gebremst. Anfangs. Denn SWH blieb zwar SWD stilistisch treu, wechselte nun jedoch in ein ganz anderes Genre. Zweidimensionale Rundentaktik auf Weltraum-Kreuzern sollte es nun sein, kein Buddeln mehr in tiefsten Minen. Mein Interesse war fast verflogen, doch beim letzten Winter-Sale gab ich mir nen Ruck und packte SWH in den Warenkorb. Nach über 30 gespielten Stunden müsste ich Image&Form eigentlich um Vergebung bitten, denn mit meiner vorausgegangenen Skepsis/Ablehnung lag ich derart falsch wie noch nie. SWH hat mich wohl noch mehr zum bedingungslosen SteamWorld-Fan gemacht, während die Entwickler den Beweis liefern dass sie ihr eigenes Steambot-Universum sogar Genre-übergreifend gekonnt zu erweitern wissen.

Es herrschen schwere Zeiten. Für Hydrofarmer, Schmuggler, Bergleute – und auch Cowbots wie Captain Piper Faraday und ihre Crew, denn Wasser ist nach der Zerstörung der Erde knapp, und so gehört es zu deren Tagesgeschäft Piraten-Raumschiffe zu entern und nur ganz bösen Schrottern (= quasi Roboter-Zombies) das wertvolle Nass mit Waffengewalt abzuknöpfen. Weil jedoch die Schrotter-Plage immer größer wird, Diesel-Royalisten vor der Unterdrückung von Zivilisten nicht zurückschrecken und dazu noch eine fremde wie auch hochgefährliche Alienbot-Rasse in Erscheinung tritt, ziehen Piper und Co. in den Kampf. Für Frieden, Freiheit, Gerechtigkeit, … Und natürlich auch für eine Handvoll Wasser. :-B

Die Story-Kampagne erstreckt sich über 3 große Weltraumkarten, jede davon weist zahlreiche Stationspunkte auf die mit Pipers Schiff zugesteuert werden können. Neben Bars und Shops als Einkaufsadresse für allerlei Waffen, Ausrüstungen und Hüte – letzteres ist in SteamWorld der allerletzte Mode-Schrei *zwinker-zwinker* – sind da eben auch jene Schiffe die es zu kapern, deren Mannschaft auszuschalten und die Beute einzusacken gilt. Zu Beginn ist die kampffähige Mannschaft einzig auf Piper und ihrem treuen Weggefährten/Matrosen Seabrass beschränkt. Diese vergrößert sich durch Anheuern weiterer Cowbots denen man ab und dann über den Weg läuft, ausreichend Ruf-Sterne vorausgesetzt. Ruf-Sterne verdient man sich nach jedem gemeistertem Level/Schiff, wobei jeweils ein Maximum von 3 Sternen - abhängig vom Erfolg - erreicht werden kann. Wer eine Level-Quote von 100% erreichen möchte muss dafür sorgen dass alle ausgewählten Besatzungsmitglieder die Mission überleben und ausnahmslos ALLES an vorhandener Schiffsbeute in seine Metallhosentaschen landet. Gleichzeitig ist ein hohes Ruf-Sterne-Konto unabdinglich, da der Zugang zu bestimmten Karten-Gebieten damit freigeschaltet werden möchte.
Die zufallsgenerierten Levels/Schiffe fallen in Größendimension und Schwere recht unterschiedlich aus, so variiert auch immer wieder die Anzahl an Charakteren die zum Einsatz kommen dürfen. Dabei hat man die freie Wahl zwischen Cowbots mit jeweils eigenem Fachgebiet wie Scharfschützen-Praxis, Erfahrung im Nahkampf oder Handling mit leichten oder schweren Waffen. Gemäß des Rundentaktik-Regelwerkes steht jeder Figur, ob nun auf Seiten des Spielers oder der CPU-Gegner, ein limitierter Bewegungs-Radius sowie eine Angriffsaktion pro Zug zur Verfügung, einschließlich individueller Sonderaktionen / Spezial-Fähigkeiten. Barrieren, Fässer und andere zerstörbare Objekte eignen sich als gute Deckung, ebenso bieten undurchdringbare Wände je nach Position entsprechenden Schutz vor gegnerischem Direktbeschuss.

Bezüglich der Gefechte muss erwähnt werden dass SWH anders funktioniert als übliche Rundentaktik-Spiele. Statt computerberechneter Wahrscheinlichkeit-/Zufallstreffer hängen Sieg und Niederlage von der eigenen Zielgenauigkeit ab.
Bei jedem seiner Cowbots muss der Spieler die Waffe manuell, also mit bloßem Auge auf den Feind ausrichten. Scharfschützengewehre/-pistolen mit Laserpointer-Aufsatz sind hier noch sehr hilfreich, bei allen anderen Waffen ohne Zielvorrichtung vertraut man einzig und allein seiner eigenen Fixiergenauigkeit. Desweiteren spielt auch die Art der Munition eine nicht minder wichtige Rolle; Kugeln und Laserschüsse können an Wänden abprallen und bei Beachtung des Einschusswinkels eine Flugbahn annehmen die selbst dann Treffer ermöglichen wenn ein Gegner kein ideales Frontal-Ziel abgibt, Granaten und andere explosive Geschosse dagegen schießen in gekrümmten Bahnen heraus und sind darum auch wesentlich ungenauer auf einzelne Gegner anzuvisieren, verursachen dafür aber mehr Flächenschaden.
Geht man siegreich aus einer Mission hervor sammelt jeder eingesetzte Charakter Erfahrungspunkte, mit Aufstieg zur nächsten EP-Stufe bekommt dieser außerdem eine neue Spezial-Fähigkeit spendiert. Auf die Arten der Fähigkeit hat man allerdings keinen Einfluss, da die Rangfolge ihrer Freischaltung fest vorgeschrieben ist.
SWH und sein Gameplay sind einfach und schnell zu verstehen, aber auch herausfordernd, jedoch nie unfair. Und sollte es mal nicht zu vollen 100% bzw. 3 Ruf-Sternen reichen ist es immer wieder möglich den betreffenden Level zu wiederholen. Auch der Umfang kann sich sehen lassen, für den Abschluss der Story im mittlerem von insgesamt 5 Schwierigkeitsgraden und kompletter Ruf-Stern-Anhäufung hab ich gut 24 Stunden gebraucht. Für nen kleinen Indie-Titel ist das schon ne ganze Menge.

Wie es die Einleitung bereits verriet haben Image& Form Games das sympathische SteamWorld-Artwork aus SWD beibehalten, diesen aber aufgrund des Genre-Wechsels ein wenig angepasst. Piper und Co. wirken etwas „erwachsener“, weniger knuffig-süß wie Rusty (dessen Sekunden-Gastauftritt man kurz erhaschen kann) und die ganzen anderen SWD-Figuren, die Schiffe und ihre toll animierten Innenräume haben ein leicht düsteres Ambiente, doch ansonsten hat es die typisch-heitere Aufmachung und die gewohnte knallbunte Farbgebung. Der Sound während der Gefechte hat ordentlich Wumms und die witzige wie multilingual untertitelte Fantasie-Roboter-Sprache passt wunderbar zum Szenario. Am meisten aber noch gefällt die musikalische Untermalung des Ganzen:
Der Soundtrack ist fabelhaft gewählt und situativ jederzeit passend, und in Bars sowie nach abgeschlossenen Endboss-Kämpfen steuert die Band „Steam Powered Giraffe“ – ja, die heisst wirklich so :-B – unglaublich schmissige Songs bei, sowas würde man bei einem kleinen Titel wie SWH gar nicht vermuten. Selbst mit dem Wissen dass dieses Spiel von der EU (!) kofinanziert wurde.

Fazit:
Super-spaßige Rundentaktik-Action im audio-visuell bezaubernden Gewand und mit einem schönen Schuss Humor. Spielerherz, was willst du mehr? 
Also, liebe Leutz von Image&Form Games, wenn ihr das hier liest, seid versichert, egal was ihr jetzt und in Zukunft an neuen SteamWorld-Ablegern in der Mache habt… SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!!!!! :D

31707915.review:
This incredibly smart and stylish steampunk game is simply great! The steambotish art style is top notch. Although thereare just a few music tracks available (played at stations/bars/boss fight endings), they fit well well into the world and are a pleasure to listen to.

The tactical gameplay reminds me a little bit of Woms (as this is only one tactical turn-based game which I could play for hours ), each character is unique with its own set of skills and can have 1 weapon and 2 utility items. I found it very satisfying to try to fit  most suitable items to characters and to level those characters up in order to unlock their unique skills. It is also very important to create a great team by carefully considering each character traits.  I highly suggest to experiment and try to combine the best team with the best gear, but be carefull as your dream team might not be the best choice in every situation.

The level desing is randomly generated and it happend only once that I was put in a very very bad starting postion.  In some levels you need to complete the objectives within given number of turns and missing the deadline usually does not end in a game over but the threat level rises and the bad guys receive some backup in a form of more mobs or automated turrerts.

I am really just a newbie in tactical games but regardless of this I found the "experienced" difficulty to give me a nice  and fun challenge.

I do not simply play tactical turn based games, but when I do, they must be hellishly good and fun to play!

31680908.review: Such a great game.  I think I got this as part of one of Humble Bundle's offerings, though I'd quite happily pay the asking price.  The mechanics are so elegant, I'm amazed it's not be used before or since.  The turn-based squad tactics game translates perfectly from the top-down X-Com style to the side-on platformer. 31612286.review:
SteamWorld Heist è un titolo che si distacca completamente dal precedente "Steamworld Dig", che riscosse tempo fa un discreto successo. Questa volta ci sposteremo nell'ambito spaziale e lo scopo del gioco sarà quello di gestire un manipolo di soldati robots e, come in molti classici, sventare i piani dei malvagi di turno per diventare così da ricercati (in quanto trattasi di pirati spaziali) ad eroi dell'universo.

TRAMA
La trama è semplice e lineare, rappresentabile come un segmento che và da A a B. Dovremo infatti compiere varie missioni attraverso le quali ricaveremo informazioni e metteremo i bastoni tra le ruote ai nostri antagonisti, fino ad affrontarli nelle varie boss fight. 

GAMEPLAY
Ci troviamo di fronte a un gioco tattico a turni 2D. I personaggi saranno disposti sulle navi che andremo ad assaltare su più piani, dovremo tenere conto della pavimentazione, di barili esplosivi e di ogni possibile ostacolo.
Lo scopo delle missioni può variare di volta in volta : alle volte dovremo sopravvivere un determinato numero di turni, altre volte dovremo prendere dei dati, altre ancora sterminare tutti i nemici all'interno del veicolo volante.
Il numero di robots utilizzabili varierà da uno a quattro a seconda del tipo di missione.
Mossa interessante la possibilità di far rimbalzare i proiettili per poter raggiungere un nemico all'apparenza in copertura.
Ho anche apprezzato tantissimo la caratterizzazione a livello di design ma sopratutto sul piano di gioco del nostro squadrone. Ogni personaggio utilizzabile infatti (molti di essi si aggiungeranno al team nel corso del viaggio) dispone di abilità esclusive e ognuno è specializzato in diverse categorie di armi. Questo spingerà il giocatore a provarli un po' tutti e ad utilizzarne alcuni in un certo tipo di missione piuttosto che altri.Nessuno verrà trascurato insomma [spoiler]o almeno non completamente[/spoiler].

TIRANDO LE SOMME
+ Gameplay : Intuitivo, facile, divertente
+ Musiche : Le canzoni sono fantastiche ! presenti nei vari bar spaziali e al termine delle boss fight le ho trovate molto divertenti e piene di energia ! Azzeccate in pieno alcune allo stile western/steampunk.
+Personaggi : Bel design, ben fatti e differenziati a livello di skills.
+Narrazione : La trama è quella che è, tuttavia lo stile narrativo è divertemente e scorrevole.
+Livello di difficoltà variabile: [u]E lo si sente eccome ![/u]

-Trama semplice e scontata 
-Il gioco è durato una decina di ore ma, vedendo la tipologia delle missioni, avrei voluto fosse un po' più lungo o che avesse un percorso più libero e meno lineare.
 
Dimenticavo un ultimo punto, lo metterei come neutrale : [b]CAPPELLI !! [/b] 
Tutti i robots avranno in testa dei [b]CAPPELLI[/b], dai più semplici ai più strambi. Inutile dire che saranno dei collezionabili e che saranno veramente tanti. L'idea non mi è dispiaciuta, ma avessero avuto un effetto secondario sul piano statistiche sarebbe stato un ottimo motivo in più per procurarceli. Così tanto per indossarli non mi dice tantissimo.

Concludo dicendo che ho gradito veramente tanto questo gioco. Se siete fan dei tactic games dovete giocarci assolutamente, tuttavia, dato lo stile colorato e lo stile narrativo vivace, mi sento di consigliarlo un po' a tutti.

-Al

31108889.review:
This is going to sound weird, but I'm totally serious. This game is a master class on turn based tactics. XCOM could learn a thing or two from these guys. I was on the fence because of the cartoony graphics, but I am SO glad I took the chance.

There are so many shortcuts that this team could have taken in the development of the game that they didn't take. Cover works the way you think it will. Enemies have realistic hit/miss ratios. Aiming is based on where you are, what kind of weapon you have, and your patience and skill (ARE YOU LISTENING, XCOM). Maps are not made difficult simply by throwing too many enemies at you.

The result is possibly the best-balanced turn-based tactical game I've ever played. This is coming from a huge fan of Fallout 2 and XCOM:EW. Before this game I honestly didn't know what people were talking about when they said "balance."

Worth every single penny. The only way it could be made better is a couch-gaming version, where my imaginary girlfriend and all my imaginary friends can play the different characters. Although all that would take is handing the controller over.

A+. Buy this game.

31026853.review:
This is a fantastic game, great squad-based tactics. It's basically a turn-based tactics game implemented in a 2D platformer. The manual aiming is a blast- when you pull of a remarkable shot, or miss what looked like a sure thing, it isn't because of some abstract dice roll, it's from your own aiming. Wish they had gone even further with that element even.

I saw some reviews say it's a bit short, but I wasn't dragging my feet and it took me ~20 hrs or so. It continues adding new wrinkles to the gameplay right to the end, so it never felt like a slog. A minor nitpick but I do think the node-based map for levels is a bit nonsense, seems odd to have a fixed map when care was obviously put into a procedural level system.

If you like tactics RPGs, then I think this a must play, since it's one of the most innovative entries to the genre in a good awhile.

31007560.review:
Image & Form yet again suprises me with SW: Heist, another game set in their very interesting steam powered robot world heist is a turn based strategy rpg that has many elements of other succesful games of the genre (Xcom movement system, Worms manually aiming your shots, etc) and the "sequel" to SW: Dig a very different game but very good as well. You play as Piper Faraday a han solo-like space captain and former gun for hire who leads her crew on a series of raids against an evil gang of thugs a corrupt military government and other factions to protect the less fortunate and do some looting in the process.

Pros
-Interesting world inhabited by interesting characters (Plot is a bit corny but still very good)
-Good difficulty, adds lots of replability and can be as forgiving or challenging as you want.
-Lots of content, each area has a good amount of missions and there is slight procedural generation so ship layouts and enemy placement will vary slightly with each play but you will see the same layout again.

Cons
-Small inventory space, even with a lot of the inventory upgrades you will constantly have to mull over what item you want to get rid of to make room for new items, weapons, abilities.
-On lower difficulties you'll have to xp farm older missions to level up after a certain point

Overall its a great game made by developers who deserve the recognition, I even bought it again on my 3ds because I liked it so much.

30973746.review:
Steamworld Dig was such a charming game, and I was very much looking forward to diving back into this world.

Steamworld Heist is obviously a very different game, but it retains the same spark. Great characters, sound and graphics, and a very smooth, polished playing experience. The soundtrack is great too.

It makes some compromises in complexity (this is not quite XCOM) but the simplicity is deceptive. I had to dial down the difficulty to Normal after failing to complete missions a little too often. There is not a lot of room for mistakes on the higher difficulty levels, but you can also change difficulty on a per mission basis, so it is quite versatile.

Character progression is very rigid. Your XP is spent automatically and you are awarded with new abilities and enhancements at a rate of one per level gained. There is no choices involved. It is still quite satisfying to acheive levels and try out new abilities and enjoy the breathing room that gaining some health points gives you.

Inventory management can be a bit of a pain, all objects are kept in a central pool and you can assign items from the pool before each job. Characters remember what they were equipped with last though, so you are not forced to redistribute items every time. It's a little different from normal RPG type games where each player has their own constant inventory. That being said, even if you have six steambots to choose from, you only need enough armor/weapons to equip the three or four that will be used in any given battle.

There is a good variety of weapon types and accessories. They make it very difficult to choose what your bots will bring with them (they each carry one weapon and have 2 'utility' spots that can be repair kits, armor (bonus to starting health), or accessory weapons like grenades). There are also other items that enhance your abilities but you can't bring it all with you each time. How I longed for one more carry space...

I seem to rely on a core team of bots that is successful most of the time, so I find myself backtracking and replaying older levels to farm XP for the other bots just to keep everyone in range of each other. Everyone has their speciality, and there is tradeoffs.

The missions generally involve retrieving water and other treasures, killing certain enemies, and getting out alive. It can be frustrating dealing with wave after wave of enemy reinforcements when you are trying to evacuate a ship, and have one of your bots get sniped just before making it out safely. Paying attention to the environment, the cover available and the enemy turret locations can mean the difference between life and death. 

The game is not long (15-20 hours apparently), but the ships are randomly generated so there is reasonable replayability. I have found myself going back in and trying different strategies on a few of them.  There is no manual save, it autosaves quite often and will tell you how long it's been since the last save when you try to quit (great touch). 

All in all, it's highly polished, charming, and makes it easy to get a quick fix or play a long session.  

Looking forward to Steamworld Dig 2!!!

Le gameplay est ultra facile à comprendre et maîtriser. Donc tout est dans le plaisir de jouer. Il dure plus longtemps que je pensais en plus. 30964127.review:
SteamWorld Heist is a refreshing take in the strategic combat field. Your steambot crew is led by captain Farraday into several tactical missions where you get to overcome enemy forces and collect loot -or as the game calls it, swag. The characters are likeable and have personality, which is something I particularly enjoyed.

Gameplaywise, it is similar to XCOM but in a 2D platformer fashion: you take cover, and get into position to shoot or brawl with enemy bots. There are quite a few different abilities available, some of which are also tied to a certain weapon group: assaulter, sniper and heavy being examples of them. Each character also expands their abilities automatically after every level up, 10 being the max level. There is an ardent collection of guns and items to loot or buy, as well as a cosmetic hat collection for the occasional completionist. 

Graphics are pretty and polished, gameplay is smooth (I have encountered no glitches or bugs in my completed game) and the difficulty is adjustable at any point in the game. Last but not least, the soundtrack was so enjoyable that it had me sitting idle in the occasional bar so I could enjoy the band playing in the background.

I absolutely recommend this game for anyone that even remotely likes tactical combat.

30846961.review:
A lot of people say that this game is like XCOM, but in 2D. It's not at all like XCOM. About the only similarities are turn-based squad combat with cover, but there are a lot of games that fit that description. For example, in XCOM your choices matter (if you aren't savescumming). In this game, your choices don't matter. The worst that happens if you botch a mission is that you lose some easily replaced money.

With that out of the way, I can say that this game is a lot of fun! The combat mechanics are simple but solid, and the enemy design is devious enough to present a challenge without being obnoxious. The three enemy races you fight are fairly similar, but different enough to prevent the game from getting repetitive. There are ten characters to recruit, each with their own abilities, and a whole lot of different items to find, which are mostly well-balanced. The sound and music were better than I expected, and the graphics are stylish.

The story is simple but well-delivered, and a playthrough where you try to recruit and level up everyone should take about 25 hours, maybe more if you go for maximum reputation. If you really want a challenge, the game keeps track of the total number of turns and losses, and your reputation, and scores you at the end of the game. Getting a top score requires beating every map with max reputation and no losses, and doing so in a minimum of turns (preventing you from grinding to overlevel). There's also a hat-collecting mechanic, where you can shoot hats off of enemies' heads and collect them for your crew to wear.

Overall, there's a lot to do and the game is both good and good value for the money.

30775482.review:
The second game in the SteamWorld series is, just like the first one, a ridiculous amount of fun.  SteamWorld Heist is a 2D strategy tactics game (Think X-COM, Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem, etc.).  You manage a group of characters, each with distinct abilities, in turn-based battles against a group of enemies, each with their own strenghts and weaknesses.  Manage your inventory and earn experience in order to customize your characters better to give them and edge on the battlefield.

Unlike the previously mentioned games, though, in which battles depend quite a bit on luck (look for the infamous picture of a soldier in X-COM having a shotgun pointed right at an alien's face with a 98% chance of hitting and still missing), battles here depend purely on skill.  Realistically, your characters hand don't stay completely still while aiming (though perhaps less realistically, considering they're robots), so it's up to you if they hit the target or not.  Also, some characters attack better from afar, others do more damage from the back, others can't attack after moving, and so on.  There's a lot of characters, abilities and weapons to juggle, and you can set your team as you like it, according to your preferred playstyle.  You're never forced to use a character you're not comfortable with if you have others at your disposal.

At times the game might infuriate you.  Most stages are randomly created through a procedural algorithm, and that means sometimes they'll be easier to handle (for instance, sometimes you might find a couple of small rooms with one or two enemies each and sometimes it'll be a large room where all congregate).  Losing or aborting a battle at most difficulties will make you lose half of your hard-earned cash.  On the plus side, re-entering the same stage might turn out to have it reconfigured on an easier way.  You might get angry and rage-quit the game at some point (I know I have), but a few minutes later you'll be drawn to the game again, because it IS that much fun.

The game includes a New Game+ option, which is always a nice thing.  Make no mistake, you will get lost in this game for days.

A: Act1のボスであるChop's Shopステージをクリアすると、そのステージの上にDLCキャラクターであるOutsiderがいる船が出現します。Outsiderと会話後に更に出現する船をクリア後、パワーエネルギーを彼に渡すことで仲間にできます。

Now I know I havn't had that much game time. Trust me from a veteran gamer. This game feels right.  Hearing the music it reminded me of an old game from many years ago called Hired Guns originally on the Amiga and later ported to PC and and the art style very reminicent of chaos engine from the old Amiga days it could actually be the same crew bitmap bros. 

You basically take a small team from your ship and board procedurally generated ships through side scrolling levels.

30698469.review:
[u]What I liked: [/u]
[list] 
    [*] Polished turned based tactics without hit chance
    [*] Superb folk rock music with great steampunk aesthetics
    [*] Great difficulty curve and progression of loot
[/list]
[u]What You Need to Know: [/u]
[list]
    [*]The game is most easily compared to XCOM in terms of gameplay, it’s a smaller game, so it’s not as expansive. Some might not like that, others will like it for cutting out all the padding and percentage hit chance (yea, no 99% misses) and bringing a polished game without anything to truly hate.
 
    [*]Let me say that the story isn’t something to remember. The gameplay is what matters here (Just like that XCOM game, ey?)

    [*]The setting is steam powered robots that you control, with mostly linear missions and some challenges occasionally. You get water as your currency to buy new gear, weapons, storage space, and recruit. 

    [*]There are about 5 classes with 2 for class having 2 robots you can recruit each with different overall abilities. This means that every character is unique and has a use and can offer lots of compositions. You level them all up to a max level. This can’t be done in one run. Towards the end, I stuck with the same 4 characters, hitting max level within the last hour of playing since I mixed it up a lot in throughout the game.

    [*]The abilities your characters get are great too, with every new level being a useful upgrade to your character. There is no percentages, just straight health, movement or damage increases; or new abilities (also improving said abilities). Combat is aimed manual by you, so no hit chance. It’s all your trick shots and skill. Love this neat mechanic


    [*]Your characters can only wield certain weapons. They are the typical gun styles, handguns, sharpshooter, heavy, assault. Lots of your projectiles ricochet, meaning a straight path isn’t always needed to hit your target. The progression of gear is great. After almost every mission you will find a new toy to use, or be able to go and buy one. This is good as the game will never get stale if you’re worried about that.


    [*]The difficulty is reasonable with 5 different choices, with the middle being perfect as it was good enough for me. You can even change it with every mission if you’re having a hard time. If you fail a mission you lose half of your currency. This might sound harsh, but you can replay any previous mission, so you can make it all back. The AI and enemy difficulty progression is great too, starting with basic enemies with no advanced weapons, gear or tactics. Toward the end you get enemies with shields, teleportation, bombs and charging weapons, and getting better at ricochet hits.

    [*]The music is perfect for the theme, having a rustic, folk rock sound, played by a steampunk band called Steam Powered Giraffe, with my favorite songs being “Brass Goggles” and “Honeybee” with more on the album for the game. Half of them are the band’s songs just repurposed for the game somehow. I would say a lot of them are good enough and since it has lyrics, some might enjoy them even more to listen outside the game. I know I’ll be getting some of these songs.

    [*] Overall the game is a shining example that a small team can make a unique turn based strategy game, fill it with charm and great music to fit the theme, giving a great experience that is cheap, short and not padded at all. This game was hard to find anything that some might hate or get annoyed by. With their previous game the robot voices were nowhere near as annoying. Great job on making a superb game. Can’t wait for more in the universe of SteamWorld.

 [/list]

[h1]My Score: [/h1]
[b]A+[/b]

[b]Paid: $7.50 [/b]
[b]Completed in: 11.5 hours[/b]

Games similar I recommend: 
[list]
    [*]RONIN
    [*]SteamWorld Dig
    [*]Xenonauts
    [*]Mark of the Ninja
    [*]Transistor

[/list]

30642803.review:
Between Steamworld Heist and Steamworld Dig the question remains, what can’t these Steambots do?

Take some Firefly, throw in some XCOM, and heaping helping of steampunk whimsy and you have got yourself Steamworld Heist. All ya need is a bot with a hammer for a penis and you got Captain Malcolm Reynolds. Pop culture references aside, Heist is a homage to westerns, just substitute horses with spaceships.

While the game does have an amazing opening sequence that sets the scene for you, I will do my best to explain the story. After the Earth exploded, bots began to mine moisture for survival. You play a rag tag group of outlaw steambots on the fringes of space. Dealing with gangs, Royalists and all sorts of seedy characters. The setting is simple but eloquent. You play the captain of one these outlaw gangs and some bots begin to muscle in on your territory. Thus the Firefly-esque adventure begins with you taking up the mantle of the common people and making off with some decent loot as a benefit.

If you’re unfamiliar with the universe of Steamworld, I highly recommend playing Steamworld Dig as that is a fantastic title all on its own. Aside from being an awesome action/platformer it also gives insights into why Earth explodes.

Steamworld Heist on the other hand does a dramatic pivot from its predecessor. Where you controlled a single bot and primarily worried about mining, this time you steal, shoot, and control a whole squad. It was definitely one of the things that impressed me with the developer Image & Form. Instead of sticking with what they knew and had already learned they decided to take the series in a whole other direction and genre. It takes some moxie for that kind of thing and hats off to them for pulling it off.
At its most simple, Heist is a turn based strategy game that puts you behind the gun.

Aiming is by far Heists defining feature and what makes it fun. Trick shots, bouncing grenades, and shooting your enemies hat off is the bread and butter of this game. It’s satisfying every time when you bounce your sniper round off five walls and hit a bot in the back of the head.

The way the mission structure works equates to a train robbery. You crew boards the enemy vessel with a given set of objectives, steal, plunder, kill, deactivate, the usual stuff. You go through compartments, collecting loot and dealing with the ships inhabitants. Usually you have to make a speedy exit via escape pod at the end of missions. Difficulty antes up with giving the enemy better guns, turrets and improving aim. The XCOM mechanic kicks in with tactical placements of your crew and a cover  mechanic. While flanking enemies is possible, it tends to be difficult as all levels are procedurally generated. Additionally there are also classes and abilities that are reminiscent of XCOM.

While there are not many buttons to worry, about the game does feature full controller support and comes recommended. Reason being is that the aiming mechanic can be a bit tricky especially if you don’t have a scope. Otherwise there isn’t too much to fuss with, you move your troops, fire, and use special abilities. Every character you have/recruit has their own unique class and weapon set. As you complete missions they gain experience which unlocks new abilities. Guns range from light pistols, shotguns, to heavy weapons like rocket launchers.
This mixing of classes and abilities makes every mission unique as most characters have their own way of approaching things.

Thankfully, all missions are repeatable and there are several different kinds of difficulty depending on your skill level. These raise the stakes when it comes to loot/XP but also increases the punishment for failure. Unlike XCOM though, you don’t lose your Steambots permanently but just lose water, the games currency.

Between heists you have the galaxy map that you use to fly around. Steamworld Heists limits content you can access either through the story or by a reputation system that is given in stars. It comes off feeling a little bit like a mobile game as certain missions cannot be done until you achieve a certain star count. As you unlock more areas you gain access to bars/shops that let you recruit new Steambots and buy weapons/accessories. All of these mechanics flow into each other very smoothly but the game isn’t spotless.

The only issue I found lies in inventory management. This can become quite a headache. Despite having a huge ship, you only are allowed to carry a limited number of items. Your storage can be expanded upon later in the game but I always felt like I was running behind on space. While all bots can share accessories/guns, you end up having quite a few unique weapons/items or double up cause you might want two of the same class on a mission. Thankfully you can sell items at any point in space but I just would’ve enjoyed a bit more freedom in this area. This is magnified and very frustrating at the end of missions constantly deciding what I wanted to keep and sell. Preventing progression in the game.

While I enjoyed Heist’s gameplay quite a bit it does become a bit repetitive eventually. Even though the game breaks things up with different objectives and a boss fight occasionally, you eventually end up in a slog of just upgrading guns/accessories. I wouldn’t say the game failed to my hold my attention but it didn’t sweep me off my feet. Unlike Steamworld Dig that I played obsessively until I beat it. I think Heist is best enjoyed causally and slowly.
What drew my attention and love about this game series is its style.

This is something that matches its predecessors and improves upon significantly. I am constantly surprised how well Robots and Western themes just blend together. Every Steambot has an incredible amount of personality to them. From the charming Piper, whose more heart then metal to background characters like bartenders and merchants. When I docked with the Saloon and found a steambot band playing some really awesome tunes, I couldn’t stop smiling. It’s little moments like these that enhances Steamworld. Enemies, allies alike all have their own unique style of ships, weapons, and detail abounds.

Obviously there aren’t rendered clouds to gawk at or 60FPS Cup o’ noodle but that doesn’t stop Steamworld from feeling like a thriving and fun universe. Things are the same when it comes to combat and more action oriented scenes. Lasers sizzle, bullets zing, and bots crunch or scatter into pieces when they die.

I have no fault with the visuals or sound department of Steamworld Heist. The music is great and I never got tired of it. There were plenty of times the music actually surprised with me a jaunty tune. It isn’t all that surprising that you can purchase the soundtrack as well. The sound effects all had their proper amount of gravitas to them and made the actions more visceral.

There is plenty to give the game quite a bit of replay value. Like I mentioned earlier there are many difficulty settings that keep things fresh if you find it too easy. The game does feature Steam Achievements and cards. There is also some additional DLC that adds more weapons, missions, and a new crew member. Depending on your skill level the game could take anywhere from ten to twenty hours of gameplay.
From a game development standpoint, It takes balls to try something completely new.

Most of the time you improve upon a formula and do the best at it to make more money. This was something completely unexpected and I appreciated Steamworld Heist for what it is. It’s fun, smooth, and well made. I hope this isn’t the last we see of the Steamworld universe and I can’t wait to see what the developer cooks up next. As for Heist, if you enjoy strategy games with a bit of a casual nature I recommend this title easily. Coming in at the indie standard of $14.99/£10.99 this is a safe bet, and downright steal during a sale.

เกม turn-based strategy (วางแผนแบบผลัดกันเดิน) ในมุมมอง 2 มิติ

โลกในเกมเป็นยุคของหุ่นยนต์ไอน้ำ ที่โลกถูกทำลายกระจายเป็นชิ้นๆ หุ่นยนต์ต้องไปอาศัยในอวกาศ
ตัวเอกของเรื่องเป็นกัปตันยานโจรสลัดที่ออกผจญภัย ต้องรวบรวมพวกพ้องต่อสู้กับพวกกลุ่มโจร และกองทัพ

ระบบการเล่นเป็นแบบผลัดกันเดิน โดยเลือกตัวละครสลับไปมาระหว่างตาเราได้อย่างอิสระ
ตัวละครแต่ละตัวจะมีความสามารถต่างๆ กันไป
- ตัวเอก เป็นสายสไนเปอร์ คอยส่องศัตรูด้วยปืนติดเลเซอร์ไกด์ แม่นยำ แต่ดาเมจน้อยหน่อย
- สายระเบิด ทำดาเมจได้มาก แต่ต้องระวัง เพราะถ้าเล็งไม่ดี มันจะย้อนกลับมาระเบิดตัวเองได้
-สายจู่โจม ทำดาเมจได้น้อย แต่ยิงได้หลายครั้ง มีสกิลฆ่าต่อเนื่องทำให้จัดการศัตรูมากๆได้ ใช้คู่กับสายระเบิด ได้ดี
-สายประชิด วิ่งเข้าใส่แล้วอัดด้วยหมัด เน้นพลังทำลาย และ HP สูง

แต่ละด่านจะมีจุดมุ่งหมายต่างกันไป ส่วนใหญ่ก็ให้เก็บของให้ครบ ทำลายเป้าหมาย 
เมื่อจบด่าน ก็จะได้น้ำ(ใช้แทนเงิน) มาสะสมไว้ซื้อไอเทมและปืนเพื่ออัพเกรดความสามารถของหุ่น

ตัวเกมทำมาได้ดี กราฟิกสวยงาม เพลงประกอบสนุก เพราะดี ได้บรรยากาศคาวบอยยุคอวกาศ
ความยากของเกมก็มีให้เลือกหลากหลาย ทั้งแบบ Casual เล่นแบบไม่เครียด ตายแล้วเล่นใหม่
กับแบบยากขึ้น เมื่อภารกิจล้มเหลว จะโดนหักเงิน ทำให้ต้องเล่นระมัดระวังกว่าเดิม
ด่านแต่ละด่านก็มีการสุ่ม ทำให้แบบแปลนไม่ค่อยซ้ำกัน ทำให้มันท้าทายและต้องคิดมากขึ้น 

ข้อเสีย  ด่านแต่ละด่านบางทีดูซ้ำซาก ภารกิจ ยังหลากหลายน้อยไปหน่อย

สรุป เป็นเกมที่สนุก น่าเล่นเกมนึง สายวางแผนผลัดกันเดินไม่ควรพลาด
เกมสนับสนุนจอยแพดเต็มรูปแบบ ใช้แล้วดูจะสะดวกกว่าคีย์บอร์ดกับเมาส์
9/10
