30548664.review:
I have been absolutely loving Steamworld Heist so far. It's a lightweight, tactical turn based game, with fun, humorous characters and interchangeable HATS! WHO DOESN'T ALWAYS LOVE HATS?!

But for reals, the gameplay is nice and easy to learn, and each character you recruit has their own skills. You'll find yourself likely favoring a few for certain missions and that's just fine.

The story and dialog are really quite great. I love listening to the banter between the robots on the ship, and find the overall story arch to be straightforward and not convoluted at all. It's a great experience to play.

And of course the art looks fantastic. It's clean, well represented and sylistic. It's visually fitting and the cohesive steampunk/robopunk style is a pleasure to look at. 

Absolutely recommend this game. Play a few levels at a time, and you'll have a solid experience.

30545652.review: Nice little gem. Like a 2D, simpler, lighthearted version of Xcom. Great value for the price too. My first playthrough lasted longer than a lot of full priced games, and it was fun the whole way through. Big props to the developers of this one for packing so much into an affordable package. I'll definitely be supporting them in the future.

30545056.review:
The game is one of these hidden gems you have in your library and get you hooked once you start playing it. Like many people you might have received it as part of a humble bundle and you should really start playing it. Steam World Heist is a 2D Turn Based Strategy game with a lot of humor, nice original soundtrack and graphics, and a western touch. It is a bit like playing XCOM in a platformer environment. Here, you have to aim properly it is not about probability to clear the ships full of different enemies that you accost. There are different types of mission and the evolution of your characters and the foes prevent the game from being boring.
Have fun collecting hats and water supplies!

30531208.review:
Fantastic side-scrolling turn-based shooter with beautifully drawn characters and environments.

The combat is challenging and fun, and the added RPG elements kept me coming back. Every mission, you assemble a team from the many unique crewmates you have recruited, and assign them weapons and equipment. Your arsenal expands as you collect "swag" and complete missions, which also reward you with experience – allowing your characters to level up and unlock new abilities – and gallons of water, which you use to buy more loot (and purely cosmetic hats).

While the story itself isn't deep, I did find it enjoyable, and the game has a much better length than its [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/playkareshi/recommended/252410]predecessor[/url]. I do recommend getting the [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/464840/]Outsider DLC[/url]; however, as the added content is scattered throughout the regular game, I suggest getting it upfront (unless you plan on doing a New Game+ playthrough).

SteamWorld Heist : Quand le RPG Tactics loufoque rencontre la 2D. 8/10 sur lesgrosjeuxdupc.fr
Retrouvez le test écrit sur : http://lesgrosjeuxdupc.fr/steamworld-heist/
Pour le test vidéo c’est ici : https://youtu.be/3AMX5icx35k

Résumé :
++ Le système de jeu RPG Tactics au tour par tour transposé en 2D.
++ Les membres de l’équipage ayant chacun ses aptitudes et son armement.
++ Les compétences originales gagnées à chaque Level-Up.
++ L’univers déjanté.
++ Les personnages décalés avec le sens de l’humour.
++ Des ennemis et des univers variés.
++ Graphiquement très beau.
++ Les musiques Folk-Rock incroyables composées par les Steam Powered Giraffe.
+   La Replay Value
+   Collectionner de jolis chapeaux….

-    … Mais bordel, à quoi servent ces foutus chapeaux ? ^^
-    L’armement peu varié.
-    La maniabilité parfois imprécise.   
--   On a envie d’en savoir plus sur les personnages (manque de profondeur).

Simple, efficace, soigné dans sa réalisation, original dans son character design avec une atmosphère renforcée par une bande son de qualité, on devine que les développeurs de Image & Form ont pris soin de leur bébé (pirate). SteamWorld Heist est un excellent jeu à recommander pour tous les amateurs (et les autres) de RPG Tactics au tour par tour.

30491276.review: If anything about this game's central premise tickles your gaming bones then I urge you to pick up on the grounds that it pulls off it core gameplay so well. The actual mechanical strategy in this game is fairly minimal, but the skill-based aiming is integrated so well that it's novelty outshines anything else. Once you accept the game's modest scale and pull off a few sweet trick shots you'll be hooked. It's got an imaginative setting and cool art-style, even a handful of original songs. The story isn't bad, but is generally only ever told through a barrage of text bubbles between characters that will likely only hold the attention of the super-invested.

Es muy bueno.

Quien haya jugado el juego anterior del estudio, «Steamworld Dig», se va a encontrar aproximadamente lo mismo, en cuanto al estilo artístico, la música, el humor y la escala, quizá un poco expandido en ambición y cuidado.
Le saca muchísimo a sus limitantes, y no parece una obra menor, sino centrada y que juega bien sus cartas.

Eso sí, donde «Dig» es un metroidvania bien conseguido, «Heist» cambia totalmente de registro. El planteamiento es similar al de «XCOM», tactica por turnos, donde controlas a un pequeño equipo de élite en misiones de abordaje y asalto. Cada miembro tiene capacidades especiales únicas y en saber combinar tus unidades y, obviamente, ejecutar tus turnos con éxito, es donde radica el reto y el gancho.

Los personajes son únicos en ese sentido, y conforme se van subiendo niveles van surgiendo subespecializaciones. Por ejemplo, Piper, la «steambot» protagonista, es francotiradora; y durante el juego aparece otro par de ellos, Valentine y Dora. Pero no son iguales; Piper es más apta para la movilidad y los remates, Valentine brilla como fracotirador estático de alto daño, y Dora luce más en ataque por la retaguardia. Al final, cada miembro del equipo es único y se preferirán las habilidades de alguno sobre otro áun cuando compartan clase. A eso, hay que sumar la elección de armas y complementos que puede traer cada «steambot», para personalizarlos y distinguirlos aún más.

El juego no tiene más profundidad que esa, aunque no es poca. Presenta bastantes variables y aunque hay muchas misiones de «ve y mata a todo» donde se reptien muchos personajes y muchas situaciones, también hay otras que por limitantes de turnos, alarmas, clase de enemigos, nuevas características del entorno u objetivos diferentes, requieren plantearse de una manera nueva cada vez.

En fin, muy amoroso y excelentemente diseñado y balanceado. Lo único que se puede decir malo es que se hace corto y dan ganas de ver realizado algo de este estudio a una escala mayor.

30397168.review:
SteamWorld Heist provides an approachable take on the turn-based tactics genre; it's a fun, fast-paced game that offers a lot of room for creative tactics and solutions to problems. The difficulty scales pretty extremely, and can be adjusted before each and every mission, so players unused to the genre need not fear getting overwhelmed; likewise, XCOM veterans will find the game plays off of their experience quite well (though it emphasizes action-economy far less, and cover/position far more) and can crank the difficulty up accordingly.

It's got a unique aesthetic, an interesting storyline (which ties in dramatically with Steamworld Dig before it) that manages to entice the player without getting in the way, and several amusing dialogues and characters. While there isn't much about the game's story and dialogue that is likely to stick with the player long after they finish, Heist creates a distinct, memorable atmosphere that will likely make it the object of comparison for other games in the genre for a long time to come.

Overall, it's worth playing both for the mind-bending take on tactics, and for the stick-with-you memories and impressions it creates.

Muy buen juego. El título es un juego táctico por turnos, donde controlas a unos robots y le disparas a cosas... digamos que es como un XCOM pero en perspectiva 2D. 

El objetivo del juego es ir avanzando por los escenarios, desarrollando la historia, mejorando tus personajes (que ganan niveles y nuevas habilidades), mejorando tus armas, loot-ear y decorar a tus robots con sombretiros.

Buen apartado sonoro, buena música, buen apartado gráfico. Tres campañas de aproximadamente 5 horas cada uno lo que le da una longevidad del juego de 15 horas... puede tomar un par de horas más si tratas de terminarlo al 100%, y muchas horas más si tratas de hacer todos los logros.

Molestias? Las batallas con los jefes pueden ser algo tediosas debido a que el juego tiene una mécanica de hordas infinitas. Si no te das prisa, te empiezan a salir hordas de enemigos que hacen que la partida se vuelva más díficil con cada turno. Los jefes tienen montones de salud lo que hace que sean demorados matarlos, y con la mécanica de hordas hace que se vuelva un poco más demorado. 

El juego puede requerir algo de grinding o repetición de misiones para hacer más fácil las cosas. Afortundamente no es excesivo y te permite probar otros heroes para conocerlos y subirles de nivel.

8.5/10

Heist ist quasi das 2D-XCOM für alle rundenbasierten Action-RPG-Fans dieser Zeit. Mit der gleichen grafischen Detailverliebtheit geht's hier von Mission zu Mission auf verschiedene Raumschiffe und Basen, deren Räume immer zufallsgeneriert sind und im Laufe der Mission aufgedeckt werden. Dabei findet das Kampfgeschehen immer in den bereits aufgedeckten Räumen statt - es lohnt sich also alle Crew-Mitglieder vor den Räumen zu platzieren, bevor man weiter rückt und weitere Feinde triggert. Hinzu kommt ein Alarmstufen-Countdown-System, was in vielen Missionen bei 0 weitere Schwierigkeiten mit sich bringt (neue Feinde, aktivierte Geschütze, usw). Hinzu kommt ein unheimlich gut funktionierendes Kampfsystem mit kauf-, find- und ausrüstbaren neuen Waffen oder Aktiv- sowie Passiv-Effekt-Equipment, ne Menge rekrutierbare Crew-Mitglieder und unterschiedliche Feinde. 30321132.review:
An excellent 2D turn-based strategy game.

The store description covers it: Steamworld Heist is a Worms and XCOM hybrid. Characters move and act much like XCOM soldiers, but on a 2D plane with a messload of steampunk robots. There's no base building or anything like that, however. There are various levels of difficulty, and it can be changed mid-game, so it's not quite as unforgiving as XCOM can be.

There's some RPG lite mechanics intertwined through this, with loot and experience driving the progression of your crew. Missions take place on ships with (more often than not) randomized layouts, and each mission has various objectives and enemy assortments. Usually you'll be taking two or three robots on a mission, but occasionally you will limited to one or be allowed to bring four. Unlike XCOM, when your characters die, they only forfeit any earned experience for the level.

Normal gameplay revolves around your crew's turn alternating with the enemy. Enemy ranks are usually dolled out slowly by opening ship doors or setting off alarms. Combat is straight forward: you aim your gun at the enemy and fire. Neither you or your enemies can dodge attacks normally, so taking cover is the only defense (aside from HP increasing items, anyway). Weapons don't tend to have laser sights unless they are "marksmen" style weapons, but lining up a shot isn't difficult at short or medium ranges. Most bullets and projectiles bounce, allowing you to make trick shots that bounce around cover or around corners.

All the different crew members have a different assortment of abilities, with some crossover skills between some characters, leaving a rather well-rounded group. None of the characters are useless, though some are better suited for mobility or taking hits. Each crew member can be utilize a weapon (most characters are proficient with one or two types of guns), two accessories and a hat, which is cosmetic. Weapons, accessories and currency are found by picking up loot items in the levels that are placed at the start. Hats are either purchased from some shops, or stolen from enemies by grazing their heads with a projectile. Enemies do not drop loot, nor do they give experience when killed, so farming kills is only useful for farming rare hats.

In between the combat, players use a map to pick missions or go to hubs/shops. It's sort of like Super Mario World, where you have to complete levels in order to progress down paths on the map. These hubs are mostly for story, hiring crew members and buying hats and equipment.

The game offers a new game plus mode that allows you to use any characters at the start of the game at the cost of all your equipment and experience. There's DLC that adds a new character, some missions and some hats, and those are peppered throughout the game (and are equally excellent). You can easily spend as little as 10 hours but as many as 30 on a playthrough, depending on how thorough you are.

The game's got a really snazzy art style that looks beautiful at high frame rates, and there's a subtle parallax effect on all the environments that's really neat to look at. The writing is pretty funny at times and not particularly verbose. For reference: there is no voice acting in the game, but it's not really needed anyway.

I kind of felt bad for getting this in a bundle, because $15 for a game like this is way more than fair.

30298068.review:
This is an outstanding little puzzle game that lets you take your time going from map to map in a Worms-style shoot-out with a variety of bad-guy robots.  There's a great deal of flexibility in how you outfit your team, and you can repeat maps until you get all three stars -- the only penalty is that you lose (about) half of your water, which is the in-game currency, when you lose a map.  It's honestly not a huge penalty, since (a)you're usually spending as much water as you can between maps, to get all those nifty upgrades, and (b)if you hit a very-hard map, the penalty decreases with each failure to complete.

There's a funny obsession with hats in this game, which has nothing to do with game mechanics but does affect your achievements.  You can have your hat shot off, or you can shoot your enemies' off their heads...there is no tactical significance to it, but it adds flavor to this game that is charmingly fully fleshed out.

If you can get this as part of your Humble Bundle (I did), or if you can get it on sale, by all means, get this game.  You can play for 5 minutes, or for 2 hours at a time...you can play one map over and over again, to build up resources, or you can zip through them to unravel the story...I love puzzle games (like chess puzzles), I love tactical games (like X-Com's ground combat) and this one just fits right in.  It surprised me how engaging it is.  Try it, you won't be sorry!

30278397.review:
Steamworld Heist è uno strategico a turni ambientato nello spazio in un lontano futuro che mette il giocatore nei panni di un gruppo di steambot pirati capitanati dal capitano  Faraday. Lo scopo del gioco è semplice; bisogna reclutare nuovi steambot e razziare il più possibile le astronavi nemiche aumentando il proprio bottino che sarà di aiuto soprattutto nelle missioni contro determinati boss. Il gioco segue lo stile classico dei giochi strategici a turni, ovvero la possibilità di muoveri entro  un certo limite di caselle ed eseguire azione come sparare, trovarsi una copertura ecc durante il proprio turno. Le due caratteristiche che però lo differenziano dai classici del genere è la scelta di adottare il 2D e il sistema di combattimento. Quest'ultimo Infatti nella maggior parte dei giochi la traiettoria dei proiettili e la possibiltà di successo di un attacco sono gestiti in automatico in base alle caratteristiche dei personaggi, in Steamworld Heist invece è il giocatore a mirare e dunque a decretare il successo di una determinata azione.Il gioco presenta anche una piccola parte manageriale che ci servirà a gestire l'equipaggiamento degli steambot prima di ogni missione.Proprio l'equipaggiamento è vitale per aumentare le possibilità di sopravvivenza ed è possibile raccoglierlo tramite i vari bottini presenti nelle missioni o comprare armi nuove e accessori nei bar spaziali  con la valuta di gioco (l'acqua).Ultimo elemento sono i cappelli,hanno un fine esclusivamente estetico ma sarà molto divertente cercare di raccoglierli tutti ed equipaggiarli sui propri steambot.
Tirando le somme SteamWorld Heist è un gioco che anche se si rifà ai classici del genere sa essere molto innovativo grazie ad un combat system solido e divertente, una componente gestionale ben riuscita e ad un'ottima soundtrack. Unica pecca è la trama che sembra essere messa li solo come contorno. Voto 8.8

30254166.review:
Well this one came at me totally by surprise. I got it bundled in the most recent Humble Monthly, which I had picked up pretty much for X-COM 2 alone. But once I poked at this one curiously, I kept at it until I had completely finished. 

Speaking of X-COM, a comparison is fitting. With a lot of similar rules, you can apply some of the very same strategies here as you do there. Shooting or sprinting ends your turn, but you can move once then shoot. Full cover is better than half cover. Enemies get a free turn to move once they see you. And so on. 

Unlike the X-COM games though, numbers will never make you miss. With manual aiming for all shots you take, you only miss through your own bad aim or positioning. A lot of weapons can ricochet off walls and cover to pull off some fancy trick shots if you line it up right, too. Which feels pretty awesome to get right. For the most part, when enemies can hit you they will, though their aim seems to have a bit of randomness to it, meaning you can get lucky misses or unlucky hits from afar. 

Also unlike X-COM, there's no overarching doom timer pressuring you to beat the game fast enough. Nor are there save slots - it autosaves every few turns, so mistakes stick with you. Thankfully, the only penalty for party member loss is lost XP, or lost money if you lose them all in one mission. You're also allowed to grind completed missions for money and XP if you're having trouble, but it's not necessary to win. 

There are numerous party members to recruit, each with their own class, skills, and preferred weapon types. You don't get to make your own characters, but there's customization in the form of gear. And hats. Piper and her crew are a likeable enough bunch of robotic rogues to push me through to the end, though the plot's fairly straightforward 'fight the bad guys' kind of stuff. It lacks voice acting, but that's fine in my book. 

It was a good challenge at the middle difficulty, called "experienced", but rarely frustrating. Bosses can seem like huge difficulty spikes at first, but didn't usually take me more than two tries to get right without any losses. 

The soundtrack is also enjoyable, especially since bosses get their own "boss defeated!" victory song thanks to nerdy band Steam Powered Giraffe. Who I've only recently discovered and I love the dorks. Combat music on the other hand can get repetitive, but that's a minor flaw. 

I can't think of much to complain about here. It's a charming game with style. It has a good idea to add to the turn-based strategy formula. It feels and sounds good. There's plenty of content, but it doesn't overstay its welcome or require you to grind. It's challenging, but not unfair. And it gets +1 over X-COM if you hate RNG-based games, given it's more about skill and timing than numbers. 

Great stuff that deserves your attention all on its own. Not just another bundle game. I might even play through it again sometime.

30203553.review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]
SteamWorld Heist is a 2d turn based XCOM-like game, taking place in a universe inhabited by robots. You control a small team of so-called steambots with unique abilities, in small, tactical confrontations against enemy bots, where you have to kill the opposition, grab the loot, and get out. 

[h1] Story [/h1]
There is a story present here, but it is rather underplayed and not the main focus of the game. You're essentially just finding new opposition with every chapter, and the script focuses on what you're doing to muck up their plans/steal their stuff. There is some enjoyment to be had with the story, but don't buy it if that's the only thing you're interested in. 

[h1] Presentation [/h1]
The presentation on display is really damn impressive considering this is a game originating from the 3DS. The game runs gracefully out of the box, and supports 60+ herz framerates without any tinkering in the cfg. files whatsoever. This is genuinely more impressive than a lot of triple A games that I've played. And don't get me started on the graphics. The 2d art here is brimming with detail and, just, pure effort. Every pipe, valve and rusty backdrop has been gracefully drawn, and are beautifully colored. Animations are superb as well.

[h1] Gameplay	[/h1]
As mentioned, this is a turn based strategy game, rather similar to XCOM. You are given a set distance you can move with a character; move a short distance and you can fire your gun afterwards, but if you move further, you will need to fold until the next turn. However, where Heist differs, is with its ditching of certain chance-based actions common in other strategy games. One example being aiming and shooting, which is done manually by using the mouse/joystick. This eliminates lots of frustration, as most deaths are your own fault, because of your poor aim. Attacking like this is incredibly entertaining, especially since you can bounce bullets off of walls, resulting in some awesome trickshots. 

In addition to this extra layer of gameplay, you have access to a set of teammates you can bring with you on a heist. They can specialize in heavy weapons, sniping, punching, and my personal favorite, flanking. You need to play around these quirks and use positions wisely, like placing the heavy on a top floor, or placing the flanker far ahead, as to make it easier to get behind the enemy and deal extra damage. The gameplay is deep, but simple and easy to learn. And most importantly, the game is fun, incredibly so. Hitting next to impossible shots, blowubg up 3 guys next to an explosive barrel, or figuring out new strategies or abilities is extraordinarily rewarding and entertaining. 


[h1] Flaws [/h1]  
There's an inventory system present here, deciding how many weapons/items you can have a hold of at any-one time. The problem is that it's incredibly harsh in terms of space, only allowing a very small amount of items to be stored. You can upgrade the availible space, but they get exponentially more expensive with every purchase. Deleting items almost after every mission got a little tedious and annoying. 

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
This is a criminally underrated game, considering the overwhelming quality and effort present here. I plead you to give this game a try, even if you're new to turn-based games. 30064466.review:
Prendiamo una pentola per cottura [i]a vapore[/i]. Buttiamoci dentro un po' di XCom, un po' di Worms e una spolveratina di un qualsiasi RPG a sviluppo lineare. Mentre cuoce a fuoco lento mettiamo su un bel CD degli "Steam Powered Giraffe" (cercateli su Youtube: potrebbero piacervi) o qualche puntata di [i]Firefly[/i]. Dopo un paio d'ore... voilat! Steamworld Heist è servito.

[h1]IL GIOCO[/h1]
La piccola tramettina dei Cowbot pirati-spaziali e i simpatici dialoghi tra personaggi fanno da contorno a uno strategico steam-punk che è più profondo di quanto non sembri, ma per rendersene conto è necessario alzare il livello di difficoltà ed allenarsi con la pistola.
Gli incarichi d'affrontare sono montati in una struttura ad albero e si alternano a negozi d'armi, cappellifici e bar (in cui troveremo immancabilmente gli Steam Powered Giraffe in concerto, con una canzone diversa per ogni location).
La mappa di ogni missione è random, diversa ogni volta che ci giocate, ma l'obiettivo rimarrà inalterato: recuperare un tesoro, distruggere un generatore, eliminare un nemico o persino un Boss. 
Scelta la difficoltà e i personaggi che prenderanno parte al colpo (ciascuno dotato di propri poteri, dati fisici e abilità), li si potrà armare ad arte per poi buttarsi nella mischia. Gli scontri sono a turni: prima i vostri robot e poi il nemico. Ogni turno è alla XCom: ogni personaggio ha due azioni, una di movimento e l'altra di attacco o ancora movimento. La peculiarità sta nel fatto che la mira non è automatica, e come nella serie di Worms, avere una buona mira è importante quanto essere strategici nei movimenti.
Se la missione sarà superata con successo ogni Cowbot sopravvissuto avrà dei punti esperienza utili per salire di livello, sbloccare abilità o migliorare i propri dati. Quello che invece guadagnerete voi sarà un certo voto in stelle, che andrà ad aumentare la vostra celebrità in quella zona della galassia. Maggiore la celebrità, maggiore la quantità di armi e oggetti che potrete comprare nei negozi grazie ai tesori e al denaro trovato. Occhio però a non finire lo spazio nell'inventario! Saperlo gestire è molto importante ed è buona norma tentare di ampliarlo non appena se ne ha l'occasione.
E se la missione va male? Scatta la punizione (a patto di giocare almeno a difficoltà normale): perderete metà dei vostri soldi per ricostruire i soldati distrutti. Ma non disperate: quando sarete sul lastrico vi verranno ricostruiti gratuitamente.
E poi ci sono i cappelli...
Il vezzo di ogni cowbot è il suo cappello. Potrete comprare cappelli in giro per il cosmo, ma anche sparare a quelli che portano i nemici per poi raccoglierli e aggiungerli alla vostra collezione. I cappelli non fanno niente! Non migliorano nulla né fanno guadagnare poteri. Sono solo cappelli... ma MOLTO alla moda e altamente collezionabili. ;-)

[h1]SÌ, OK, MA IN SOLDONI?[/h1]
Come ho detto, Steamworld Heist è semplice in superficie, ma assolutamente impegnativo non appena si decide di aumentare la difficoltà. Qualcuno può criticare la linearità nello sviluppo dei personaggi, ma il più delle volte la libertà negli RPG è fittizia: nelle varie situazioni la scelta più logica è una sola. I game designer ci accecano con gli specchietti del "libero arbitrio" e il più delle volte la fanno franca.
Qui non ci sono specchietti. Vuoi per ampliare il target e non intimorire i neofiti, vuoi per arrivare al sodo della strategia, ogni eroe sblocca un'abilità specifica al level-up, ed è il loro accoppiamento nelle missioni nonché la nostra abilità nello sfruttare quello che abbiamo ciò che fa la differenza. Una missione difficile può diventare semplicissima se si scelgono i giusti Cowbot con i giusti poteri e li si rifornisce con i giusti ammennicoli. Il grinding è quindi IMMANCABILE se vogliamo vincere e la randomizzazione delle missioni gioca a nostro favore (e contro la noia).
Riguardo il perdere metà del nostro gruzzoletto al fallimento di missione, è un sistema per far girare l'economia: spendendo si perderanno meno soldi al fallimento (mi piace vedere il bicchiere mezzo pieno). ;-)

Da parte mia Steamworld Heist è un gioco assolutamente consigliato, a patto di abbracciare la sua apparente semplicità come un trampolino per le difficoltà più alte e le strategie più fini. PREPARE FOR BOARDING!!!

[h1]NEWGAME+ NOTA BENE![/h1]
Dopo la fine del gioco, sulla mappa apparirà un "buco nero" che vi permetterà di iniziare una nuova partita da zero alla difficoltà che preferite. Verrà azzerata qualsiasi cosa, tranne i cappelli raccolti, e sulla nave ci saranno già tutti i personaggi che avete sbloccato. Swaaag!

29946559.review:
SteamWorld Heist - это космическое приключение с пошаговыми битвами, густо замешанное на «Светлячке» (Firefly) Джосса Уидона и стимпанке собственного розлива. Собственно мир, в котором проиходят все события игры, тот же самый, что и в предыдущей игре студии - SteamWorld Dig - только на несколько столетий позже. Вообще всю игру можно рассматривать как продолжение работы на SWD: всё, абсолютно всё стало лучше, больше, детализованее, вкуснее, интереснее и красивее. Однако это было бы упрощением и умолчанием истинных достоинств игры, особенно для тех кто в SWD никогда не играл.

Во-первых, это расширенная и углубленная вселенная паровых роботов, которая обросла интересными деталями окружающего мира, добавив очень жизненной глубины и интереса происходящему. Надеюсь авторы продолжать работу в данном направлении и когда-нибудь мы увидим если не 4X-стратегию, то хотя бы RPG по мотивам.

Во-вторых, сплошная и грамотная эксплуатация тематики Firefly. Собственно даже за небольшие отсылки к данному сериалу игру стоило бы как минимум похвалить, но авторы решили сделать своё собственное приключение космических ковбоев (ковботов), сумев выдержать качество до самого конца истории.

В-третьих, игра потрясающе выглядит и отлично звучит. Стимпанк у авторов изначально свой: там всё чистое и красочное. Но здесь оно еще снабжено массой мелких интересных деталей. Каждый космический бар вызывает интереса пожалуй больше, чем выделенная авторами функциональная нагрузка: к сожалению ни выпить, ни поговорить с посетителями (кроме некоторых исключений), ни подраться там нельзя. Отлично задекорированы и уровни во всех трех зонах игры, особенно сюжетные локации.

За музыку (вернее - песни!) отвечает группа Steam Powered Giraffe, и тут комментировать бессмысленно - нужно слушать, очень желательно в игре, а не отдельно. Фольк-рок с небольшим уклоном в кантри моментально погружает в атмосферу приключения космических ковбоев в захолустном звездном баре. Исполнено настолько душевно, что я переигрывал битву с Красной Королевой только ради залихватской песни в конце.

И вот мы накнец добрались до самой мякотки: системы пошаговых боев, среди которых и проходят 8-10 часов игры - именно столько нужно для прохождения кампании со всеми дополнительными заданиями в зависимости от выбранной сложности и вашей сообразительности. Боевка устроена достаточно просто, но интересно. Четыре основных типа оружия + рукопашный бой. Нюансы добавляются через способности персонажей и свойства уникального оружия, а также через носимые предметы - по 2 на каждого персонажа. Даже после 100 часов игры механика не перестает радовать благодаря системе рикошетов и замедления времени при убийствах: эффективно применяется и эффектно выглядит. Единственно что не хватает полной прорисовки траектории для гранатометов (для носимых гранат она есть).

Настоятельно рекомендую играть вместе с DLC «Чужак» (The Outsider): оно не только добавляет уникального персонажа с неповторимыми умениями, но также и оружие, предметы, а также задания на протяжении всей кампании. Кроме того, при использовании персонажа в бою появляются несколько уникальных диалогов.

В игре есть шапки, десятки шапок. Выполняют исключительно декоративную функцию, можно не использовать вообще, а можно всех нарядить в краснознаменные ушанки.

Итого: смело брать всех фанатам жанра пошаговой тактики, а также тем, кому понравилась SteamWorld Dig.
SteamWorld Heist строится на тех же принципах: за практически казуальной оболочкой скрывается увлекательная механика.

29927970.review:
Got this game in a Humble Monthly bundle, never heard of it before and was very pleasantly suprised.
+ Nice art style with attention to details
+ Surprisingly deep strategic elements for this rather simple gameplay 
+ Nice characters, funny dialogue and story
+ Proves superiority of steam power over diesel and even electrical power. Why don't we use that anymore...space travel is so much simpler with steam power
+ Dozens of hats!!!

- Can get a bit repetitive when grinding for water or XP
- Small balancing issues:
-> Some characters are way stronger than others due to their abilities, especially late game
-> Assault weapons like shotguns and smgs are useless most of the time. They do the same max damage as pistols of the same tier, but spread a lot. So if you manage to shoot someone point blank and all pellets hit, you do the same damage as when you hit with one pistol bullet, which is far superior in accuracy
-> A few levels in midgame are way more difficult then the whole rest of the game, including the endboss

Overall you should get around 15-20 hours of fun out of this, more if you do not mind the repetitiveness and want to try the higher difficulties.

29903857.review:
Good morning, crew! On board this spaceship, we will experience an epic adventure full of twists, in a real war with robots and space cowbots. Are you ready for a memorable adventure?

In SteamWorld Heist we control Captain Piper, who will travel the stars to save his race of steam-powered robots. During the journey the player loot and perform various types of missions, which are focused on battles. In the meantime you will also need to recruit teammates to fight alongside you and manage the gear of your crew. While In the bars, which are one of the places where we improve weapons, items and recruit warriors, you can also find the Steam Powered Giraffe band playing. This group is responsible for all the soundtrack of the game - a soundtrack of the best quality, by the way, with both cheerful and intimist songs.

The game is very similar to XCOM, as far as tactical gameplay is concerned, as well as the movement system, which allows us to walk a stretch to then shoot (or use a skill) or sprint without extra actions. But, unlike XCOM, we are not in the hands of the Random Number Generator (RNG), that is, the chance to miss or hit a shot is totally in the hands of the player. Some weapons have bouncing bullets, as well as grenades and other devices, which gives a Worms climate. Like Worms, it is possible to achieve unexpected and surprising results that go beyond targeting straight, which makes performance on the artillery part critical to success.

The world of SteamWorld Heist is divided into three parts, which are three large maps with various missions within them. The first part is the worst of all, with little variety in the missions, a lot of repetition and some unfair enemies for the beginning of the game, like a giant robot with an armored shield. This may discourage you a little, but if you persist, the game improves drastically from the second part onwards, with an excellent grand finale on the last boss, which is by far the most stressful mission and requires a lot of strategy to win. On the difficulty I played (Experienced - which is equivalent to normal), it took just over 12 hours to finish everything. What's cool is that after finishing the game, you can play a New Game Plus, in which you need to replay the whole journey, but keeping your team and their hats. Yes, hats - although it is something purely cosmetic, the combination of some of them even guarantee you some achievements.

SteamWorld Heist is excellently replayable because it brings procedural generation for the vast majority of missions, which means that some of them never repeat themselves. The only exceptions are key missions, such as boss fights and others that require a very specific objective. After a few hours of gameplay, a very interesting alarm system appears and it is similar to the alarm system of Invisible Inc, in which after a determined number of turns, more enemies or turrets appear, requiring time optimization.

Performance in the missions are rated positively if you complete it with all the crew alive and also find and pick up a hidden treasure. The performance is rewarded with stars, which are used to unlock new missions and also to recruit some soldiers. When you fail a mission, with all members dead, you lose half the water (which is the game's currency) that you have. Although it seems like something that punishes the player, this is actually a very friendly system, considering that we would have to lose many matches before achieve a game over.

SteamWorld Heist also has some DLCs, which are basically new hats, a new playable character, new missions and new weapons and equipment. This extra content will not make much difference in the game, since it is already quite fun with the basic version, but it can serve as an incentive to finish the campaign and start New Game Plus with these additional content.

[b]Pros[/b]
* Gameplay that unites the best of XCOM and Worms
* Good replay value and variety of missions
* Great variety of items and weapons, even without the DLCs
* Plot full of twists
* Excellent soundtrack

[b]Con[/b]
* The first third of the game is repetitive and with some unnecessarily unfair enemies

29783140.review:
I loved Steamworld Heist. It's a simple game of "point-and-shoot", not too complicated and doesn't come with all the Pay To Win baggage that other games have. It's like XCOM but simpler. Steamworld Heist is set in the world after Earth is destoyed and all its inhabitants are lost to space. You play Captain Piper, the leader of a ragtag Steam crew who has turned pirate due to her disobeying an order to sell Steambots into slavery. The "Would you have sold the Jews to the Nazis if you were given the order?" choice

The objective of Steamworld Heist is usually to kill all the enemy Scrappers, loot the Epic Scrap and have no casualties. To do so, you play a turn-based game. On your turn, you have 2 actions, Move and Shoot. You may move twice in a row and not shoot, move and shoot or shoot and not move. Hide behind conveniently placed barrels in all the enemy ships you encounter. Shoot dynamite that is also conveniently placed next to enemies. Combat is repetitive and the map doesn't change much. You can recruit, upgrade and outfit your crew to customise them to your play style which is pretty cool.

Conclusion, it is a fun game overall. While it is not XCOM, Steamworld Heist does give a feeling of a clean simple game. Note that it's co-founded by the European Union.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Simple Controls
You can just use the mouse to move and shoot. It's that simple.

2. Build Your Crew
You can customise them to your playstyle.

3. Different abilities
As you play the game, you can keep on levelling up and gain new abilitiies. While there isn't a talent tree to choose from, the special abilities do make a slight difference E.g. Ivanski's Abs of Steel, invulnerable for 1 turn.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Repetitive Combat
It's the exact same thing over and over again. 

2. Stupid Voiceovers
Electronic metal grinding is kind of boring to listen to. While the dialogue is interesting, the voices are boring.

3. Cheesing the Game
Melee AI is the weakest in the whole game. They can be cheesed by covering all possible locations that they can stand on. E.g. Standing in between 2 barrels. That way the melee AI will attack the barrels and you'll still be able to shoot them at point blank range.

4. The Characters don't differentiate until mid game
You can't see a difference until the bots level up, so your first impression is that there's no differentiation.

5. Very Obvious Linear Questing
Normally, games try to mask linear questing. This one doesn't. It's literally a line from point A to point B.

6. New Game Plus
It was a bit dry honestly. I wasn't looking forward to the New Game Plus (the black hole). I would be fighting the exact same enemies and the story would be the same. I would have preferred something like the Witcher 2 which would entice me to play a NG+.

29762351.review:
SteamWorld Heist is lovely. It is a light Tactical Role-Playing, bite-sized 2D Dungeon Crawler, with a "trick shot" Outer Space Western vibe that's set in an endearing Steampunk World inhabited by robots. Travel through space and through 3 distinctly different zones, assault enemy barges and slowly build an arsenal of weapons. Gather a likeable cast of mechanized misfits.

The game itself is PERFECTLY suited for occasional casual play, with challenging levels that take maybe 5-15 minutes a piece and it's a joy to pop in when you've a got a few spare minutes to waste.

Perhaps the game's biggest trick is the way you fire, which is a mix of both carefully manual aiming - which can almost become a puzzle onto itself when handling snipers - combined with the XCOM method of movement and ability usage. There is no percentage, or luck based shooting. You yourself decide on the arch of your character's shots, raising their aim up and down, wether it is to lob a grenade just over a barrel, or carefully line up your bullet to ricochet off the surfaces. Your characters aims aren't steady and will waver along the general direction, but if you time your shot when it all lines up perfectly, you could in theory hit your marks halway across the map. It's all on you and when you manage to bounce your sniper's shot across 4 different surfaces to hit a distant enemy in the back of the head as he cowers behind a barrel, it is an extremely rewarding experience that ties well into the game's slightly Western / Firefly motive.

Perfect execution and steady aim is all but required as well, since the game isn't all that forgiving on a wasted turn. There is a constant timer that, although not causing an instant game over, will summon additional reinforcements that will overwhelm a sluggish or conservative player if the biggest existing threats haven't already been dealt with.

The enemies are varied and cleverly designed, and will require careful planning. Shooting a hulking foe in the knee will immobilize them. Carrying specific items around might help open up new tactics, like stunning them. Shield carrying foes need to be either flanked or lured into an area where you can bounce your shot to hit them in a weak spot. The last zone's enemies force you to stay mobile, or prioritize targets. You have abilities such as healing, auras to buff allies, double shots, sprint & gun and many more to stay alive. 

The RPG mechanics are minimal and you don't have to worry about skill trees. Each character has three inventory slots to give them new abilities, make up for weaknesses, or emphasize strengths as you see fit. None of it is very complicated, but fortunately the game does an excellent job of setting you up with a cast of characters that feel diverse and unique enough to be ultimately rewarding as you level up their pre-existing talents. Wacky, mute melee characters that can land and take a punch. A charming old military granny armed with a bazooka and enough explosives to blow a black hole in space. A sniping chimney sweep, a grizzled old shotgun sailor and a farmyard gal turned SMG wielding bounty hunter. My favourite must be "payroll": A gentleman fortune hunter that can blitz through enemy lines to flank, with abilities that are all puns on his method of mono-wheeled propulsion.


And all of these character, and the world they live in, are just a treat to spend your time with. Although you won't spend a lot of time delving into lore, effective use of quips, jokes, background art, casual chatter among the robot crew and light-hearted remarks, all tell a much greater story in just a few effective sentences. The recovery of an old human steam iron for instance, sees the game speculate on how this must have been the first of steam robot kind, telling the player much about how little the robots really know about the past and where humanity went. The final enemies, are not only exactly what you'd expect an adversary of a steampunk world to be, but tie in beautifully to the Western/Firefly theme of individual freedom and frontier spirit.

Highly recommended as both a charming adventure and a light-hearted strategy game.

The comps to a 'horizontal X-Com' are ridiculous. This game is much easier and has virtually no meta-game. Putting a tactical game into a side-view takes away actual dimensions of strategy. This strikes me as something that should be more of a child's intro to strategy games rather than an actual expansion of the genre.

... but despite that, it is wildly refreshing to play a tactical game in which shooting at someone results in them actually being shot, and you know exactly when enemies are going to see you and vice versa, and no one's magically shooting you thru walls. It's actually made me think about whether the 'difficulty' I'm attributing to more 'serious' tactical games is legitimately earned or not.

The game is also very charming, and it takes the right approach to story-telling (punchy). These guys made good, solid, uncynical products and deserve support.

Guns! Robots! X-COM tactical gameplay! HATS!!!

Great game if you like tactical turn-based games.  For those of you that have played X-COM before, you'll be at home with this 2-D verrsion of the gameplay you're used to, only with less stress and more focus on riccochet shooting, and in some of the crew's case, buffing squadmates.  There's partial and full cover that you'll need to learn to take advantage of to survive, even if you don't call it that (old habit i suppose), squad positioning is key, weapons and armor can and need to be adjusted throughout your missions (each character gets one weapon (limited to two specific types per char) and 2 supplemental items (universal to all chars).

The great thing about this game that makes it different/less stressful than X-COM is the focus on making every shot count, but you don't have permanent reprecussions for your actions.  If all your squadmates die, they can be put back together for half your earnings and the loss of any XP gained on that mission for dead squadmates (rough, but easily recoverable).  I personally started on Veteran, the 2nd hardest diff, and it's something I'd only recommend if you're familiar with these kinds of games.  I'm posting this review at 26 hrs where I've gotten a 'perfect' victory, and I think it was well worth the time to do so.  If that sounds like your cup of tea, than I highly recommend this game :)

29464744.review:
In the dry run between when the Nintendo 3DS came out and when the games started really rolling in, one neat indie game on their E-Shop took off: Steamworld Dig. It was a pretty simple Motherlode-style platformer, but it had charm and a satisfying gameplay loop. The only problem was its length, which was short enough to beat in just a few sessions. The game was successful, but rather than do a direct sequel, Image & Form decided to make one in a different genre altogether, a strategy RPG. That means you won't beat Steamworld Heist in just a few hours, and it also resulted in a fantastic game to me.

Heist is set a while after Dig, following the Earth exploding and its robot inhabitants moving into space on barges. You play as Captain Piper and her crew, who operate as space 'pirates', although you never steal from anyone who isn't also a pirate or evil in some other way, so they may as well just be bounty hunters or something. Pirate attacks in the outer regions of space have become more vicious later, and it's up to them to find out why, and make off with as much loot or hats as they can carry.

Combat is clearly inspired by X-COM: all the ladders, drops and cover are there as you might have seen them in Enemy Unknown/Within, but set in a 2D backdrop. Also like that game, you can move and shoot or use an item, or use your entire move dashing. The most unique wrinkle though, is that there is no RNG in Steamworld Heist, at least on your end. When you go to attack at range, you're allowed to freely aim your weapon, and spend as long as you want aiming the perfect shot. Your bots' don't have perfect stability, so the sights waver a bit, and there are things like ricochets to factor in, but if you hate when a 90 percent shot turns into a miss in X-COM or Fire Emblem, this might be the game for you.

That doesn't make the game easy, of course. Even your most bulky party members can't just tank fire, and it's safe to assume enemies will hit them if they're ever out in the open. Your team is made up of all unique party members, so they're not gone forever if they bite it, but that means they don't receive experience (which is doled out for fulfilling mission objectives rather than killing enemies), and your rating for the mission will drop. It's a good balance between encouraging you to be careful, but not punishing you horribly if something happens to go wrong. There are also multiple difficulties so you can fine-tune it however you like.

Despite being in just 2D Heist has a lot of tricks up its sleeve, such as enemies who only melee, ones with shields you have to flank, and ones who charge up piercing lasers. It's also able to replicate things from X-COM that work with it, like flanking (at least with two characters), and a running timer on some missions that will spawn extra reinforcements, keeping you from just turtling up. There are also some interesting boss battles, which X-COM doesn't really do.

Heist also has a DLC known as The Outsider, which adds another character and a couple more missions to each map (of which there are three, with different ships to invade and enemies to fight). It's not necessary by any means, but the extra crew member is interesting to use, and it has some useful, but not game-breaking items. I like that it's not cordoned off in its own little area, and it's only five dollars as well.

Overall, Steamworld Heist was a very pleasant surprise for me, and a huge step forward for the people behind it. Moving between genres can't be easy, but they produced something not just good, but a huge leap forward compared to their last game. If any of this sounds interesting to you I'd recommend picking it up now, and especially if it's on sale. Really looking forward to Image & Form's next game, whatever genre it happens to be.

29127847.review:
SteamWorld Heist is a side scrolling, turn-based, tactical game where you're the commander of a group of space pirates drawn into unavoidable conflict against the Empire while performing routine heists. Although the game is in side-scrolling 2D, it encompasses the familiar genre staples such as a cover system and terrain variability while displaying some of its own mechanics such as bullet ricochet which add some depth to the simplified systems. While the game delivers an entertaining journey and tense combat, it suffers from a lacklustre story and somewhat repetitive mission structure in the latter half.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Dialogue and interactions between characters is really enjoyable as characters often share their entertaining back-stories with you after missions.
+ Combat is extremely well done, I've heard it compared to a simplified mix of XCOM/Worms.
+ Bullet ricochet is highly enjoyable as you can kill enemies hiding behind cover by ricocheting bullets in the blind spots where there is no cover. Getting unassisted ricocheted kills feel extremely  satisfying.
+ A lot of effort was placed into the audio and visual aspects of the game and it shows as the game oozes polish from every nook and cranny.
+ There's no grind for what amounts for a tactical game and that's surprising for me. Lower skilled characters can be carried and get essential 2 bars if they survived the mission easily bringing them up to the rest of the squad.
+ There's no reliance on RNG during the combat it's all skill. If you missed shot, YOU missed the shot as have full control of where you aim. If a character is out in the open then the chances of receiving damage is 90-100% and it was fully based on YOUR decision.
+ Combat while not difficult is often times tense under certain situations depending on your difficulty.
+ The difficulty curve is rather smooth. I played on Experienced and even though I got wiped on a few missions, it wasn't difficult to complete the game.
+ A unique-ish loot system that's literally all of the items found lying on the floor in missions plus the epic swag bonus which is often placed in a mildly inconvenient room forcing you to explore all rooms. Don't feel like managing your small inventory to store mission loot rewards, fine, simply go for the epic swag and leave all other items alone.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Story is kind of lacklustre and forgettable.
- You can't equip weapons/items outside of missions.
- Missions are too repetitive, you're often stuck doing the same things mission in, mission out and while enjoyable it does get tiresome.
- Limited inventory results in management feeling extremely tedious as you're given generous amounts of loot as reward for completing missions.
- Aborting missions cost 50% of your current money/water. Why is this a thing, there were times where I accidentally retried missions I'd completed instead of selecting the next mission and I had to slug through it again because I'd be penalised for nothing.
- The game feels a bit too long and drawn out, almost like if it was padded with unnecessary content e.g. the 1 character missions.
- There are times where the enemy AI is too accurate. This is clearly evident during the boss battle against the Queen. The general's bullet will ricochet a number of times and the result is a perfect shot no matter what. I've had this happen to me a lot during that battle to the point that it's unfair and too perfect.
- Battles can become drawn out as result of the alert system which spawns a number of enemies of increasing difficulty when the counter has elapsed. I get why this is here but boy does it get annoying.

[h1]Irritations[/h1]
+/- Hats...why are they a thing? They serve literally no purpose, no added stat benefit or complexity. 
+/- Loot is kind of boring as it simply boils down to +1 this or -1 that.
+/- There are no unique group passive synergies when in combat other than the captain's Inspire ability. I feel like this is a missed opportunity seeing as how simplified the game is, this could've added some much needed depth and nuance to the combat.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
SteamWorld Heist is an overall enjoyable experience despite its shortcomings and is well worth the recommendation. The combat is tense, the dialogue is well written, the strategy and tactical mechanics while simple are extremely accessible and all of this results in a very entertaining package.

1) You get weapons which show you the trajectory of your bullet, which 90% doesn't match the actual bullet path. 
2) Game puts you in unfair odds, which force you replay missions and basically grind in a 300mb game, seriously? That's an awful way to make a game longer. 
3)The game is made artaficially longer. 
4)Replay value of missions is lost due to the game punishing you constantly, even for doing everything right. Which makes grinding redundant.  

You know, if the game at least was funny, I'd finish it, but it's not even funny. 

Loved Steam World Dig from start to finish, hate this one.  

P.S. I didn't think of the game to be hard, it just intentionally makes you replay levels. I. Don't. Want. To. Do. That. They. All. Look. The. Same! 


Verdict: Music/Art is good. The "game" itself, not so much.

28873377.review:
Un univers steampunk réussit, du tour par tour en 2D qui fonctionne extrêmement bien et du loot fait d'arme, de gadget et de chapeau, voilà un bon résumer du jeu.
Un jeu étonnamment fun, avec même de la rejouabilité grâce au new game+ et le loot. Je conseil de faire le jeu dans toutes ces difficultés, ainsi le jeu aura une bonne duré de vie de plus de 50h. Mais comptés dans les 20h pour finir le jeu en mode normale.

En gros vous aurez une sorte de hub via votre vaisseaux ou vous pourrez parler avec vos coéquipier et accédé à la map, map sur lequel il y aura un chemin plus ou moins linéaire, par le fait que certaine quête secondaire ne soit pas obligatoire mais qu'on ne peut globalement pas vraiment sortir du chemin. Vous rencontrerez divers compagnon à engager dans des zones sans combat, avec les quels vous formerez des commando de 1 à 4 personnage celons la mission et vous devrez le plus souvent passer du point A au point B d'un vaisseaux ennemis, en devant juste récupéré tout le loot, ou en tuent tel adversaire ou tel quantité d'ennemis au passage, en détruisant tel truc ou en atteignent tel endroit avant.

La diversité des missions et des ennemis est assez bonne, et il y a suffisamment d'arme, d'objet et de coéquipier aux capacités variés pour les appréhender de plusieurs façon différente. En tout cas on n'a pas l'impression que se soit répétitif, sauf peut être si on veux farmer un peu.
Le gameplay consiste en une phase de déplacement, puis de tir (à moins que vous ayez couru à la place, c'est à dire aller plus loin que votre capacité de déplacement initial). Vous devrez viser juste, et c'est cette partit là du jeu qui est la plus fun. Rien de plus gratifiant dans se jeu de réussir un tir bien placer avec n'importe quel arme.

Il y a en plus un système de chapeau qu'on peu enlever aux ennemis et récupéré ensuite pour les mettre sur nos personnages, ça ne sert à rien mais c'est sympa.

Son DLC ajoute un compagnon, quelque nouvelle mission et de nouveau chapeau. Il n'est pas indispensable mais c'est sympa quand même si vous aimez vraiment le jeu.

A savoir que le jeu se joue surtout à la manette, il est complètement fait pour jouer avec et il le fait très bien. La sourie reste possible, mais c'est moins évidant.

Un jeu coup de cœur pour moi qui m'as amuser plus et plus longtemps que je le pensais (54h pour les 3 mode de difficulté et quelque succès), et que je conseil vivement.

28319714.review:
My review comes after I have fully completed Steamworld Heist on 'Experienced' difficulty on my first playthrough.

I enjoyed every moment of this game and there is a variety of difficulty settings for more casual players or more harcore players.

This turn-based, skill-based, shooter game has little elements of RNG and the majority of outcomes is based on your strategy and skills. There is a good selection of members and guns to choose from that cater to different playing styles. Some are sharpshooters that get an aim-assist laser line, some are rocket launcher users, some are more skilled based (i.e. Sally can get additional shots if she kills an enemy and with 'mad dog' she can shoot forever until she doesn't kill an enemy in one turn) and others are more strategy based (i.e. Payroll has very high movement and gains double shot + bonus dmg when flanking so you move behind enemies and unleash hell on them).

The levels are mostly randomized to some degree and sometimes, but if you played certain levels 10+ times over (yea I did lol) you've gotten the idea what the general layout is going to be like.

The majority of the RNG comes from whether or not you crit an enemy, assuming you don't have 100% crit chance and sometimes when you do not crit and the enemy survives with 1 hp it kinda sucks.

There are weapon shops in-game but some of the best equipment I've obtained was RNG loot from finishing levels. Though not necessary to continue with the game it does make it much easier (i.e. Exoskeleton - +2 HP, +1 Mend +1 Melee..that is really nice for melee focused member like Billy).

The music and art-style is appropriate and both are enjoyable.

Game also offers NG+ if you want to start from the beginning, but keep your crew, level and gear. This gives the oppurtunity to play at a higher difficulty level..or lower if you wish.

The story was simple, and straightforward. Nothing spectacular about it, but really bad about it either.

------------
tl;dr 
Gameplay - 2/2
Boss Fights - 1/1
Customization of Party - 2/2
Art and Music - 2/2
NG+ - 1/1
Story 1/2

Overall: 9/10. Highly Recommended

28279262.review:
SteamWorld Heist is an excellent turn-based strategy with a twist - manual aiming.
This game isn;t a typical turn-based strategy. The maps are not-top, but veiwed from the side, almost like a side-scroller. But don't be fooled - you will still be playing the game by selecting units, exacuting commands and taking turns with your enemy. The only difference in controls is the aforementioned manual aiming. When you want to attack, you'll have to point your sights just right. This adds a lot to the strategy. Cover is not just a stat, but a physical barrier that cannot be shot through. Accuracy is also not a stat - all skill. This also allows for fun trick shots, something that you could never do just hitting the "attack" command. It opens up all new possibilites for clever manuvers outside of the simple numbers and rulebooks. The numbers still play a big part of the game though, so strategy fans, don't worry. Manual aiming is a big part of the game, but doesn't take over the other aspects of the game in any way. There's experience and leveling, tons of weapons and subweapons, shops and item management, and so forth. It all fits together very nicely and becomes a seemless strategy-sprinkled-with-skill experience.
To top it off, the world is a quirky steampunk space land with lovable automaton characters and fun hats to collect. The story isn't much, just enough to give you an excuse to go from shoot-out to shoot-out, and the characters and world add a charm on top of the fun gameplay that completes the uniqueness of the experience.
Also, the soundtrack is done by Steam Powered Giraffe, a steampunk-themed folk/vaudeville band that sings about automatons even when they're not writing for a steampunk game. They did an excellent job on this soundtrack, so if you like the soundtrack in this game, check out their other work as well.
Overall, this game is like no others out there. If you like turned-based strategy, or light-hearted steampunk robot characters, than I highly recomend this game.

28165745.review:
I purchased this game a while back on the Nintendo 3DS eshop, since it's been in a final form there for a while.

I put about 10 hours into it on the mobile system, and I remember thinking "Geez, there would totally be a market for this game on Steam!"

Lo and behold, Steamworld : Heist has made it's way here, it has a fantastic feel to it, it looks great and the mouse controls are a big boost.

This game is not quite XCom for depth, but if you imagine a great reimagining of XCom's combat without much overworld management, you'll understand the basic game loop.

Enter enemy junkship, do things that generally involve turning a bunch of robots into scrap heap.

The mechanics are pretty satisfying - landing a ricochet shot off a roof to hit an enemy behind cover is a pretty neat trick.

Atmospherically, the game has this really neat mix of retrofuturism between this "turn of the century" cinema and 2004's Firefly.

It seems like many of the levels are randomly generated around a mold similar to Diablo.

The only major complaint would be level variety - the only tileset you see is "rusty metal ship internals". It'd have been neat to see some more worldbuilding for these cowbots for some asteroids or the like.

Overall, this is definitely worth your $15.

28125305.review: This game is amazing and I can't stop playing it. It's rare that I finish a game and jump straight into New Game + (after getting the DLC). Great mix of strategy and skill. Fun story and characters. Beware, it's one of those "just one more turn" type of games.

28092318.review: sehr sehr sehr sehr gutes spiel:  100% spaß

28088482.review:
[b]Steamworld Heist is simply a fun to play, and it hasn't gotten boring yet.[/b]

One of the main reasons this game has amazing replayability is that starting over is so dang fun for some reason. The New Game Plus option also allows you to start over keeping your... Well, I won't spoil too much, but it makes restarting feel even [i]more[/i] fun. It's nice to go back to the basics after beating the entire game, especially since about halfway through, you'll forget what it feels like to not be overwhelmed at all times.

[b]PROS:[/b]

Lots of things.
[*] Turn based, but not: Although you and the enemy take turns shooting at each other in a very engaging bar-fight-shoot-out-esque style, you don't simply click on the enemy to attack. Well, I mean, you can. But what I mean is, you do the aiming. Some guns ricochet, some guns deal area damage, some guns pierce. This combined with the fact you have to manually line up your sights with the enemy makes it feel much more immersive.
[*] A wide cast of characters: Some people will tell you that some characters become useless at some point, and some are too over-powered. I partly agree. Some characters are practically essential to have late-game, and it becomes pretty obvious that not just ANY team comp will work. However... That said, the characters all have personalities, which are great. Sometimes, after a mission, you can talk to them back on-board and learn something about their past, or their character. Additionally, bringing certain heroes to certain missions prompts dialogue that you otherwise never would have heard. It's up to you to figure that out. Oh and, when I said I partly agreed, I said it because I don't really think any hero becomes [i]totally[/i] useless. Some characters become more viable, but this doesn't neccessarily mean the rest of the crew becomes useless. If you want a challenge, or are just genuinely attached to a character, by all means, use them!
[*] THE GRAPHICS: My gosh, the scenery, the characters, the background... It's all beautiful. I've never seen another game company make something in this exact way - Not to say it's the best thing ever, but it's absolutely gorgeous most of the time, and feels refreshing. Even the dark, gloomy interiors of the Scrapper ships (Don't worry, it's not really a spoiler. They're literally the first enemies you'll encounter.) will take your eye off the battle once or twice... or twenty times... In one level. Not to mention the detail they put into the cosmos, which is always present in the background, and most of the time covered by the level you're on. Take time to look around, you'll find it worth your time. Mainly because of the aesthetics... And there's some nice little easter eggs and quirky things to see!
[*] The story: This game made me think it was going to be really short. And then there was a non-specific thing that non-specifically happened that changed the story to a non-specific degree. I'm trying not to spoiler much. This also happens a non-specific amount of times. In a non-specific order. Needless to say, the story will keep you glued to the game for your first run-through, and likely for the next couple of times as you find more and more you missed the first couple of times.
[*] The sounds: This may sound minor, but believe me it's not. When I say sounds, I mean ALL of them. Of course the music is great, if you've played Steamworld Dig you'd know that. If not, I'm telling you - The music is great. But it's also the little things, like the enemy bots falling apart and their parts clanking on the ground a few times before finally settling, the richochet of bullets off metal, heck, even the robots [b]talking[/b] sounds awesome! Trust me, you'll know what I mean when you try it.
[*] The feeling of growth of your team: This is sort of a weird one, but if you're one of those people who [i]loves[/i] watching your roster slowly grow in power and ability over the course of a game, this game really makes you feel good about it. The benefits of leveling up range from a minor health boost or passive, to a huge turn that makes the character totally different from everyone else. Exp grinding is also NOT A PAIN AT ALL. Seriously. To get all characters to max level, you might have to run a couple levels a couple more times than usual. But it's fun to do that! And you can totally beat the game without maxed out heroes, so don't even worry about it unless you really, really want it (Like I did). Oh, and there's an achievement for it. So yeah.
[*] HATS! HATS HATS HATS! This game has hats! Lots of them! In fact it's almost a joke! Shoot hats off of your enemies to get them! Buy hats! JUST GET MORE HATS! Haaaats!

[b]CONS:[/b]

(Wind howls, and a tumbleweed made of scrap and barbed wire flies across outer-space...)

Well not entirely. Although there are a couple things that nag me, and might nag you. For starters...

[*] This isn't the case for me, but I can see how it can be for others - Repetativeness: This isn't the case for me, but I can see how it can be for others - Repetativeness... In all seriousness, there's enough character diversity and most but not all levels are randomly generated, so this shouldn't be too big an issue... And like I said, there's not much grinding involved, so a new level will probably feel... Well, like a new level! But I can certainly see how it can get a liiiittle boring for soooooome people. But trust me - Odds, are, it won't be a problem. At all. Take a break from the game now and then, and the urge to come back will slowly creep up on you.
[*] Weapon diversity: For the most part, and I won't lie, new weapons are usually just upgraded versions of the ones you already had. Which is fine, except... There's not many weapons that AREN'T straight upgrades to ones you already had. Sure, different heroes use different types of weapons, but outside of that, each type of weapon usually only does 1 or 2 different things, at most, depending on the type. Oh, and there's some nice quirky "rare" weapons that change it up, but like I said, you'll probably find a powered-up version that will eventually turn it into nothing more than a collector's item... Which leads me to my last "con".
[*] Inventory space: There ain't much of it. You're gonna have to spend a LOT of water (in-game currency, go figure) to upgrade your inventory size, too. It's a pain, sort of. Grind a few levels and you'll be filthy rich again, though. I guess the whole "new weapons are just upgrades from the previous ones" works with this system, since you're probably gonna want to sell the old weapons anyways... It's just... I wish there was more. You have to check your inventory and sell stuff every couple of missions. And I'd like to keep those rare collectible weapons just for fun without compromising my time sifting my inventory of junk and duplicates. But this is a minor issue, if an issue at all.

And... That's all! I gotta say, this game blew me away. I knew Steamworld Dig was fun, but it's not like it was ground breaking (Tecnhically speaking, it was, but you know what I mean). If I'm being totally honest, I wasn't sure how well they were gonna pull this game off. I was a skeptic. But as a skeptic does, I completely took back my word once I saw the evidence (Disclaimer: Some skeptics are still too stubborn to do this). By that note, if you're skeptical about this game too, I understand. People tend to read a bit more into the Cons of a game review than the Pros, and take the Cons much more to heart. But please, for your sake, don't. Don't second-guess yourself on this one. If you like any of the genres, or liked Steamworld Dig, or anything Steampunk/Robot related, or shoot-outs, or space, or just great game design in general, do yourself a favor and buy this game. Wanna wait til its on sale? Why not? Only means you're getting a game worth well more than its price tag for cheap. [b]Highly recommend.[/b]

I have only two minor issues with this game.

1) Weapon balance. Common weapons of the same tier generally deal the same damage, and this is an issue. Pistols have perfect aim while SMGs and shotguns do not. When all three deal identical damage on a direct hit, the pistol is clearly the superior choice in almost all situations, with the shotgun being the least useful. Only sniper weapons and heavy weapons are exceptions to this, due to the usefulnes of laser sights with the former and area damage of the latter.

2) New Game Plus. This is literally just a reset of the entire game, except you get to keep your crew members. I felt like this wasn't properly explained in the confirmation pop-up and I would not have started NG+ had I known that. A way to swap between NG+ and the regular mode would have been nice, rather than permanently changing my save file.

All in all still one of the best game I played this year. The Outsider DLC is also highly recommended.

27884629.review: Bought the game on the 3DS and played through it in one week while on vacation. Can not recommend it enough for anyone who likes Xcom like games with robots in space!! The music is a highlight as well.

27844906.review:
This is XCOM-light meets Firefly the TV show. Aiming, including in real-time, in a turn-based game is clever and new. SteamWorld Heist also has fantastic recorded (vs. digitally synthesized) original music...I don't know of any other game at quite this level.

There are two downsides: 

1. Platformer view with highly constrained ship layouts turn most combat into a slugfest. The only tactics are chosing when to fall back or use a special power. There's no opportunity to leverage movement and positioning effectively.

2. The fantastic art also disguises which floor/ceiling surfaces provide cover and which can be shot through. The fun theme and fun mechanics are in conflict here and diminish both.

The controller mapping isn't quite as good as XCOM's, but it is close.

27823246.review:
Замечательная игра! Восхитительна яигра! Великолепная игра!
Купил её после того, как прошел StemWorld Dig (тоде рекомендую, кстати). Но я никак не ожидал, что создатели этого классного платформера, могут сделать крутой пошаговый тактический шутер. Причем настолько крутой, что по-настоящему удивит меня - человека, который наиграл черт знает сколько часов в XCOM: Enemy Unknown, потом в XCOM: Enemy Within и в XCOM: Long War. 

В SteamWorld Heist прекрасно всё:
+приятная графика - видно, что сделано с любовью)))
+игровой процесс - это нечто!
+реиграбельность зашкаливает, хочется играть и играть, проходя уровни по-новому, разными персонажами.
+тактическая составляющая не хуже, чем в XCOM
+каждый член команды по-своему крут! 
+офигенный саундтрек
+это очень позитивная и стильная игра (поймёте, что я имею в виду, когда поиграете).

К минусам условно можно отнести невозможность сохранять игру, когда захочется - игра сама сохраняет процесс после каждого хода. Но может быть это и плюс - приходится обдумывать каждый ход. А свои ошибки можно исправить, перепройдя уровень.

В общем, рекомендую всем тем, кто наигрался в XCOM и кому хочется ещё чего-то в этом духе. Куча положительных эмоций обеспечена! 

Я номинировал эту игру на премию STEAM в номинации "Эта игра нравилась мне еще до того, как стала хитом". В самом деле, я удивлен, почему про эту игру никто из моих друзей и знакомых не слышал? Это шедевр!

27609661.review:
I really, really like the premise. Turn-based tactic + 2D sidescroll + space. If that doesn't sound awesome, I don't know what does.

However, the game, unfortunately, doesn't really live up to my expectation due to various issues:
- Why the hell does a turn based tactic game have a reflex-based aiming system? Do you want me to think about positioning and stuff or do you want me to think about timing my aim? Please just pick one.
- Clunky control. It's super hard if you want to adjust your aim by a little when using mouse. A lot of time I accidentally fire my gun when I just want to change my aim a bit.
- Boring story / world. The game seems to have a unique lore, but it never allows us to see/explore it. It would be fine if the game isn't so story-driven.
- Loot system that drops useless hats. I seriously don't understand why the game needs it, other than to artifically makes the loot seems more important.
- No customizablity for our space ship. Seeing that the hero has a spaceship, I seriously expected the game to allow players to upgrade and customize the spaceship, maybe add a room or change the warp engine, etc. But nope, hats are better apparently.

27536833.review:
This game is a surprise. A positive one. If you like steam punk, robots as the main protagonists instead of humans, turn based skill games and cool music, this is the one for you.
The mechanics are simple to understand, the actions are easy to perform and there is always a reward for victory. The game is sometimes challenging but never unfair. At most you have to play a level three times before you finish with perfect score. The robot characters are mostly funny and unique. The graphics are not state of the art, but clearly enough for this type of game. The music is nice (with some cons).

The pros: 
Easily 20 hours play time if you play it a second time on a higher difficulty.
A rich and colorful world design.
Good game mechanics.
Music and Graphic blend together.

The cons:
In the end, you play mostly the same 4 or 5 robots out of 9. It may be another set of robots for you than for me, but it will happen.
The music worked for me only in the game. I tried a few samples in the web without the game, and it's not as good as it sounds here. After a while, it may be repetetive in the game too.
It's no groundbreaking or breathtaking game. What do you expect?

Overall a 8/10

26470793.review:
SteamWorld Digと世界観を共にするロボットキャラのゲーム。Digは地下へ地下へと潜っていくゲームだったが、Heistは一転して宇宙を渡り歩いていく。

スクリーンショットを見るとシューティングアクションのようにも見えるが、実際にはアクション性、リアルタイム性皆無のターンベースのストラテジーなのでじっくりまったり遊べる。

横2D画面内でキャラクターを操作して、移動＋射撃か、ダッシュ移動（移動量２倍）かのどちらかを選択する。また箱などの遮蔽物に隠れることで、敵の銃撃を防ぐことができる。全ての味方の行動が完了すると、敵が行動する。このあたりのルールはXCOMの横2D版とよく言われるくらいなので、それをプレイしたことのある人にはわかりやすいだろう。


出てくる敵味方は基本的に全てロボ。味方キャラクラーには使用可能武器とレベルアップで覚えていくスキルがあり、個性と装備する武器やアイテムにより戦略も変わってくる。

マップは宇宙船になっていて、自身の船をドッキングして無理やり乗り込んでいく。敵の殲滅、施設の破壊、アイテムの回収など、各マップごとに設定された目標を達成すると出口が開き、全キャラクターが出口に揃ったらマップクリア。次のマップやイベントに進めるようになる。ちなみにアイテム回収と生存状況によって☆が貰える。

マップの概要や敵の種類はある程度決まっているが、部屋の構成や敵やアイテムの配置などは毎回変化するので、リプレイ性もある。

攻撃は射撃位置を指定して撃つことになるが、手ブレあり、一部の武器は重力の影響ありで、狙ったところに必ず当たるとは限らない。また武器によっては跳弾が可能で、直接狙えない敵も、壁や障害物で跳ね返した弾を当てて攻撃することも可能。

武器やアイテムはマップ内の袋や宝箱を拾うことでランダムに入手できる。武器やアイテムの性能は固定だが、たまに紫色に光るレア装備が出ることも。他に、お金として入手できる「水」を使って、お店で買うこともできる。


日本語対応はしていないが、ゲームのルール自体はわりとシンプルなので、簡単な英語がわかれば遊べると思う。難易度も選べるし、プレイ中に難易度変更も可能なのでとっつきやすいかと。銃撃で機械の敵がバラバラになる感じも楽しい。

キャラクターにちょっと癖があるし、あまり有名ではないみたいだが、個人的にはすごく当たりだった。

26461485.review:
Ich mag eigentlich kaum Spiele die Rundenbasiert sind, aber Steamworld Heist ist da eine Ausnahme. Es mach einfach reisen Spaß seine Gegner um ein paat ecken zu verschrotten und man ist oft am fiebern, ob die abgefeuerte Granate nicht doch noch zurück kommt.

Neben den Bossgegnern, den tollen Waffen, der lustigen Charakteren und den erfrischenden Scenario gibt es auch Herausforderungsmissionen, viele Händler und stimmige Bars, in der schöne Musik gespielt wird.

Das einzige was mich stört, ist das man nur vor einer Mission die Mannschaft ausrüsten darf und nicht zwischendurch. Auch das Inventar ist immer zu klein, egal wie viele Slots man kauft.

Aber dennoch ist ein echt gut gelungendes Spiel!
