26448394.review:
"A TBT shooter with interesting mechanics and a soundtrack by Steam Powered Giraffe? Why wasn't it in my library sooner?"

That's all I got for an introduction, so let's just dive in.

[b]PROS[/b]
[list]
[*]The core mechanic of the game is the player-controlled aiming; it gets the player far more involved in combat than simply picking a target and rolling the dice like other TBT games.  Even with infinite turn time, the slightest sway can take you off target and you'll have only your own timing and placement to blame.  Shot ricochet is also central to the game; No shot is sweeter than the one that removes the rare hat from your opponent before bouncing off the wall and planting itself in the back of the bot's head
[*]The roster of squadmates is diverse, with some having varying skills inside the same class, and some having a class all their own.
[*]Weapons, especially legendaries, become very eccentric after a third of the way through the game: Laser-sighted sharpshooter pistols that shoot through enemies, cluster-firing rocket launchers and a gun that throws a heap of bouncing spike-balls at your foes.
[*]Do I even have to say that SPG brings their best to this game?
[/list]

[b]CONS[/b]
[list]
[*]Some squadmates will become obsolete, even after much grinding to keep them up with the rest of the squad.  Sally is an early addition to your crew, but her skills are a poor match for her stats; her skills are focused on killing as many opponents in one turn as possible, but while others would have extra health or greater mobility to back this up, she has neither.  Meanwhile, Ivanski the tank would soak up XP from how much I used him.
[*]Be sure to keep up with your weapon's rank, because difficulty takes a SPIKE during the last third of the game, due to the new super-durable units deployed in disproportionate numbers.  On medium or higher, I was very unlikely to get through a mission with all bots intact on the first try.

26435758.review:
I expected a short fun romp through this game. I never expected it to have some longevity, without ever feeling tiresome, and for me to stay so engrossed though the whole experience.

It's hard to describe the feeling of satisfaction one gets when executing a headshot on a bot in the next room via 16 ricochets with a sniper pistol.

Great music, great variety, intelligent sense of humour, no bugs experienced during my time playing, and the insatiable urge to collect all of the hats. What's not to like?

At a glance it might not seem interesting, but it really is worth your time!

26128974.review:
So, after over 20 hours of gameplay I finished the game on the third out of five difficulty levels - Experienced.

And wow, was it a fun ride.

I guess it's time to write a review, huh?

Then let's start.






Steamworld Heist is set in a universe where humans went extinct (not quite, but... spoilers) and Earth is now inhabited by steam powered robots. Actually it WAS inhabited by them, because Steamworld Heist takes place hundreds of years after the first game, when Earth explodes and all that is left of it are big shards floating in space. Luckily Steambots learned how to build spaceships and managed to escape.

Soon began the new era in their history, a era of Cowbots exploring the endless frontiers of Universe.

But their life isn't so simple. Cowbots have to face many powerful threats: space pirates, diesel powered robots who formed strong military and consider themselves superior over everyone else, and an alien, powerful threat lurking somewhere in Deep Space.


In Steamworld Heist you play as Piper Faraday - a pirate captain with a golden heart and assemble a crew of different colorful characters, like a jolly adventurous grampa who is a great sniper, a soldier with a love for blowing things up or a robot sailor with a fish head who can only communicate by saying "Blub".


The gameplay is a bit like 2D XCOM - you play in turns, there's full cover and half cover, you also can choose if you want to move a few tiles and shoot, or use up your turn to sprint. But there's a very important feature that makes Steamworld Heist much better than XCOM.



You aim each shot manually. When you play your shots are not calculated by RNG - everything depends on your skill. Another cool thing is that your bullets can bounce off walls and objects. You will use ricochets often, because enemies rarely can be hit with a straight shot. If someone hides behind cover, you can just shoot at a nearby wall or barrel to hit him in the back of the skull. When you pull off a risky shot and it connects, it feels really satisfying.

The game has a wide selection of different weapons you can use as well as many different items you can equip for missions, like medkits, armor or sidearms. But that's not important.


What's important that this game has hats.


Dozens of hats.


What are they for?


Nothing. Absolutely f*cking nothing. They don't give you any stat boosts, they are just there to put on your head.

So does that mean that they suck?

No! They look great and it's fun to collect different hats and put them on different characters.


Also, a really good band called Steam Powered Giraffe made several songs for this game.

Check them out on Youtube, they are fantastic.



So, in short: 


Steamworld Heist is almost perfect. It runs well, the graphics look good, the gameplay is really fun, it offers a lot of replayability, and the music is super catchy. This may be the best game I ever played in the last few years.


Highly recommend.



Also, get the Outsider DLC. You will get a awesome new character, more missions, new weapons and even more hats.







Blub.

26007729.review:
Broad Review: This is a turn-based strategy game where the player must use their robots to reach an objective. There are several different classes that are used and introduced in the game each with something unique and useful to bring. Similar to Worms, each person can attack once per turn, but unlike Worms the turns are for the whole team rather than just one person on the team.

tl;won't read : This game is a fun little time waster if you can get past the bullcrap but it the game doesn't even try to do anything new and it will have a hard time keeping you engaged. If there was more effort put into the gameplay or story than I would be much more amused.

Numbering:
[b]Gameplay:[/b] 4/10
[b]Story:[/b] 2/10
[b]Music:[/b] 6/10
[b]Visuals[/b] 7/10

[b]Overall[/b] 6/10
For a more extensive review, please see below:

[b]Gameplay: 4/10[/b] This game plays well and runs well even on my weak laptop, however, the gameplay lacks depth and will become boring as the story is not intersting in the slightest. Also, there are plenty of game design choices that are either bad or ones that I did not agree with. These problems include:[b]Difficulty Spiking[/b] The difficulty curve is a bit wonky even in the short time that I played it, act 1 was very easy but 2 missions into act two is where the ai gets extreme aiming ability as well as abilities that you won't even know existed that allows them to do things that you aren't even sure you'll ever be able to do...  in short the gameplay becomes unfair instead of difficult because of it.[b]Infinetly Spawning Enimies[/b] Honestly, I thought videogames were over this. Never have I played a game with infinitely spawning enemies and thought it was amazing. Even worse, enemies that spawn in the middle of a match have a turn although, luckily, they don't always take advantage of it. This is a legit bad design choice as it shows just how much your game lacks depth and it is just artificial difficulty.[b]Randomly Generated Missions[/b]  This is another design choice that confused me because it removes several elements of strategy from the game. It's obvious this was added in to prevent the player from getting an edge but it is not fun for a single player game. Especially considering that there is no way the player can know which characters to bring anyway meaning you will have to play missions several times before finding out what works.
There are some good design choices, very few but very fun. The gunplay is interesting and the ability, while mostly useless, are fun to mess around with. Other than that there isn't much to say.

[b]Story 2/10[/b] Here's a story that you've never heard before, evil underdogs rebel againts a society that is being ruined by a superior foe. A very unique concept that has only been done in almost every form of media and each genre in that respective media. Like the gameplay, the story doesn't bring anything new to the table but it does little to offend and that's why It scores very low. If it was bad then there could have been some enjoyment out of it, but it lacks depth and it does nothing with the concept. The characters do not help, there is absolutely nothing interesting about the charcters beyond the first few missions, this is true in most games but this time it was particularly dreadful because there is so much that could be done with the characters in the world yet the chance is missed completely. The writing has it's moments but they are very few and hard to find because you will skip it... because it's boring. In short, interesting premise that is brought down by boring characters and an equally boring plot. 

[b]Music: 5/10[/b] The music during the gameplay was bad, not to say it was horrible but it wasn't passible. The tracks aren't very inspired and feels as if it was made quickly and haphazardly. It also loses it's effect as it is played all of the time and there is no intensity with harder/more enimies which feels like a huge wasted oppurtunity. [b]HOWEVER[/b] there is good music in the rest of the world, namely the bar. Music helps make a game more immersive and the bar helped build the world. Unfortunatley, it was great at best and overall, the music is brought down due to the lame gameplay music.

[b]Visuals: 7/10[/b] This game's art is not bad. In fact, it is simple enough to remain memorable and unique enough to have it's own identity. Everything that needs to be there in terms of gameplay elements is easily distinguishable making it easy to look at and play. It is only a seven though becuase while it is very good, it isn't new nor interesting. I honestly would have glazed over this game had it not been recommened to me because this style, steampunk, is not my thing. I do know other people enjoy steam punk and you wouldn't be looking at this review for this game if you weren't interested.

My overall opinion: This game is very well polished and has had a clear amount of effort put it and some aspects its play. However, unlike most strategy games, this game lacks depth and very quickly becomes unintersting. There isn't anything new in this game in the first place and if you have ever played any 2-D strategy game and didn't enjoy it, you will Definetly NOT enjoy this.
    It may be obvious by now but I did NOT enjoy playing this game. So why did I reccommend it? Because if you can get past the lack of depth and boring story than you have a fun little time waster on your hands and I mean that with a lot of sincerity. If you play this game casually, rather than a hardcore game, then you will enjoy it.

It's a game that I felt compelling enough to finish, and that's pretty rare for me.

Pros:
* Nice mix of the recent XCOMs 2-move strategy with Worms like aiming with different gun types, such as sniper "rifles", pistols, grenade launchers, SMGs, and shotguns
* Hats!
* Each "act" has a unique atmosphere / enemy types.

Cons:
* The game became quite repetitive towards the 8 hour mark.  There weren't enough things introduced in the late game that kept the gameplay fresh.  As a result, the game became stale 
* New Game + is literally just playing the game over again, except you get to keep your hats and unlocked characters.  I only played the first stage of NG+ before quitting. 
* I didn't see much of a reason to switch characters (on Experienced difficulty).  Party priority was Sally, Piper, Bea, and Billy, and I didn't feel like I needed to switch it up from that.  

Notes:
* If you would like to get credit for beating the game on a higher difficulty, make sure to stay at that difficulty! I played most of the game on the Experienced difficulty, which is like the 2nd to hardest, but I only got credit for the lowest difficulty that I played it on, which was normal for the first level because I didn't know how hard it was going to be.  So I feel a bit ripped off there.

Final thoughts:
It was a fun game, and I would recommend it to others, but I probably won't be coming back to it.  Definitely buy it if you are looking for about 8 hours of enjoyment out of a 10 hour playthrough!

25884931.review:
[b][i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] is a really good game with high polish and great execution, but much like [i]SteamWorld Dig[/i] it suffers from not enough depth and complexity. Lots of potential wasted here, IMO.[/b] Not to sound insulting, but Image & Form games often feel (to me) like one notch above games with mobile developement in mind. Overly simplified to a fault. When you build a game that begs to be compared and described as something like [i]XCOM[/i], you have the potential for tons of customization and sandbox-like creativity. Let me explain further.

When you reduce a tactical game down to 2D, you already lose a bit of strategy, which is fine - to a certain extent this was made up for by the brilliant bullet-bouncing/aiming system. Thats great, and beyond the superb graphics and music, thats about where the greatness ends. [b]Leveling up could not be more simple - you have no choices, no skill tree, and have no options in bonuses you recieve.[/b] It might as well be non-existant. You gain power as you win, and therefore can fight stronger/more enemies. It's a rub.

At first the loot you find is interesting until you realize that guns aren't [i]really[/i] that functionally different, and it's a simple numbers game (ie. Gun A has +1, and Gun B has +2, so Gun B it is). [b]The weapon stats increase fairly linearly, so you don't get that awesome feeling of finding rare loot, or getting something early in the game.[/b] Another note about loot - at the end of every level you have to 'open' your loot by clicking on it, which is fun for a second, but after a couple hours it feels like a mobile game. Yawn.

The hat collection is cool, and I like how you can strategize to shoot them off of enemies heads to get them. Nice. Are they functional? I don't believe they are, but I could be wrong. 

[b]I find it frustrating to give [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] a negative review, because it is really awesome and is [i]soooo close[/i] to achieving greatness.[/b] But alas, it is also so far. I want more. I want strategy like [i]XCOM[/i]. Whether it would be more base-building elements, better equipment, character customization, etc. All of this is possible in this game. In fact, the hard part of building a brilliant combat system is done. I think we just need more bells-and-whistles.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Awesome addicting combat that rewards solid strategy a la [i]XCOM[/i]
+Beautiful artwork, animation, and music
+Gotta love that [i]SteamWorld[/i] universe
+Controls are tight regardless if you use keyboard and mouse or controller
+Hat collection is cool

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Everything can be solved with money, and this is no exception; if the game were ten bucks, I could overlook a lot, but that's not the state of things, so:
-Overall things are too simple for an [i]XCOM[/i]-like game; loot is boring and linear, character customization verges on something mobile (as does a few features), no base building elements, etc.

[b]At the end of the day, considering all the DLC, [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] costs well over $20, which is quite steep for something so one-dimensional.[/b] Yes, the combat and artwork and music and atmosphere are brilliant, but after about 2-5 hours I think most people would find it repetitive and shallow.

Peace,

25784023.review:
I enjoyed SteamWorld Dig. It wasn't a game I'd play for multiple playthroughs, but it was nice. So, for my stream, I requested a key for SteamWorld Heist through my press contact. I was expecting a demo. They gave me the full game plus DLC.

But when I say that "if I could buy this game again for myself,  I would", I mean it. Because this game is 100% more up my alley.

Taking place in the same universe as SteamWorld Dig, Heist plays as a turn-based tactical shooter. There are nine characters (ten with Outsider DLC) that each bring their own unique flavor, allowing a variety of playstyles and approaches to any particular mission. Crippling mechanics and flankers give an advantage from below or behind, but explosives characters might prefer the high ground. Ricochet mechanics allow sharpshooters and snipers (and others, if you're really good at free aiming) plenty of opportunities for complex shots from safe positions. Brawlers and other heavy characters can get in the enemies' faces. And even within the same character class, your crew still has differences in weapon proficiencies and specific advantages between them. Ultimately, combined with simple but punishing level design, this creates a tactics experience that can be both meditative and relaxing on easier difficulties or missions and a genuine challenge and rage-inducing trial on harder difficulties. Equipment allows additional customization, but you have to be choosy with it; limited inventory (while a good mechanic for a challenge) is still one of the most frustrating mechanics in games of any genre. But don't worry! The cosmetic hats you can collect by lightly skimming them off the heads of your enemies take up none of your inventory! So collect away!

The story is presented in a playful western-in-space asthetic with plenty of banter and dialogue to give more substance. I wouldn't say the game is plot heavy, but it doesn't promise to me. What it does promise is the swagger and quirky humor of its thematic genre. The music contains one of the game's strongest points and weakest. In chapter completes and bars, the music is provided by Steam Powered Giraffe, a steampunk band that fits this game's flavor like a glove. In battles, the music is not intrusive or unenjoyable, but as you will be playing a lot of missions and sometimes taking a long time on turns, you will wish they had more variety there.

All-in-all, this game is not only just a game I love...but critically strong in all of its categories.

Now, if you excuse me, I need to get more steampunk space hats.

25733051.review:
Here's the short of it - it's my GOTY 2016.

It's a bit like Worms, set through the filter of a sweet space western. Everything is done almost perfectly, and i'd like to express how much i've come to love this game here.

The mechanics are extremely satisfying. It's a turn-based system on a 2D plane where you have to maneuver and aim shots, using various mechanics to insure that you're hitting without getting hit yourself. Taking cover, using line of sight(such as ricocheting bullets and arcing projectiles like grenades), and calculating damage so that the enemy lines are either crushed or so scattered that they can't muster a threatening retaliation.

But the combat is only part of what goes down when boarding a shuttle. Half of the fun is just assembling a proper team, utilizing the loadout system to either boost the strengths or cover the weaknesses of your various crewmates. Aboard the shuttles themselves is treasure, or 'swag', to find and gather. The swag itself is generally the game's currency(water; it's good for you!), but occasionally it will be weapons and items of various rarity that provide either a new mechanic for your arsenal or some kind of statistical boost. Collecting the stuff also gains you bonus experience after you get out, so there's multiple incentives to get in and out as quickly as possible. I've redone a ton of stages just trying to find rare stuff and level out characters, experimenting with new character and loadout combinations. Pro-tip, Payroll is awesome.

There are a few major arcs to the story and level design, each offering some solid enemy types that consistently add more to the shenanigans as you proceed - you've got standard mooks, but some start coming at you with shields that provide them regular cover, enemies that will scatter oil on the ground to ignite under you, melee enemies packed to explode when they die, snipers that attempt to utilize the ricochet, and so much more that I dare not spoil. They're all initially kind of intimidating, and demand that your playstyle adapt quickly to each incoming threat. It provides a pretty meaty challenge, and can feel so satisfying when a plan comes together. Better still, if you're really hurting to get through an objective, the difficulty has five or so settings that allow you to get past a mission and let you build yourself up a bit before tackling it again.

I can't emphasize enough how great it feels when you can clear a room or a threat by sheer wit and skill alone. Things like needling a rocket through a cluttered hallway to hit a target before it can kill an ally, or forcing an enemy to turn around by getting into melee so that a flanking character can crush its health bar. What helps is that most maps are randomly generated, and a lot of stages will spawn in more enemies from various entryways, so it helps to build up the adaptability and skill required to handle later stages. It's very smart about how it both teaches and rewards players.

Oh, and there are bosses, and they all kick ass. They're all super distinct and memorable, with some kind of added gimmick that may or may not hint at stuff you might encounter more regularly as the game proceeds. They can be a legitimate struggle, as more and more enemies start forcing their way into the engagement, putting pressure onto the player to finish the boss as quickly as they can before they get overwhelmed. And when their health reaches zero, and the sparks fly, and their body blasts in every direction, the soundtrack kicks in, letting their sweet melodies follow you out; one arm carrying the swag, and the other raised in victory.

On the subject of audio, this game has an excellent soundtrack - mostly played very quietly in the background, picking up when enemies are nearby, it's a very western and sci-fi series of tracks. Steam-Powered Giraffe did a great deal of the music, which you hear as fanfare for defeating a boss and in the various bars spanning the game. On more than one occasion i'd found myself stopping to just listen, which I think says a great deal more than what i've done for ambience in the past. The weapons and sound effects are also all very crisp and excellent, very distinct sounds that leave you satisfied when you scrap some poor sap thinking he's safe behind that barrel.

The visuals are a mixed bag, but I think they do a great job of showing you everything you need to see. There's even a minimap you can deploy, in case you ever get confused about things like swag, doors, etc. All of the non-mook types of robots have very memorable designs, and they're given a little more creative freedom since everything is a robot and doesn't have to conform to any particular type of body. Note again the aforementioned character Payroll, whose legs are literally just a big wheel, like Gizmoduck.

The story isn't particularly grand, but for a game like this, it only needed a modest amount to get the player going - the gameplay was enough to keep me involved, but the presentation of the story was quite excellent. So many little touches with the dialogue and the direction the robots were taking in design allows it to stay fresh all the way through to the end.

There are some other little disappointments, like character features switching sides when they turn around(Piper's 'hair' shifts from either side of her head), or maybe a thing or two about the story itself, but honestly if that's the worst I have to say about the game then i'd say you've got a pretty solid game on your hands...at least, for me.

I haven't had this much fun with a title since maybe 2013 with Monaco. I've been recommending this to everyone I know that plays games, and I don't see myself stopping anytime soon. It's legitimately a 10/10 for me, and I hope that it can provide even half of what I experienced to you if you do try it.

25704711.review:
Highly enjoyable low-stress XCOM-like. Very interesting hybrid of the aforementioned game and Worms: It's got great customization, inventory management, good weapon variety, and very well put together leveling-up system. The gameplay itself may seem very simplistic but it has interesting depth; chiefly with unit position (As all your battles take place aboard usually cramped spaceship interiors) but more entertainingly enough with bullet ricochet. Pulling off a well-executed (Or outright lucky) trickshot in this game is incredibly satisfying. The different characters also fulfill traditional class roles that we all know and love (Specific abilities and access to specific weapon types, as well as suitably different stats).

Apart from the game itself the art style, animation, and catchy soundtrack really tie it all together. It's *loaded* with character and I absolutely adore how charming (And surprisingly bleak) the setting is. I was also surprised by how satisfying the sound effects are.

Anyways I'm enjoying this game a lot. It's charming and easy to get into without being shallow and repetative: There's a surprising amount of depth both inside and outside of the combat. An easy recommendation for strategy game fans.

It's also family-friendly, and a great game for parents/grandparents to play with  the kids; but make no mistake, when the kids have been consigned to their beds the grown ups will be fighting over who's playing this one!

25581433.review:
An original and well polished turn based strategy. It's not a particularly deep game but it's a well polished one and together those traits make it very approachable and easy to recommend to anyone.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
  [*]Approachable RPG. Health, Damage, and Move are the only stats.
  [*]Manually aim your skills. Shots can bounce off walls and obstacles. Sniper characters and pull off some fun trick shots.
  [*]Enjoyable soundtrack. I love the main theme.
  [*]Difficulty effects reward. This goes a long way to removing most grind from the game. Just go back to an easier level and ramp up the difficulty.
  [*]New Game+. Start with all characters at level 0 and keep all unlocked hats.
  [*]Fully rebindable controls. Even supports rebinding controllers! WHY IS THIS NOT NOT A STANDARD FEATURE IN GAMES!
  [*]Wonderful art style. 
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
  [*]Can't get the Steamworld Dig hat. On 3DS if you have Dig installed you can unlock a free hat. I really like this hat. I own Dig on Steam. It's installed. No hat. Very disappointed.
  [*]Lacks and significant customization.
  [*]Character progression is predetermined.
  [*]There's a lot of overlap between the character's skills. I only actually used about five of the ten characters available.
  [*]With some exceptions the 'Sharpshooter' class of weapons are the only ones that get laser sights.
  [*]The soundtrack does not contain any of the combat or ambient music. Only the tavern songs.
  [*]Some of the tavern songs are ehhhhh... They do a good job setting the mood in game though.
[/list]

All in all, worth the asking price. Heck, I already own it on 3DS but bought it again.

25334557.review:
I played SteamWorld Dig quite a while ago mainly because, despite the fact that it looked like something I’d enjoy, people kept praising it. Unfortunately the game didn’t meet my expectations but I still found it to be a good game overall. All this to say that when I heard that there was a new game of the SteamWorld series coming out I got a little bit skeptical. When I eventually saw the game itself I knew the chances of enjoying this were far greater than the previous one. [i]”Inspired by classics like XCOM and Worms”[/i], they caught my interest right there.

[b][u]Story:[/u][/b]

In SteamWorld Heist you get to play as Piper, the captain of a ship of Cowbots which is on the run from Royalist forces due to alleged acts of treason, piracy and smuggling. The Royalist forces are led by the Queen and are committed to rebuilding their planet that was shattered a long time ago but, despite their noble intentions, they tend to extort other Cowbots for resources in order to achieve their goal. 

Our brave heroes decide it is enough and it’s time to help out the common folk so they start their journey by ridding the Outskirts of the Scrappers, a group of cowbots who use any spare parts of their fallen enemies to either upgrade themselves or increase their ranks. From there forward, the story escalates at a steady pace and along the way you’ll meet other friendly cowbots which can join your crew, each of them having their own unique character and background. 

[b][u]Gameplay:[/u][/b]

As I’ve mentioned before, the devs were inspired by games such as XCOM and Worms, but in essence I’d say they only took 2 key elements from both of those games. From the recent XCOM reboot, they’ve took the 2 moves per turn system in which you can move a character twice within a certain range, move once and then attack or use an ability or simply attacking which will cancel the second phase of that turn. From the Worm series what they’ve adapted to their formula was making it so that, in contrast with XCOM for example, instead of relying on a percentage chance of hitting a target, it is actually the player who aims the weapons and the various different items and abilities. This not only imposes another layer of skill on the player but it also makes the combat more interesting and fun due to the fact that a lot of projectiles (bullets, grenades, etc) can ricochet from walls. 

The combat itself revolves around taking cover behind shields and other obstacles, tactics rather than pure luck based on hit chances, keeping an eye on alarm countdowns which make you proceed faster in order to not get hit by enemy reinforcements or turret emplacements. There weapon and enemy variety is just enough to keep things interesting, from close quarters weapons and enemies to long range fights and even teleporting enemies that can surprise you. The same goes for your crew, given the fact that each has their own set of abilities and play style.

As far as controls scheme go, i the game is a lot easier to play with a controller rather than with a keyboard and mouse, simply because with the controller you just move your right analog stick in the direction you want to attack, while on keyboard and mouse you have to click with the mouse and play around a bit in order to get the proper trajectory you want.

Besides the combat part of the game, which is what you’ll spend most of your time doing, between missions you can walk around your ship and talk to your crew and go to the space map and select your next destination. On the space map you can go to shops to buy new equipment (including hats), go straight for the main missions or do some side missions. Each mission takes place on a ship with a randomly generated layout and it can consist on collecting [i]”swag”[/i] (loot containers), killing a certain amount of enemies or rescuing someone and after that you need to move all your crew to an escape pod in order to evacuate.You can always go back and replay previous missions in order to level up your crew if you’re having trouble. Upon completing a mission you’ll get EXP which enables you to level up your characters, thus unlocking new abilities. Depending on the amount of swag you gather during a mission you’ll also be able to open containers which can either have water, which acts as a form of currency, treasures or weapons and other equipment such as hats. 

[b][u]Visuals & Audio:[/u][/b]

As far as visuals go I don’t think there is really much that needs to be said, they are clean, good looking and fit the theme perfectly. I don’t think I’ve ever seen such good looking steampunk robots ever before. The change in scenery as you move to new zones is also very notable and the game never loses its charm.

Now, one of the biggest things about this game for me is the music. I looked it up and apparently the devs have worked with [i]Steam Powered Giraffe[/i], a group which I had never heard before but after looking them up I’m even more glad I played this game, they do an excellent job in setting the right mood at the right times in the game, mainly when you visit the bars and you can see the actual group there playing. Yet, one thing that I wish was in the game was voice acting, I feel like it could add a whole new level of character to the various characters in the game but alas..

If you’ve read this far you’ve probably got the feeling that I thoroughly enjoyed SteamWorld Heist, if you just skipped until the end then let me fill you in.

[h1][b]If you enjoyed SteamWorld Dig world design and theme you’ll probably like this game as well. If you’re into turn-based tactical games that focus on combat chances are you’ll have a great time. The game does get kind of repetitive the longer you play but, at least for me, the combat was fun and challenging enough to keep me going. If you’re just looking for a charming, easy to pick up and play, amazing, gorgeous, fun and cheerful game with solid mechanics and a great steampunk setting I highly recommend you pick this one up.[/b][/h1]

25156774.review:
[h1] Lead your rag-tag group of cowbots into battle against the Scrappers and their nefarious technomancer leader, Chop Sue, and the blue-oiled Royalists and their monstrous monarch. Shoot, duck behind cover, use skills and items, and pick up loot –all while you nod your head to the western twang of the soundtrack. [/h1]

https://youtu.be/aK1atQC0GHM

.Story.
The Earth has been broken into a million pieces and the steam-powered residents that had lived on its surface have taken to the stars.

You are a gentle cowbot, a moisture farmer by trade, and your attempts to eke out a living are thwarted by the Royalists and a gang of vicious bots known as the Scrappers alike.

And so you turn to a life of adventure, the liberation of the common folk, and more importantly, heists!

.Gameplay.
You can use your keyboard and mouse or a gamepad. I prefer the latter, so I’ll be talking about those controls from here on out. The majority of gameplay occurs on the battlefield, though the moments between battle will be spent on the main map, which exists as a series of space ships connected. You can travel to each location by selecting it and more open up to you after you beat the preceding level. 

There are two types of areas: battle field and hub (where you can buy equipment and recruit units). So, if you’re looking for a game where you can explore the rich universe, then this isn’t the game for you.

Before the quest begins, you’re given an information screen that shows you three icons at the top: whether you collected the Epic Swag, the number of units you can take into battle, and the number of stars you can get/have gotten respectively. Underneath that, you can find the objectives that you need to complete and are also given the option to change difficulty. 

The different difficulties include casual, regular, experienced, veteran, and elite. Changing difficulty effects the penalty for failing a mission (you lose a percentage of your stored gallons from 0-50%), the number of enemies, how much damage enemies do, and their health. The higher the difficulty, the higher these stats, but also the more bonus experience you’ll receive at the end of the battle, so there’s a measure of risk versus reward here.

Once you’re satisfied with the difficulty setting, you can change your loadout. Here, you select the units you want to use as well as their equipment. Units have four equipment slots: a weapon, two utility slots, and a hat. The utility slots can be used for armor, grenades, first aid kits, etc, while the hat is purely cosmetic.

Quests consist of one main objective plus one (or two side, depending on the number of stars you can get) objective that usually (read: almost always) has to do with gathering the Epic Swag available on that level

And now, combat.

Combat is turn-based and you can swap behind units mid-turn if need be. You need to aim in order to shoot other units, so if you aren’t very good at estimating distances and line of site in pixels, then you’re SOL. Some guns have a laser sites available, however, so you can play with those until you get better at eyeballing distances.

You’ll  lead a small team—two to three units—through the bowels of an enemy ship and teamwork is key in order to make sure everyone makes it to the extraction point in one piece. Objects such as barrels can be used as cover. When attacking, you’re told exactly how much damage you’ll do (or a range if applicable).

After your glorious victory, you get to open up all of the swag bags and containers you picked up. Inside you’ll find Gallons, equipment, and objects solely for selling to make a profit. Epic Swag containers cannot be picked up more than once.

Experience is awarded at the end of every successful battle. It’s divided evenly between your units. 
You’re also given a star rating based on: objective(s) (two stars), Epic Swag collected (one star), and any casualties (subtract one star per death).

*If a unit dies, they are reassembled once you go back to your ship. These units receive no experience.
Reputation is used to hire more crew. New crew starts at level 0, so it’s a good idea to go back to earlier stages in order to get them up to speed.

.Atmosphere.
SteamWorld ‘s brightly-coloured sprites are detailed and nice to look at. The Scrappers’ ships’ mechanical innards are appropriately dismal, and the pubs and bars that serve as your information hubs are contrastingly warm and well-lit. They also feature fantastic music via a “live band” of bots that sing wholly original tunes.

The game does a wonderful job of creating a grungy, dystopian world where the general populace consists of steam-powered robots and something as commonplace as water has become a currency. The bots “speak” in gibberish reminiscent of the older Legend of Zelda titles or even Animal Crossing and the script is rife with humour.

.Longevity.
It’s taken me about five hours to beat the first area—including the challenge stages, which are unlocked by playing through normally—on “experienced” and I managed to get all of the stars while I was at it. I could easily see sinking the promised 15-20 hours into this game, however.

The difficulties would normally offer greater longevity, but given that the difficulty can be changed at the beginning of a battle without affecting the reputation rating you got previously on another difficulty, there’s no real reason to play on a more difficult setting except to challenge yourself. 

I’ll update this with my final verdict once I’ve completed the game.

.Pros and Cons. 
[list]
[*]Amazing music and art style.
[*]Humorous writing.
[*]Limited equipment slots force you to strategize.
[*]Combat is satisfying, especially if you bounce bullets off of the stage in order to make kills.
[*]Did I mention that bullets can ricochet? Because that’s really fun.
[*]Unit classes that have different passive abilities.

[*]The game as a whole is very linear. There’s no sort of choice in what stages you play; you just play them one after the other. The objectives are also very linear, usually involving destroying/collecting an objective and then evacuating. Your unit automatically learns skills upon levelling up. 
[*]Battles swiftly become a matter of running from point A to point B because there’s no point in killing all of the enemies seeing as you don’t receive anything extra for doing so. Enemies also become much, much stronger than your units on higher difficulties, so avoidance is the best tactic one can employ.
[*]You run out of inventory space very, very quickly. This is more of an annoyance than anything.
[*]All of these complaints above are minor. My largest problem was the alarm system. After it is first introduced, the game uses the concept into the ground and, rather than being a challenge, it becomes a hassle. The alarms call in more enemies after counting down from [some number] to zero. The clock ticks by every time a turn passes. This would be fine if it didn’t take so long to navigate the map—partially because your units can’t move very far and still deal with enemies, partially because some maps are simply a maze of rooms for no damn reason—and it wasn’t so easy to be overrun as a result.
This is, of course, a personal complaint, but it should be taken into consideration because you’ll run into these frequently. 
[/list]

.Bottom line.
The pros outweigh the cons for sure and, if you can forgive repetitive gameplay and a linear world, you’ll enjoy SteamWorld Heist. The cast is quirky and loveable, the music is great, and strategizing is fun.

With a range of difficulties and additional challenge stages, there’s something for strategy lovers of every skill level here. The game is definitely worth a look if you’re even a little bit interested in the genre.

25024255.review:
Coming from the indie studio Image & Form, SteamWorld Heist is a delightful take on the turn based strategy genre. The pseudo sequel to 2013’s SteamWorld Dig, Heist shares many elements from the modern XCOM and Shadowrun series, albeit in the 2D space, and is just as good as its contemporaries.

Having never played the first game in the series, Heist was a great introduction to a world that is very reminiscent of the Borderlands and Firefly universes. The wonderful meld of western/sci fi and steampunk is a great match and is wonderfully realized in Heist. Special shout out to Steam Powered Giraffe who orchestrated a tremendous soundtrack that only enhances the setting of the game. Tonally, the game is very consistent and forms a solid identity.

One of the main hooks for Heist is that every level is procedurally generated. This allows for multiple playthroughs and grinding to avoid getting stale as fast since level layout and enemy location will be different each time. The other back of the box feature is that unlike XCOM, Heist’s gameplay is based purely on skill rather than luck. Don’t get me wrong, I love XCOM, but boy is it frustrating when you miss a shot with 95% accuracy and you have your gun square in the alien’s face. In SteamWorld Heist, you aim your shots, so the accuracy is completely up to you, which is quite refreshing. The game allows for both long and short ranged characters, but I found long range to be much more successful (especially when you have a rifle with a laser scope).

The game throws enough environmental and enemy variety at you to keep the 10+ hour adventure fresh and well-paced throughout. There is a story there for those who want it, and while charming, I found it took a backseat to the rock solid mechanics that the game presents you. Speaking of great mechanics, I especially loved the fast forward feature when moving your team around. When you select a teammate to move around, you can skip the running animation entirely by holding down a button. This was a wonderful addition as it can make certain missions much less tedious as a result.

SteamWorld Heist is an entertaining sidescrolling, turn based strategy game that can be played as casually or as hardcore as you’d like. The art and music are lovely and the world is quite amusing. There is plenty of game to be had here, especially if you plan on doing New Game+. In addition, there is a somewhat sizeable DLC at a nominal price that is well worth the investment. I greatly enjoyed myself with Heist and hope to see more games from this universe in the future from a great up and coming studio.

24776990.review:
特别赞的一款游戏，十分上瘾。
游戏是横版回合制射击游戏，特点在于利用子弹在墙上的弹射杀敌，而且其他任何方面的制作都十分优秀，让人爱不释手。

10个可用角色（其中DLC一个）技巧特征优缺点十分鲜明有用，没有坐冷板凳的角色，人物靠升级获得技能。

武器和道具种类十分丰富，根据玩家偏好不同，不会出现某把武器称霸的情况，而且不同武器针对不同角色也会发挥出不同的效果，譬如士兵后期有个被动技能是一回合不动则可以射击两次，给他配上移动后不允许射击的加特林机枪，可以达到高于其他角色三倍的伤害，但移动后无法射击常常会陷入被敌人追着打无法还手的尴尬境地。

不像《无主之地》和《以撒的结合》里很多是以花哨甚至是坑爹为主，这款游戏里的武器和道具几乎全都有用，偏好不同仅体现在玩家的游戏策略上。敌人、NPC、地形的种类也十分丰富，同时游戏几乎没有随机性的设计，主要以玩家的策略，而不是赌博（譬如以撒里的老虎机，挺进地牢里的宝箱这种设定都是没有的）来通关。

游戏难度很友好，一共4个难度，如果认真去玩，并不会有太多挫折感，而且因为每次重打时，每关房间布局都会随机排列，因此即便在同一关输上几次或刷钱刷经验刷评价也不会觉得很腻烦。
进入游戏后不会遇到哪怕1秒的读取，而且几乎你做每个动作都会给你保存一下（这也是防止玩家用S/L大法无脑过关），所以游戏过程行云流水让人无法停下。

一周目不完全收集，倒数第二个难度认真玩通大概16个小时，十分过瘾。加上DLC，把人物再练到满级大概4个小时不到。

游戏的画面十分精致，这款游戏不得不提到的就是音乐。这算不上大作的精品里居然有7首以上专门演唱的歌曲，应该都是原创，因为配词很符合剧情；每进入一间酒吧就有一首曲子，游戏里大概有6个酒吧，每打败一个BOSS也有一首庆祝的曲子，游戏大概3个boss。

很久没遇到如此让人上瘾而且喜爱的游戏了（当然也有上瘾而且不喜欢的游戏，譬如星露谷物语，MD简直毒品）。极度好评！强烈推荐大家都去试试这款精品！

24775833.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
SteamWorld Heist has been developed and published by Image & Form. It’s the dev team’s second game to include this setting, after SteamWorld Dig and while they feature different genres, both present us with colorful and likeable characters within a fascinating steampunk-from-outer-space world.
 
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
I’ve seen few hybrids of strategy and platforming outside of the well established Worms franchise. I have to say that SteamWorld Heist managed to impress me with its over the top cast of pirate robots and constant carefully planned action sequences aboard enemy ships and bases. You have a complex customization system when it comes to your mechanized crew. You get to shape them by your own taste and change everything from their inventory, appearance and even their skillsets. The turn-based shooting mechanics work fine once you get used to them and the scaling difficulty. 
 
For a 2D side-scroller, the graphical diversity is more than enough and few levels seem to repeat themselves while the weapon effects offer even more eye-candy. The game’s soundtrack features some very catchy tunes which only add to the game’s sci-fi atmosphere. No complaints in this regard.
 
[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Challenging gameplay emphasising on strategic thinking
+ Memorable cast of characters and enviroments
+ Steam Achievements & Trading Cards
 
[h1]Cons[/h1]
- No multiplayer
- Slightly overpriced
 
[h1]Result / Final thoughts[/h1]
Even after several hours, I was still not even a bit bored by this title. It truly serves as a good example of what you can do with these particular hybrid gameplay mechanics once you replace homicidal worms with space robot pirates. Comic relief was also present in decent amount and the game does provide both Cards and Achievements. Apart from the total lack of an MP mode, the price tag feels like too much is being asked even if SteamWorks Heist definitely feels like a more polished indie title than Steam has gotten used to. At the time of this writing, the title is still being sold for 20 dollars/euros (+more for DLC). With a modest price drop or when bought on Sale, it becomes a very good deal for a charming strategy game.
 
[b]Rating 8/10[/b]
 
[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews]Imperial Reviews[/url] and [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Cubbes]Cubbes[/url].[/quote]

Steamworld Heist is a game that has something to offer for all types of players whether you’re a beginner or a veteran to turn-based strategy games.  A lot of what I think this game does well has to do with the fact that it simplifies this genre, but at the same time, manages to make it fun.  Of course, this means that this game doesn’t have as many deep and innovative features compared to other similar games, but honestly, I don’t think this game needed it.  To me, this simplification created more room to make a game that is accessible to play for anyone and I think that reason alone is enough for me to highly recommend playing this game.  So if you’re looking to step foot into the turn-based strategy game genre for the first time and would like to play a game that is not only friendly to beginners but also fun to play as well, then look no further than Steamworld Heist.

24718034.review:
In short: buy this game

In long: buuuuuuuuuuy thiiiiiiiiiis gaaaaaaaaaaaaaaameeeeeeeeeeee

In detail: a gorgeous steampunk robot Firely XCOM without the RNG shenanigans. The theme is fantastic, the art beautiful, the characters great, and the gameplay fun and rewarding. You manually aim all your shots, so you miss not because you didn't pray to RNGesus, but because your aim was off. The ricochet mechanic means you can do insane shots that involve bouncing a bullet off two pieces of cover, taking some poor bot's hat off (because it's shiny and you want it), and then hitting some other bot square in his face. Weapon design has good variety with enough special guns with unique characteristics that it's always interesting, and unlike XCOM (where you field your A-team wherever possible), mixing up your squad composition is necessary as squad size varies between missions, and different characters' strengths will play into different level layouts. Also, most of the levels are prodecurally generated, so you'll only see the same ship twice on special missions (ie, boss fights).

Overall a fantastic game.

24683707.review:
Отличная тактическая пошаговая игра, с необычным для жанра взлядом "сбоку". Да и в целом у игры много хороших и свежих идей, и она в целом очень крутая и как игра, и как тактическая пошаговая рпг. 

Но почему-то на языке вертится неприятное слово "Ремесленная". Это ни в коем случае не умаляет заслуги разработчиков. Просто это уже вторая их игра, которая отдает таким неприятным душком легкой бездушности(первая игра steamworld dig). 

И я не знаю, как объяснить это ощущение. Просто такое чувство, что разработчики собирали игру не как что-то свое, а как некого франкенштейна, просто хорошо его загримировали, подыскали красивую кожу и обильно облили духами. 
Не то чтобы игры совсем плохие, но первая мне не понравилась отчасти из-за этого, а в heist просто "зашла" мне, поскольку я давно искал что-нибудь крутое, новое и про тактику. Да и в целом игра намного лучше скроена.

Очень рекомендую, если Вам нравится подобная стилистика и пошаговые бои с упором на тактику. Одна только механика рикошетов чего стоит. Причем самое приятное, неплохой баланс сложности и длины самой игры. Она и не слишком короткая и не слишком длинная, а если вам будет слишком трудно/легко, вы можете всегда изменить сложность. За это штрафов особых нет, только поощрение.

В общем, круто. Рекомендую.

24553529.review:
I loved this game!
I am a big fan of turn based strategy games and this game definitely delivered fun and sometines deeply strategic and difficult challenges. But what I enjoyed the most is that this game is absolutely non-problematic in all ways! It's not racist nor sexist, which is a constantly disturbing and disgusting problem in almost any other game I've played. But this game is full of fleshed out female characters, and also lots of non-binary gender neutral characters as well! Not ONCE did this game offend in any way, which to me is extremely refreshing. The wonderfully spellbinding effect of a really good game is usually brutally cut off by some sexist aspect of the game, which reminds you that it was exclusively made by straight white men that do not realise their privileges. It's clear to me that this is not the case at Image & Form. Either they are all aware of the social problems among us, or there is at least one among them that steadily kept sexist content out of the way.

This game was a breath of fresh air!

24228904.review:
SteamWorld Heist:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
  
A world shattered into millions of pieces forces its inhabitants into space. They are known as Cowbots and they survive by farming moisture and mining what they can from near to exhausted land. But that is not all, gangs of nasty Scrappers are ranging across the galaxy. Their major talent is to acquire scrap-metals and water from hardworking Cowbots! On top of that, they need to avoid the bullies, Diesel Royalists, who run the galaxy! But there is more, much more. . .  Bots, it’s time for you to enter SteamWorld Heist!

SteamWorld Heist is a 2D turn-based strategy game where you take control of Piper Faraday, a well-known smuggler/occasional pirate and her crew. First, you will need to choose the gameplay difficulty, from casual to elite. Your first mission is a very good tutorial to get familiar with the controls and how the game works.  At the end of the tutorial, you will acquire your first crew members. . .  the magnificent “Seabrass!” Then you will get your first look at your spaceship and meet Wonky, your faithful pilot! 

On the spaceship top level, where Wonky is steering your vessel, you will find your operations table with a space map. From here, you can activate your next mission; docking at bars, arms traders vessels and other important destinations. Each mission will have three clear stars underneath them. If you managed to achieve all objectives within the mission, you will be rewarded with three gold stars. Try to accumulate as many stars as possible as you will need them later on to unlock new destinations.

Now that you are ready to launch a mission, select one from the space map; see the objectives, how many crew members you can take into the battle with you and get straight to the loadout menu. In the loadout, you will have four inventory spots to fill in. When you are happy with your selection, jump into the mission, which is procedurally generated. Wonky will carefully dock onto the enemy ship, drop you off and the rest is all up to you!

The really big difference in this turn-based strategy game is the ability to manually aim the guns of your characters directly at your enemies or even use the wall for your bullets to ricochet and hit an enemy robot. You will be able to hide behind barrels, but avoid using explosive barrels as a cover - Your robot might become scrap-metal very quickly! Make sure to pick up bags and chests of loot as they contain either water, weapons or armour. When you achieve the main objective(s) make your way to the escape pod and your mission will end.

At the end of the mission, your character will own experience points which go towards levelling up. Then you will find out what new items, or how much water, is in the loot you picked up. If you earned a fair bit of water, try to head up to bars or arms dealers to purchase new goodies, as water is a currency in SteamWorld Heist.

I really like the 2D artworks in this game. Control-wise, either you use the gamepad or the mouse and keyboard; they are easy to learn. Good story and fun dialogues.

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

-	Great 2D artworks
-	Procedurally generated levels 
-	Good Story and dialogues
-	Very good gameplay and easy to learn
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~  

-	Your characters will not avoid or block a melee attack 
-	Does not have the ability to compare stats when you buy a new weapon

SteamWorld Heist is a great turn-based strategy game. If it’s your first game it that genre, you will be hooked! If you’re a veteran it this genre, you love it!

9/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

24198785.review:
[h1][u][b]Introduction[/b][/u][/h1]


[b]Steamworld Heist[/b] is a side-scrolling, turn-based strategy game that is set on a space sci-fi/steampunk environment with its gameplay being inspired by the combination of both the X-COM and Worms series.


[h1][u][b]Gameplay[/b][/u][/h1]


As you start the game, you will be introduced to [b]five (5) levels of difficulty[/b] that suits your preference. Those are "Casual", "Regular", "Experienced", "Veteran", and "Elite", and as it increases in difficulty, it also yields more bonus experience the harder it is (and you can change it before you start any mission).  

At your disposal is a [b]space pirate crew[/b] composed of robots referred to as [i]"steambots"[/i] and is led by [b]Captain Piper Faraday[/b]. Along the way, you will find recruitable characters that can be enlisted by either proving your worth through the amount of [i]"reputation"[/i] you have, paying them with [i]"swag"[/i], or in some cases will join you by their own accord.

The gameplay focuses on mission-based levels which yields reputation in the form of golden stars that indicates how well you performed on that certain level once you clear it.There are objectives that you need to follow and once they are cleared, an escape route will be opened for your members to finish the mission. You can also find loot called [b]"swag bags"[/b] and [b]"epic swag"[/b] in these stages that appears in a form of a sack and a box respectively, and its contents are unknown until you have revealed them at the stage's end.

The way the [b]battle system[/b] works in the game is [b]turn-based[/b] and each unit can do [b]two types of action per turn[/b]. Moving through the area and [b]re-positioning[/b] yourself while in the orange highlighted area will allow to still be able do an action after moving, but if you [b]"sprint"[/b] (represented by blue areas), your character will end its turn once you move on its position.
While you are able to do action, [b]you can either fire your weapon, use your secondary equipment, or use your "active abilities".[/b] 

[b]Each weapon has its own merits, damage area, and aiming type[/b] which are all specified on their descriptions. In accordance to this, your characters can only equip certain types of weapon available for them (for example, Piper can only use Sharpshooter and Handgun weapons). Another type of equipment are the [b]hats and secondary equipment[/b], and unlike weapons, any character will be able to equip them (though hats are purely for fashion, while the secondary equipment has their respective uses).

Upon [b]finishing the mission[/b], you are will [b]receive the reputation[/b] according to what objectives you have cleared and an additional star per epic swag you get minus the number of fallen members. You will also be able to unlock your loots and reveal what item they might be and receive [b]awarded experience points[/b] that is distributed evenly to all alive crew members after the mission. When a crew member levels-up, they will get either a passive or active skill that will help through your future endeavors.



[h1][u][b]The Pros[/b][/u][/h1]

[list]

    [*][b]Fun and Challenging Battle System[/b] - I really love the mechanics of their battle system as well as its weapon physics (like the ricocheting of the bullets and the splash damage from explosives), and even enacts the unsteadiness of the aim which requires both calculation and perfect timing of the player (which further heightens the challenge). It also has that added satisfaction when you land a calculated no-scope MLG pro shot, and that surprise factor when you accidentally hit an enemy that wasn't planned. Overall, it brings a very wholesome gameplay that makes you wanting more and more.

    [*][b]Tons of Content[/b] - From the numerous items, weapons and equipment (and swag) for you to collect, to the various characters available to recruit and play as, and the dozens of challenging missions that you can engage on, you can easily have a day’s worth of hours in gameplay time that awaits you. Oh, and the hats. Have I mentioned that there are various hats (like cat-on-top hat or some anime-related hat) available for you to suit-up your steambots?

    [*][b]Brilliant Soundtracks[/b] - Not only that the sound effects perfectly fits the sci-fi/steampunk nature of the game's theme, it also showcases some really nice songs/soundtracks that catches the ambiance of what a classic midnight bar should be. My favorite track is [i]"Honeybee"[/i] by [b]Steam Powered Giraffe[/b].

    [*][b]Clean Game Graphics[/b] - Similar to the developer's earlier game (SteamWorld Dig), this new entry to the series presents a very clean art design throughout the whole game which is something that I always expect a game would have since not only it looks visually appealing, but also prevents possible confusion that players might encounter in terms of either the game mechanics or menus. 

[/list] 


[h1][u][b]The Cons[/b][/u][/h1]

[list]

    [*][b]Lack of Ability Choices[/b] - To be clear, I am pertaining to the lack of "skill trees" that are normally available in role-playing games. While the game is great at its current set-up, I do think that it would be more enjoyable for players to be able to customize their preferred characters rather than blindly waiting for the abilities/power-ups unlock as they level-up. For example, you kept on playing a certain character that you got early in the game because you already invested the experience points to that one just to know that another character is more suited to your preferences/play-style. 

    [*][b]No Co-op/Multi-player Mode[/b] - Unlike the X-COM and Worms games, both of which inspired the battle system of this game, the game only has single-player story mode available (at least during this review has been posted), in which is pretty important in terms of replayability and gives its players the option to enjoy the game with their family, friends or even duke it out with their rivals.

    [*][b]Repetitive Gameplay[/b] - Same old nemesis by the games from this genre. While the game is very fun and challenging that will occupy you for hours and hours of gameplay, it doesn't deny the fact that the same gameplay is presented during the course of the game. I was actually excited when I reached one the point of the game where a certain NPC tells you about a "brawl club" that you can join in since it might be a mini-game/mode added that is different from the regular battles. And while that mission did introduce a new part of the game, where it introduced a three-way battle between you and two other factions, the battle premise is no different which was disappointing in a certain way. 

[/list] 


[h1][u][b]Final Thoughts[/b][/u][/h1]

For those who are fond of turn-based games, this game is easily a [b]MUST-BUY[/b]. And for the people who even have the slightest of interest of playing, it is worth the try and am pretty sure you will love it.

[b]Rating[/b] - 9.4/10 

[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/elitegives]Elite Giveaways[/url], check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA games.[/quote]

24169179.review:
SteamWorld Heist had actually been on my radar for quite a while. Mentioned by Austin Walker on The Giant Beastcast podcast earlier this year, the phrase “2D X-Com” set my hopes high. Not having a 3DS, I had to anxiously wait for it to come to PC. Every month or so I’d looked to see if there was even a release date, until finally, recently, it popped up on Steam.

Made by Image & Form, it’s been my turn-based tactical game of choice. These are the same developers who did SteamWorld Dig, which has the same aesthetic and charm, but is an adventure game in real-time. In Heist you play as a captain of a mercenary group of steambots (robots powered by steam). You’re a bit of a rogue with a heart of gold. The Han Solo of steambot piracy. It’s all presented charmingly in 2D, except for a couple of cutscenes. Each mission has turn-based combat also from a 2D perspective, and it takes some of the baseline mechanics from the recent X-Com series and repurposes them. The two mainstays are a cover system, and an action point system tied to movement.

Here’s the catch, where things break from X-Com or other turn-based cover shooters: you’re the one lining up your shots. No percentage based shooting, no hidden dice rolls. It’s all based on your ability to line up shots, in a very Worms-like manner, and have them connect. There’s a strong focus on being able to ricochet shots, in addition to using cover, which has a really enjoyable kinetic feel to it. I found myself turning my head to the side to try to line up shots. Pulling off a long shot, or a shot with a ricochet, is a blast of endorphins for me. It’s a “problem solved” moment, where a tactical challenge was faced and defeated.

Your character’s aim of each shot does ‘float’, for lack of a better term, up and down just enough to add to the challenge but not unfairly. There’s a level of anticipation while you’re trying to line it up. And while some guns have a laser sight, most do not. Not really a problem with close range guns like shotguns, but bouncing explosives and pistols each present a challenge and heighten the stakes.

Additionally, you also have a roster of characters that have different activatable abilities and strengths. And that last bit might actually be more crucial than I’m giving it credit, as it really added to my enjoyment in switching and exploring the different classes (for the most part — sorry Bea!). They offered enough variety and provided some different solutions to the missions you run into.

All of this has me actually considering a 2nd run. Most of that has to do with the tactical layer. The engagements were fun to solve and making those shots never got old. The missions themselves had enough variety, and the overall length was solid. I finished the game on the default difficulty level (Experienced) in 14 hours. Playing a couple missions here and there was easy and enjoyable, and while I was ready for things to end, I wouldn’t mind restarting on a harder difficulty.
I didn’t find the story particularly engaging, but the bits of humor scattered throughout were amusing enough. The music was a mixed bag as the general background and battle music was a little too monotonous, but some of the songs you heard in the bars or at the end were great and brought a light-hearted tone. The visuals speak for themselves and the animations were well done and brought their own charms as well.

In closing, X-Com or Final Fantasy Tactics, this is not, and thank goodness. Not that I don’t want more of those games (see Arcadian Atlas for a modern hopeful at recreating the latter), but I definitely want turn-based games going in more directions. Using 2D physics is a fun way to mix the genre up. I‘d love to see this concept revisited, and possibly expanded upon.

24136336.review:
手残花了十多个小时通关第一周目，不得不说这是个非常不错的游戏。其大致玩法类似于枪战版的百战天虫，通过回合制控制自己的角色通过关卡。
剧情方面就是老套的机械英雄拯救世界吧。不过玩法是一个亮点。这里推荐手柄进行游戏，可以玩的很畅快。

每个回合控制的角色有一次移动阶段和一次行动阶段，必须先移动再行动。移动阶段每个角色有一个冲刺距离和移动距离，冲刺距离大概是奔跑距离的两倍，分别用蓝线和黄线表示。如果进行冲刺，则无法进行行动阶段。行动阶段则可以使用自己身上的物品或者开枪射击。如果任务中玩家控制两个以上的角色，可以随时切换角色进行任意阶段。
角色走到掩体旁边会自动下蹲降低被击率，所有的武器在瞄准时会上下抖动增加射击难度，似乎越强大的武器抖动效果越强。唯一需要用到的射击技术应该就是子弹的反弹技巧了，比如狙击枪的超远程多次反弹击杀。
每名队员有独特的属性和技能，比如船长可以鼓舞相邻的队员使其攻击力上升，胖子受到伤害就会被激怒，下次攻击上升。每名队员能够持有的武器也不同，除了手枪通用以外，每名队员有固定的步枪类型。除了武器以外，每个队员有两个物品栏，可以持有医疗包、手雷等辅助物品。这些装备可以通过关卡掠夺而来，也可以在商店购买。装备简单地划分了1-10个等级和普通/稀有两个品质，越高级的装备越后期才能拿到，属性也越变态。而稀有物品一般带有特殊效果，有好有坏。
BGM很不错，似乎有十几首吧。可惜每个队员没有CV只有机械音。

接下来谈谈帽子……[spoiler]说实话我真的不知道这东西有什么卵用，帽子收集甚至比枪和装备还贵[/spoiler]
每名队员可以带一个帽子用于……装饰？被爆头的时候帽子似乎有一定几率帮你抵挡伤害但是帽子会被击飞，通过移动到帽子边上可以捡起来。你想要搞到敌人头上的帽子也得瞄着他们头上的帽子开枪然后花一回合跑过去捡。

不得不说这是一款策略性很强的游戏，敌人很多，子弹伤害也足够强，加上少得可怜的回复手段，如果玩家控制的角色如果无脑冲上去很容易阵亡，这就要求玩家合理利用掩体和走位，合理计算伤害秒杀敌人，并同时尽量让对面不会有机会击中你的角色。[spoiler] 不然己方队员死了人就拿不到三星了[/spoiler]

关于DLC，the outsider添加了一个职业是outsider的队员，需要触发剧情找到。添加了几个少量的关卡，每个关卡都送一个稀有物品。[spoiler]DLC给的武器道具还有队员敢不敢再imba一点[/spoiler]
另外一个DLC应该是音乐包。

总评分9/10，1分扣给关卡太短还有场景的千篇一律。
