24098650.review:
SteamWorld Heist is a quick but intense turn-based tactical combat game with a certain challenge to it. Right of the bat, the game strikes you with its art style, its vivid setting and its compelling soundtrack. I was hooked from the start, there is no denying that.

Characters speak volumes with their designs, much more than with their actually lines of dialogues, and while there is a plot, the fights and gameplay are where the game shines. As nice as the music or the graphics are, it is the combat that makes the game: overcome many enemies; collect their hats for an added challenge, unlocking them for your characters; and loot stuff!
To overcome the odds, you can use up to four heroes at times; as many as there are character classes. Each hero as its own set of skills however, even if some are redundant among them. The battles are short, requiring your aim to be precise, which often necessitates a certain perspective on the position and reposition of the characters during the fights.
Obviously, the great joy of the game comes from overcoming a mission by the skin of your teeth and going through the collected loot and swag, unlocking support items and weapons. A few of them change the way the game is played, especially with ricochet shoots, -which make trick shoots, in the cramped hulls of the spaceships, a delight-, but most of them are rather standard, offering only incremental improvements.

The same can also be said about the levelling-up system. While each character has at least one skill specific to him or herself, most of the level bonuses are only a flat improvements to health or skill damage, making level gains a little bit lacklustre by the end. However, it does scale nicely with the tougher fights and enemies ahead. As such, the difficulty of the game feels rather tight: I never felt, having lost a mission, that I couldn't have done better or that the mission was impossible to succeed.

As a side note, I only found myself switching up my dream team of characters during missions for varieties sake only, and regretting this decision more often than not, as nasty surprises loomed ahead. Of the pool of ten characters you can get back to, I sadly only ever used half of them regularly, if that.

The game's length genuinely surprised me however, with over 15 hours for one playthrough. Missions are replayable, for loot, hats and experience and there is a 'newgame+' mode, apparently offering even more hats to collect, but little else.
Still, I believe I got my money's worth out of it and, more importantly, I had a very pleasant time with SteamWorld Heist. I wholeheartedly recommend this game, especially if the price is cut down.

24095755.review:
[h1] SteamWorld Heist [/h1]

DISCLAIMER: I received this product for no cost for the purpose of reviewing. However, this does not affect my views and opinions of the game.

SteamWorld Heist is a colourful 2D turn-based strategy shooter. The game-play is in the same vein as "XCOM" or "Worms", in a sense where you have precision based skill shots, as well as having certain terrain/objects provide cover for the player. The art style very much reminds me of the other SteamWorld games, as well as "Awesomenauts". 

--------

[b] Graphics: 8 / 10 [/b] 

I've always enjoyed the art-style and design of SteamWorld Dig, and the same is true for this game. The unit and environmental designs are very vibrant and colorful. The animation quality is very good, and the cartoon-y steampunk visuals are something that I really like. Even the cut-scenes look really well designed and have a lot going for them. The minor gripe I have with the graphics, are the resolutions settings. Although the settings menu has a lot to offer and gives plenty of options (considering it being a 2D game), I could not find any options for resolutions, though it's possible I wasn't looking hard enough. The optimization of the game seems fine, I didn't have any problems running the game. The game should run fine on any low to mid-tier graphics card and CPU. 

--------

[b] Sound: 7 / 10 [/b] 

The sound assets are very well done. Although music is subjective, the soundtrack is catchy and sounds good. When I first started the game, I was taken by a nice guitar melody that was on the menu screen. There's also some narration at some parts of the game, as well as voice acting which sound great. None of the sound assets ever really get boring or repetitive,  and even the gunshot/skill sounds sound decent. The dialogue in the game is also very well done. 

--------

[b] Mechanics: 8 / 10 [/b] 

The game's mechanics are really well put together. The controls are understandable and can be changed to your liking. You can use a keyboard or a joy-pad for the game. You pretty much move your units in turn order trying to eliminate the enemies on the screen. For every unit, you have a limited amount of movements per turn, as well and an attacking action. You can take cover behind objects and then try to shoot the enemy behind your cover, though the enemy can also do the same. Projectiles you fire can bounce off objects. This can be used to your advantage in hitting enemies you normally couldn't with a straight line of fire. You have to manually aim and shoot your guns, kind of like those virtual pool/snooker games. This means there's some skill involved when firing. 

Throughout the game you will come across new units to play with and even find hats to wear. You also get experience after completing a stage which levels up your character and provides them with new stats and abilities. You can also pick up a variety of weapons within the game that change your damage output, but can also have other abilities and effects. There are some units that that are only able to use certain weapons as your units have different classes. Loot bags can be found in every stage as well as a special loot bag that usually contains better equipment as well as reputation. As your reputation increases, you can use it to unlock new areas to explore as well as hire new units. 

Some stages are a little more complicated than others, sometimes it's a simple run and gun mission, while others have an alarm system. In this type of scenario, you have a certain amount of turns before an alarm goes off. Once it does, turrets will be put up or more enemies will appear, making things a little more difficult for your units. This means your plays have to be a lot more efficient, and a lot more thought has to be placed into your actions. You can always go back to previous stages to earn more experience and loot. 

--------

[b] Final Personal Remarks: [/b]

The game is very enjoyable. Unfortunately, I'm not very good at these types of games. Though there is a difficulty selection which lets the game cater to newer players to this genre, as well as veterans. So I think I'll be turning the difficulty down a bit. Even as I type this, I'm listening to the music within the game, as I really do enjoy it. The game looks and sounds great. It's very satisfying to play and there's quite a bit of fun to be had here.

Thanks to the devs for giving me the opportunity to review the game, as well as anyone who took this review into consideration, I hope it helped.

24072957.review:
[table][tr][td][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/CuratorPixel] Curator Pixel[/url] - [i]Pursuing objectivity with a critical eye[/i][/td][/tr][/table]

Originally a Nintendo 3DS title, [i]Steamworld Heist[/i] manages to succesfully transition to the Steam platform with increased fidelity. The developer decided to take their next title in a different direction, drawing inspiration from games like  XCOM and Worms. The end result is a game with a unique combination of mechanics which make for addictive and rewarding gameplay.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
Despite being set in a time of struggle, [i]Steamworld Heist[/i] manages to maintain a beautiful artstyle, with every asset showing high levels of fidelity.  Characters are very well animated throughout the experience, and on top of that, the game features fully voiced cutscenes which help further set the tone of the game. Nothing strikes you as lazy or out of place in this game.

The audio is also impressive and packs a real punch. Great sound effects  give the player a sense of satisfaction when downing an enemy, or a sense of urgency once they hear an alarm go off. The game features a great soundtrack as well, from the main menu’s theme, to the dramatic combat music and catchy tavern songs.  All music is performed in-studio by the band Steam Powered Giraffe.

[h1]Plot[/h1]
Earth has blown up, making water a very scarce resource. The game’s main character, Piper Faraday, and her crew of smugglers will have to discover why the Scrappers, a criminal organization, are causing so much trouble with farmers and other citizens. While handling this situation, you must also keep a healthy stock of water supplies, and focus on avoiding the attention of the anti-smuggler Royal Space Force.

[h1]Interface/Controls[/h1]
The interface feels very natural. It is easy to understand where your character can move, and which objects can be used for cover. Each character's path has a color which indicates if they can still shoot after moving. Damage is also presented in a form that is easy to comprehend, even without the need for massive numbers which clutter the screen. The game also features a very simple, but effective, inventory system, giving you the option to equip items to your crew members before each mission.

The controls are very well done. It is easy to cycle through your crew members and issue them orders. The game recommends the use of a gamepad, although less optimal mouse and keyboard controls are available in the options menu.  

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[i]Steamworld Heist[/i] is primarily a turn-based strategy game. What sets this game apart from similar games is the 2D nature of it, and the ability to manually aim your weapons. This introduces a level of skill that is very unique for this genre, as you won’t be depending on hit chances and critical strike percentages. If a shot misses, then it’s solely your fault. On top of that, some of the game’s weapons feature a ricochet mechanic, meaning you can get really creative with how to shoot enemies that are taking cover.

The game has five levels of difficulty: Casual, Regular, Experienced, Veteran and Elite. So if you’re the type of player who only wants to see the story, you can do just that. Or if you’re up for a challenge that is more intense, you can go with the higher difficulties. Each mission is randomly generated, giving the game replayability. However, due to its randomized nature, luck can work for or against us. If a player finds themself struggling to complete a particular mission, they can opt to die or abandon and restart, hoping that the next generated map will be “easier”. Despite what could be considered a flaw in any other game, [i]Steamworld Heist[/i] deters this in a very smart way by introducing a currency penalty every time we fail.

We collect loot in every mission, and are rewarded with reputation and experience at the end of each mission. Reputation is granted based on how successful a run was, and can be used to unlock new paths. It can also be used to recruit new crew members who want to join our cause. The game punishes sloppy performance, not only by diminishing the reputation gain, but also by preventing dead crew members from earning any experience at all.

The backstory of your crew members can be explored by initiating a conversation with them in between missions. An exclamation mark over their head will indicate when they have something new to say, which is reminiscent of other games in the genre. By not shoving a bunch of backstory into the player's face, the game provides a nice balance between gameplay and narrative, allowing the player to engage in the game’s lore if they so desire.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[i]Steamworld Heist[/i] oozes with quality in almost every aspect of the game. It would be nice to have a multiplayer mode and a map editor, but this is no excuse to skip the game. Fun characters, amazing game design, and great music make this title one that every fan of the genre should play. At the same time, thanks to its flexible difficulty options, it serves as an entry point for players who want to get into the genre.

[table][tr][td][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/25303734/][u]Follow Curator Pixel for more analyses and reviews[/u][/url][/td][/tr][/table]

24059674.review:
Dieses Spiel war ein Überraschungshit für mich. Im Sale gekauft, da ich auf rundenbasierte Kämpfe stehe und mir die Optik gefallen hat. Das Kampfsystem erinnert ein wenig am Worms, wobei sich hier die Teams erst abwechseln, wenn das komplette Team seine Aktionen abgeschlossen hat. Ebenso handelt es sich um ein reines Einzelspieler Spiel und kann durch eine interessante, wenn auch nicht fesselnde Story. Zu Beginn einer Mission kann man sich die Teammitglieder und deren Ausrüstung zusammenstellen, wodurch sich das Vorgehen bei einer Mission ändern lässt. Jede Figur hat ihre eigene kleine Geschichte, die sich über kurze Gespräche in Erfahrung bringen lässt. Abgesehen von einigen gefühlt unfairen Aktionen der Gegner ist der Schwierigkeitsgrad ausgeglichen und motivierend.

Für Freunde von Rundenstrategie und schrägen Charakteren gebe ich eine klare Kaufempfehlung.

9/10

24047191.review:
[table][tr][td][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MentorPixel]Mentor Píxel[/url] - [i]Análisis bit a bit[/i][/td][/tr][/table]

De cavar minas en [i]Steamworld Dig[/i] a surcar la galaxia en una nave pirata junto a una tripulación de contrabandistas. [i]Steamworld Heist[/i] desembarca olvidándose de la fórmula que hizo famoso a su predecesor, para, en un movimiento arriesgado en pos del avance del medio, transformarse en un juego de estrategia por turnos repleto de acción, bastante alejado de la zona de [i]confort[/i] en la que se hallaba anteriormente.

[h1]Presentación[/h1]
Ambientado en un entorno al más estilo steampunk, en éste distópico futuro se aprecia un acabado impecable con un diseño gráfico en dos dimensiones. Aunque ostentador de un gran arte visual, la acción de los combates hará a uno dejar de lado la belleza de los escenarios que le rodea en pos de concentrarse en alcanzar la victoria, utilizando su diseño y objetos con dicho fin.

El audio es como la jugabilidad, rápido y dinámico, no hay voces; tan sólo sonidos cortos que los personajes hacen al dialogar. El resto está todo volcado a funciones, uso de objetos y música de ambiente bien implementada, que le viene al juego como anillo al dedo, de la mano del grupo folk/rock [i]Steam Powered Giraffe[/i], pueden ser vistos actuando en diferentes escenarios visitados, como si fuesen otros personajes más del juego.

Hablamos de un título que goza de un apartado artístico bello y técnicamente pulido. Impacta positivamente su diseño de personajes, objetos y niveles, de los cuales se echan en falta su variedad, pues a pesar de la cantidad, el diseño artístico los hace bastante parecidos los unos a los otros.

[h1]Argumento[/h1]
El juego deja en claro sus bases desde el vamos: la Tierra fue hecha pedazos, y los robots a base de vapor que allí habitaban se vieron forzados a vagar por el cosmos en busca de recursos para subsistir. Como si eso no fuera suficiente, hay dos facciones de enemigos a enfrentar, ellos son los saqueadores, que están esclavizando a aquellos que aún residen en los restos de la Tierra, sacándole la última gota de recursos, y por otro lado, los Lealistas, robots más avanzados a base de diésel que parecen representar una dictadura corporativa. Todo eso, y algo más…

La capitana de una nave pirata, Piper Faraday, junto a un grupo de contrabandistas, iniciará un viaje por el espacio para darles una lección a los saqueadores y recolectar recursos. Recorrerá pues, distintos lugares en donde reclutará nuevas tropas que la ayuden en la tarea.

[h1]Controles/Interfaz[/h1]
El juego carece de modo ventana sin bordes, pero lo compensa con sus bajos requisitos y estabilidad técnica. Todas las opciones presentes, ya sean técnicas o de personalización, presentan un apartado muy simple y fácil de manejar.

Pudiéndose jugar tanto con ratón como con teclado, el juego expande su manera de ser jugado, incluso pudiendo combinar ambos periféricos a la hora de la acción. Lamentablemente, a la hora de usar el ratón para disparar, puede resultar molesta la auto-mira agresiva hacia aquello a lo que queramos disparar.

Lejos de todo aquello, los controles son sólidos y cómodos tanto para los veteranos del género como para los recién llegados.

[h1]Jugabilidad[/h1]
En [i]Steamworld Heist[/i] uno hace uso de su propio estilo de juego, sea que seamos lentos y metódicos, directos o a distancia, o incluso kamikazes. Las diferentes maneras de hacer lo mismo generan una experiencia diferente para cada jugador. No obstante, la dificultad progresiva del juego forzará a uno a reintentar el nivel, actualizando su tipo de estrategia y adecuándose al tipo de circunstancia presentada.

Diferentes tipos de tropas, todos únicos, capaces de resistir mayor daño, más versados en el manejo de un arma en particular, y la líder del grupo, con sus propias habilidades especiales. Un gran repertorio de armas, que resultan ser más de 100 y más los ítems a equiparles, cualquiera puede encontrar su zona de confort para cada nivel con cada combinación ganadora a escoger.

Sobre escoger, no sólo tendremos a disposición un arma, pues aunque el sistema de equipamiento de los personajes es básico, impecable y simple, también tendremos a elección de equipamientos kits de curación, bombas y otros equipo para mejorar habilidades de movimiento, protección y demás. Cada personaje posee tres ranuras de equipo que deben ser usadas estratégicamente, pues de eso dependerá el éxito de muchas batallas.

Una vez en la acción, será menester utilizar el diseño del nivel, tanto como objetos que proporcionan protección, para inclinar la balanza a favor de Piper y su grupo. Al hacer uso de barriles para ponerse a cubierto, los enemigos podrán romperlos si lo dañan lo suficiente, y en caso de buscar resguardo tras explosivos, lo mejor es ir pensando en qué hacer cuando haya que repetir el nivel. Una vez a cubierto, se debe emplear el sistema para apuntar y disparar, pues la trayectoria de las balas se muestra en la pantalla si esta posee una mira láser; las balas son capaces de rebotar contra las superficies, ampliando el marco de estrategia, considerando además, que el daño producido depende de la zona de impacto sobre el enemigo.

El ritmo de los combates va de la mano con el sistema de turnos, ya que todo irá a un ritmo relativamente acelerado, incluso pudiendo activar en el menú de título la opción de adelantar los movimientos de los personajes para ahorra tiempo.

Dado que la repetición de niveles, y el procedimiento de ensayo y error sobre patrones pre-existentes puede volverse sumamente tedioso, el juego se encarga de generar aleatoriamente el diseño de cada nivel, lo cual es sin duda un gran alivio para aquellos que odien la repetición constante, y favorece la rejugabilidad puesto que el juego presenta un desarrollo adictivo en todos sus aspectos.

A pesar de que el juego acaba cuando ya no tiene más que ofrecer, se hacen notables los pedidos por parte de los fans, de añadir el modo multijugador que claramente permitiría alargar la experiencia incalculablemente y así aumentar su valor de rejugabilidad.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
[i]Steamworld Heist[/i], como título de estrategia, pero con la inclusión de elementos de juego de rol, resulta en una apuesta seguro para todos aquellos que gusten del género. Adictivo, rápido, equilibrado pero desafiante; una joya como pocas.

24042676.review:
SteamWorld Heist is a game in which you assemble and equip a team of robots to take down enemies; where you battle them in a tactical, turn-based style on a 2D spaceship. Similar to XCOM(which I loved playing), it is an incredibly fun game to play-whilst still being challenging. 

Pros:
-Gameplay is very fun and engaging-also smooth
-Controls are customizable and easy to use
-Graphics are friendly with a cool art style
-Sound is an amazing touch where it highlights the combat and different game mechanics of the game. The music/soundtrack is amazing!
-Yes it is replayable-just like SteamWorld Dig
-Due to its small filesize and requirements it is playable on most if not all computers and therefore is very accessible :D
-Hats :D

Cons:
-Infrequent FPS lag spikes, nothing major though
-No multiplayer
-Would be amazing if you could further customize robots

In conclusion, this is definetely one of the better games I have ever played and, without a doubt I would reccomend it to anyone-it's worth its price and its amazing gameplay. I am in full understanding of the game's small and capable and yet surely growing team but I am in full and true support of the game's progress and expansion as the SteamWorld games are one of my favourite and I would love to see what they become in the future and how many different ones do come out. -For people who loved playing games like XCOM and/or Worms then this is definitely something you should check out, buy and further support the team.              
                                                              9/10 :)

24032183.review:
[table][tr][td][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9059978]Mentor Píxel[/url] - [i]Bajo el lente crítico de un monóculo objetivo[/i][/td][/tr][/table]

Han sido muy poco los juegos que han explorado el subgénero de disparos tácticos con perspectiva lateral. [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] lo hace combinando elementos de los clásicos [i]X-COM[/i] y [i]Worms[/i], jugándose con una campaña bien lograda y llena de contenido.

[h1]Presentación[/h1]
Con unos gráficos dibujados a mano, una selección de colores frescos y unas animaciones bien hechas, [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] se vende como un juego agradable a la vista. Una vez lo ejecutemos y veamos su manera de presentarse, estaremos cautivados por solo apreciar su estética. La música, aunque por sus evidentes bucles de reproducción infinitas, reflejan un nivel de producción decente que le hacen bien a la ambientación steampunk de su temática.

[h1]Controles/Interfaz[/h1]
El juego nos ofrece la opción de jugar con el teclado o el ratón. Con el uso del teclado sentiremos la kinestesia de [i]Worms[/i] al mover nuestras unidades de combate directamente, mientras que con el mando del ratón tendremos la sensación de estar jugando un [i]X-COM[/i] lateral, pero por si fuera poco el juego soporta el uso de control. Cualquiera que sea nuestro medio de interacción, estas opciones nos ofrecerán una comodidad que se ajustará a nuestra preferencia.

Por otro lado, la interfaz es uno de los aspectos más amigables del juego. Con el diseño de su tamaño, posicionamiento y proporciones, lo hacen fácil de adaptarse a primera vista. Aunque jugadores suspicaces pudieran tildarlo de tener marcas originarias de una consola portable por sus bordeados tan suavizados, el resultado final hace que se presente fácilmente como un juego que pertenece a otras plataformas.

[h1]Argumento[/h1]
[i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] es el tercer juego del universo [i]SteamWorld[/i], y aunque no es una secuela de los juegos anteriores, sí está ambientado cientos de años en el futuro. En este tiempo la Tierra ha sido destruida, y los robots inteligentes a base de vapor han logrado sobrevivir y subsistir en el espacio, para ello no solo deben buscan agua y recursos, sino que deben lidiar con saqueadores y Lealistas, robots a base diésel que abusan de su poder mediante monopolizar el espacio. Nosotros jugaremos como la capitana Piper Faraday, al mando de una tripulación de contrabandistas.

Uno de los aspectos disonantes de su narrativa -ligada a su presentación- es la apariencia de la capitana Faraday, quien a primera vista no se evidencia corresponder al sexo femenino, esto se debe no solo por su apariencia tan masculina sino por los efectos de sonidos utilizados para su tono de voz; esto, sumado a que mediante textos y diálogos recordaremos su sexo, nos generará una discordancia cognitiva entre lo que vemos y lo que realmente es que podría distraernos de la inmersión.

[h1]Jugabilidad[/h1]
La mejor manera de describir [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] es partiendo del concepto de un [i]X-COM[/i] lateral, o un [i]Worms[/i] más táctico. Sin embargo quienes no tengan experiencia con estos títulos de estrategia y carezcan de referencias, podrán comprender sus mecánicas si se entendiera como un juego de rol de disparos tácticos lateral.

Como es característico del género, estaremos a cargo de un equipo de unidades con características únicas. Los combates están conformados por rondas de un turno por unidad. Estas unidades podrán cubrirse en el entorno, atacar, utilizar habilidades y objetos. La dinámica táctica del juego parte de la habilidad del jugador para coordinar sus movidas y hacer un uso óptimo de las potencialidades de sus unidades en cada uno de sus respectivos turnos.

Una vez iniciemos la campaña del juego podremos escoger entre cinco dificultades: Casual, Normal, Experimentado, Veterano y Élite. Muy apropiadamente el juego detalla los siguientes aspectos en cada dificultad: penalización por fallo de misión, cantidad, daños y salud de enemigos. Cada dificultad no solo describe para qué audiencia de jugadores se adecúa, sino que especifica cómo recompensa cada dificultad en cuanto al otorgamiento de puntos de experiencia. Por si fuera poco, al principio de cada misión podemos re-determinar la dificultad a nuestro gusto. Esto no solo hace el juego amigable para quienes sean nuevos en el género, sino que también ofrece un verdadero desafío a quienes sean veteranos. 

Comenzaremos nuestra campaña adentrados en una misión que servirá de tutorial y en la que nos asiremos de las mecánicas esenciales del juego: movernos, cubrirnos, atacar y usar habilidades, además aprenderemos que las balas rebotan, lo cual es una de las características peculiares de este título, cual le saca provecho a su naturaleza lateral.

Una vez finalicemos cada misión, las unidades vivas ganarán experiencia con la que subirán de nivel, y con ello aumentarán sus atributos y desbloquearán habilidades. Además, podremos equipar a los personajes con armas y equipamientos que modificarán sus estadísticas. Estos objetos los obtendremos al abrir los botines que habremos recogido en el mapa de cada misión y comprándolos en tiendas con la moneda del juego: agua. En el inventario podremos acceder a los artículos, a los detalles de nuestros personajes y a la colección de sombreros que hayamos recogido a lo largo del juego —guiño—.

Nuestra manera de reclutar unidades y accediendo a otras zonas del mapa será mediante canjearse su favor con el sistema de reputación del que consta el juego. Este sistema no es más que la suma de las estrellas que se nos haya otorgado en cada misión, determinado por nuestra eficiencia en ellas. Y he ahí donde radica la mecánica central del juego: el combate.

Cada misión constará de objetivos específicos cuya dificultad incrementa a lo largo de la campaña mediante la implementación de mecánicas contra-tiempo. Sin embargo es notable que una de las características que hace del título tan rejugable no es solo la versatilidad en su configuración de dificultad, sino que el juego se encarga de que las misiones que rejuguemos no sean las mismas, debido a que el juego genera al azar la estructura de los mapas siempre que entremos en una misión.

[h1]Rejugabilidad[/h1]
Una vez terminemos la campaña una vez, se desbloqueará el New Game+, la cual consta de una dificultad más elevada e iniciaremos con nuestra colección de sombreros intactas y personajes sin progreso.

Sin embargo, a pesar de que el título ofrece una campaña satisfactoria que invita ser rejugada y saca provecho a su generación aleatoria de mapas, es lamentable que el juego con su potencial no pueda ser disfrutado mediante la interacción y competencia con otros jugadores por su carente funcionalidad multijugador.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
Siendo un juego de disparos tácticos lateral, [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] ofrece una premisa como no se ha explorado en otros títulos, con unas mecánicas de combate desafiantes, los aficionados al género no se sentirán de ninguna manera defraudados. Mientras tanto, los jugadores más casuales son invitados a ser complacidos por su sistema de selección de dificultad, la cual permite establecer las condiciones de las mecánicas de combate y hacer de la experiencia más un paseo que un desafío imperdonable.

El hecho de que el juego, con su gran potencial, no soporte una modalidad multijugador puede ser causa de desánimo para muchos, sin embargo, el título ofrece una campaña satisfactoria que no se queda corta con su sentido de progreso persistente y sus mecánicas de rol. Es por ello [i]SteamWorld Heist[/i] se hace tan fácil de recomendar, su versatilidad en el desafío que ofrece no decepcionará a audiencias de cualquier tipo.

23998191.review:
First lets look at a few menu and setting items.  It doesnt have any options currently for borderless fullscreen which is a slight bugaboo for me, but definitely not a deal breaker.  There is a slider in the settings that allows you to adjust the interface size which is pretty cool.  Another thing that is more of a personal annoyance for me is that there is no master volume slider in the audio settings.  

That being said I cant imagine why you would want to turn the volume down on this game.  The sounds and music are awesome!

Sounds: 9/10. 

The music is great and fits the style of the game perfectly.  The weapon noises are actually really well down as well as some of the special effects.  If you compare it to the voice acting and epic orchestra soundtrack of a AAA game then it would be lacking, but I rated it based on how it fits for this game.  It would have earned a 10, but the garbled sounds of the robot voices gets a little hard to listen to after a while.

Artwork: 9/10

The artwork is incredibly well done and detailed.  The style feels almost like it is part inspired by Matt Groening creations like The Simpsons and Futurama, and partially inspired by more gritty graphic novels like The Walking Dead.  Clearly it is difficult to explian but you can see for yourself!

Gameplay: 5/10

The story is pretty good, the ability to free aim your shots is definitely cool and adds some level of variety, but you will still find missions sort of blurring together after a while.  XCOM players will be familiar with this type of mission fatigue.  It is a great game, but after a while you just need a break.  

I would suggest you read the dialogue though because it is well written and pretty funny at times.  

You can equip your recruited ship mates with various head covers that slightly changes their character model.  I am sure some players will find this to be neat, but I personally find it to feel unfinished and a bit of a distraction.  The head covers dont have any stat boosts as far as I can tell.  

The game has some shining moments and it just feels really fun when you play it, but it has a long way to go before it is going to be earning high scores in the gameplay section.

Controls: No rating here just an explanation.

If you are familiar with XCOM controls you will pick this game up super quick.  It is turn based and each turn you have the ability to use two actions per character; a move aciton and a firing action.  You can also opt to spend both of your acitons on movement, but you will not get to attack.  The games shining feature and what makes it really fun is that you get to manually aim each shot which makes for some pretty satisfying trickshots.

I give it a 7/10 overall, but personally I have enjoyed it a lot and will continue to play it.

23969092.review:
Simplistic but fun.  The game is a 2D turn-based strategy that bring up nostalgic memories of the Worms franchise or FF Tactics but has the feel of a mobile game.

You manage a small crew of robot frontiersmen in a series of levels requiring you to find loot, eliminate enemies, or complete map-specific objectives.  Your crew continue to level up in a linear fashion as you acquire better and better loot.  The levels seem to contain a degree of procedurally generated design which is nice to have as I often found myself repeating levels to grid levels for my characters.  The setting is interesting and graphically pleasant set in the same style as Steamworld Dig but in space.  Think robotic Firefly complete with dangerous scrappers, an oppressive military faction, and an ominous alien presence.

Worth buying at a low price but don't expect anything to stick beyond a short enjoyable experience.

23962293.review:
Buy it.  Buy it now.  It's fun.  It's got good graphics.  The music is good and so are the sounds.  The game has a story.  It's very linear but there are "side" missions you can play, or ignore.  You can hire different bots to work with you and they all use slightly different weapons.  The game's been described as a mix of a turn-based metroid-vania style game and a 2D XCOM, which is fairly accurate.

Each "map" differs from the last in some way, and almost all are randomly generated, so you can play the same mission 3 times, but the ships you're on have different layouts.  Oh, and I mentioned you can re-play missions. . .  but you don't have to.  You may want to because you can get more currency (gallons of water) and items.

The game has a decent variety of items with different rarities, but it's not too much like some games out there.  You can wear armour, or get boots that speed you up by one space.  You can carry a secondary sidearm, grenade, healing item, melee boosting item and quite a few others.

Each character "class" differs a fair amount, and each character who shares a class with another character is not a carbon copy of them.  The two Vanguards I have don't have exactly the same abilities, nor do the two sentries that I have.  As you level up your bots, and only those who attend a mission and survive get experience, they gain new abilities.  Maybe it's extra health.  Perhaps a new skill, or an augment for an old skill.  Maybe they get faster.  Maybe they regenerate after every hit.  Maybe they get cranky when they get hit and do more damage on their next attack.  Perhaps they inspire their comerades, or can heal them.

Now, gameplay.  Turn based, as I mentioned, and it's well done.  It's not too slow most of the time, unless a lot of enemies have to move and attack.  Most characters can move x spaces, or 2x spaces if they sprint and forego shooting.  Some weapons can only be used if you don't move first, but most can.  The game looks a bit like a platformer, 2D style game, but there's no jumping up.  You also have to aim your shots yourself.  Meaning you can miss - and so can the enemy.  Be careful with area effect weapons, get a bad bounce and you'll be sorry!  The enemy can also damage themselves with some weapons, and they do, at times.

You can bounce shots.  And you'll often *WANT* to bounce shots.  Most shots can be bounced off walls and cover until they strike an enemy, or until they lose energy after traveling a certain distance.  Heavier weapons, like the harpoon guns or grenade launcher type weapons, fire in an arc so you have to take that into account when firing longer distances.

Every 'bot you control has access to slightly different weapon groups.  So far all my characters have access to two weapon groups per character.  They can also use two utility items which can include other limited use weapons, and a few have weapons as special abilities as well.

There's cover, but all the cover items I've seen so far can be damaged and destroyed if it's shot often enough.  Some platforms you stand on are solid and also provide cover.  They are an indestructable form of protection from enemy fire.  There are other platforms you can walk on but they provide no cover at all.  With the cover items like barrels and barriers, along with platforms you can use as cover you can use these to your advantage - but so can the enemy.  Open doors or hatches can be fired through, and it's always satisfying to get a bounce shot to hit a target when you're firing through an open hatch and bouncing the shot off off two walls, a floor and a barrel before it hits your intended target.  Equally satisfying is when an enemy gets a bad bounce from an area effect weapon and blows himself, and his mates, to bits.  Less satisfying is when you misjudge a bounce and your area effect projectile lands at your feet.  

There is a cost of doing business.  If all your bots get blown up on a mission, you pay a reconstruction fee of several thousand gallons.  All the missions I've completed so far only require one bot to make it through to the end and I didn't notice any fees for reconstruction if I managed to complete a mission that way.  Somf of the bots you hire cost gallons, some are free.  All, so far, are worth it.

Oh, and a big +1 to the devs who understand that sometimes turn based games feel slow.  They've managed to speed up your turns because once a character starts to walk or run to a destination, you can select the next one and start their turn while the first one is still on the move.

I highly recommend this game, and also recommend you play with a game pad (and so do the devs ).  I don't usually prefer a game pad over keyboard/mouse but in this case I do.

Did you buy it yet?  Why not???  Stop reading and go get this one!  I'm even tempted to go get Steamworld Dig now that I've seen these devs. in action.

23816649.review:
A really fun, 20 hour or so, turn-based game.  Engaging gameplay, lighthearted story, great art and sound design.  All party members were colourful, useful and unique. Wonderful world to explore.  Definitely what I was looking for.

My only criticisms would be a couple of nitpicky balance things: The heavy weapons often felt like a bit too much risk vs not enough reward, and being to purchase the highly-useful nuclear bullets might have been a mistake (with the exception of a couple of characters, they were pretty much the only utility item I was using by the end of the game).

Despite those minor quips, I had an excellent time playing.  Very much a recommended purchase.

23780729.review:
[b]Steamworld Heist is an amazing strategy game where XCOM meets Worms in Metroidvania style gameplay to create one of the best games I’ve played this year.[/b]

[b]Story[/b]
The story of SteamWorld Heist follows Piper, a cowbot whose ‘job’ it is to visit planets making deliveries and gathering ‘moisture’ in a time where the Royalists run everything. But Scrappers, rogue cowbots who destroy others for parts, are on the rise and terrorizing every corner of the galaxy so you decide to lend a helping hand with your crew. The story actually gets a lot more detailed within two or three missions and is really well written. So far (I haven’t completed the game) I’m loving following it and I feel it is one of the strong suits of the game if you follow it and read all the dialogue (if you don’t it’s really easy to skip it and miss what is going on). The characters and crew you meet along the way are really loveable and feel a lot more than just random soldiers or cannon fodder which comes from just how well the dialouge and small bios are written.

[b]General Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay of SteamWorld Heist is so freaking fun. If you’ve ever played XCOM and Worms you’ll find it melds the gameplay style of those together perfectly making for an amazing turn-based strategy that requires a lot of skill and tactics rather than luck. 
You start with two crew members which you can control but you’ll be able to recruit more crew members as the missions go on. Each crew member has a class and their own stats and abilities which you’ll be able to level up as you complete missions and earn experience. Though the abilities are predefined for each class and you cannot choose how to upgrade each crew member you can choose which crew goes onto which mission allowing you to level some members first if you prefer their skills. When you begin a mission you’ll be allowed to choose your difficulty and you’ll gain experience and rewards based on whichever you select, harder reaping better benefits but also having larger penalties for failure. Once you’ve chosen your level and difficulty you’ll be able to change your loadout choosing weapons and items for use in combat that you can equip your crew with then you’re ready to battle. Weapons can be class specific or used by any class, it depends and each weapon can have different perks like added crit chance or guaranteed cripple and some weapons are rarer than others with a few not being able to be bought only found. Items can be bought at any shop and range from grenades and melee weapons to healing kits, all of which can be using during missions. 
The gameplay is turn based and as I said before is reminiscent of XCOM. You can move a certain amount of tiles per turn and also have the option to attack (depending on the distance you moved). Your attacks can be controlled much like you can when playing worms, you just choose your direction and fire either directly at your target or using a little ricochet to help you along. Different weapons will attack differently, have different effects and do different damage so you’ll be able to customize your loadout to your playstyle.
Enemies you kill drop hats sometimes (hats are just superficial but for some reason I find myself wanting to own every single one) and you can find ‘swag’ throughout the levels which will reveal its content at the end of the level. This can range from new weapons for your crew, items to sell or moisture. You don’t have to collect all the items on the level but I strongly advise it if you want your game to not get too hard as you go along because everything you find can be used or sold. Stuff you don’t want can be sold for moisture meaning exploring is always the better option and you feel rewarded for not just rushing.
Each mission you start will have one or multiple goals which you’ll need to complete before advancing to the next level but you don’t always have to complete them all, some are entirely optional. Some of the missions are optional also and you can ignore them if you don’t feel like it’s worth your time or if it’s too hard meaning you’re able to play the game at your own pace rather than being forced through the motions.

[b]Pros[/b]
--- Great easy to learn gameplay.
--- Loveable crew members.
--- Fantastic story with well-written dialogue
--- Multiple genres melded well.
--- Intuitive gameplay and interfaces.
---Procedurally generated maps for replayability.
--- HATS OKAY. HATS..
---[spoiler]That song in Gat’s bar. Seriously the best thing i’ve heard this year.[/spoiler]

[b]Cons[/b]
--- The robots ...breathe…? Meaning some shots i’ve missed because the aim changes ever so slightly without warning.
--- Can’t block, defend or set up any way to protect yourself between rounds like you can in similar games.
--- Can’t compare item stats when buying them.

[b]Summary[/b]
SteamWorld Heist is one of those fantastic games that keeps you coming back for more and more every time. The unique way it combines multiple game styles to create such a perfect game is unbelievable and it’s yet another game I can’t recommend highly enough. The gameplay works perfectly, the story is well written and the characters are engaging. This is one of the few games out there i’d say is fully deserving of it’s price tag and worth every single cent.You’ll find SteamWorld Heist satisfying cravings you didn’t even know you had.

23753045.review:
Select your team members and go kick some metalbutt!
For each mission you will be in control of 1 to 4 characters, each with a different set of skills and specialty. Snipers? Got that. More feeling like coming in guns blazing with a nice shotgun or assault rifle? Got it too. Still too subtle for you, would rather blast all with a grenade launcher or a bazooka? Still the right place to go! Or get a balanced team, whatever suits you!
The game plays like a 2D turn-based tactical game, you start, can move and shoot or move twice, and when everyone's done it is the enemy's turn. You can hide behind various-sized covers, which can all be destroyed. The shooting system is dynamic, there is no percentage-based system: when you want to shoot, your character aims (with the arm moving slightly so you're not always sure to hit) and trigger! A lot of weapons bounce of explode, so careful with the friendly fire!

The game is not very long, but replayable with 5 different levels of difficulty. The 3rd one, experienced is the one I started with and can be considered as normal difficulty, even if it tends to get easier towards the end. Overall a very nice buy I recommend it.

23687201.review:
Cowboy pirates in outer space...it's such a tempting theme to build an addictive fun-filled game around. And so Image & Form, the very same publisher & developer of the much beloved SteamWorld Dig, took this idea and ran with it in their newest masterpiece entitled SteamWorld Heist. It is an artistically gorgeous turn-based strategy game nestled within the steampunk universe which derives influence from several outside sources including: Xcom, Worms, and especially the TV series Firefly. But yet it manages to wrap it all together in such a creative way...one which bestows upon SteamWorld Heist a uniquely distinctive identity to call its very own as well. Because within it are to be found all kinds of zany characters, dialogue, & bosses which somehow impossibly exist...and they are so very individualistic from each other that you'll simply never bore from interacting with each.

Its storyline premise is that you play as Captain Piper Faraday, the lead female protagonist within this lore who is an infamous smuggler and pirate bot, and who yet also commands a crew of mercenary bots under her direct control. Your quest is to essentially keep the rival faction Scrappers away from your territory, while commandeering their spaceships and looting them of their valuables whenever you must battle them. And interestingly, the items of value to be had here are water (ie. currency), reputation points, hats (these amusingly play a prominent role in this game as you collect them from your fallen enemies to wear upon shooting them off of their heads), plus all manner of looted items you come across to be stashed away in your inventory system. Quite honestly, it's all so very engrossing and engaging to partake in....especially with so many countless hours (15-20) of missions and objectives to complete. And also because you have full freedom to both customize and upgrade your entire crew as you see fit for any given mission, which further adds to the tactical side of things brilliantly.

Another positive attribute to mention here, is that the cornerstone of its gameplay is based primarily around skill as opposed to chance...which is undoubtedly a very commendable approach to take. Because it allows gamers to more fully connect with the experience, and thus to more fully invest themselves into its outcome in a manner that is optimally satisfying.

There is certainly no shortage of fun to be had with the gameplay either since you must well and truly strategize which approach you will be taking with your crew-mates in order to best overcome your enemies. And having the ability to manually aim each & every one of your shots with carefully thought out trick-shot-style ricochet trajectories is something which you'll never tire of doing, since countless creative possibilities can be had for any given situation. And speaking of which, the layouts for the missions are procedurally generated which ensures that no two playthroughs will ever be quite the same...thus greatly enhancing its replay value many fold.

But where this title truly shines is in its inspirational and highly polished presentation, where seemingly no short-cuts were taken in creating a truly breathtaking experience for gamers to both enjoy and immerse themselves into. The benchmark set here is quite high indeed, and its colorful and distinctive aesthetic style alone will dazzle you instantly, whereas the ingratiating and memorable old-western style soundtrack for the game (expertly done by Steam Powered Giraffe) is one which coalesces wonderfully with the light-hearted and zany atmosphere of SteamWorld Heist. It's absolutely stellar, and imbues this game with a healthy dose of flair & personality in a seemingly effortless manner. Coupled together with the high-quality sound effects to be enjoyed (such as the bullet ricochet sounds especially), there is no doubt whatsoever that it all combines to accentuate the perception of immersion within this wacky robotic world, in a way that is both pleasing and fulfilling.

And on a side-note here, all of the robotic speech from the characters in the game is audibly unintelligible....therefore such dialogue is also presented graphically in boxes as well (which can be read of course). Admittedly this took me a bit of getting used to, but after a little while you will adapt to it. 

Finally, there also exists an additional content DLC which can be purchased separately (SteamWorld Heist: The Outsider), if you're gunning to add new hats, weapons, and missions to the game.


[h1]Verdict[/h1]

I have to come right out and say that this was a blast and a real treat to play! And as much as I carefully looked for them, there just weren't any obvious deficiencies to be found here with this new release, because virtually every single facet of it is so admirably executed. You can readily tell that its developers are a very experienced team of professionals who invested a whole lot of time & effort into making this a must-own title for fans of the genre. In fact, I'm not even a hard-core turn-based gamer by any stretch of the imagination, yet even I found myself smiling with satisfaction for much of the experience...especially since it exudes such light-hearted fun & artistic creativity as gift-wrapping for its rock-solid gameplay...with no obvious nor major short-comings to be found whatsoever. 

Thus I would readily recommend this gem as a very worthy addition to your library, especially so if such games interest you in any way at all to begin with. And I'm always delighted to review games where that extra amount of care & attention to detail were placed into them...ensuring that they will be purchased with no regrets by those of us who adore stepping inside of such fantastical futuristic worlds which also pay homage to the past...ones where we can command a crew of whimsical bots while proudly wearing the most outlandish assortment of hats you'll ever find.

I'll enthusiastically rate this one a very solid 4.5 out of 5 stars


[h1]Pros:[/h1]

- Strategtic skill-based gameplay along with several difficulty levels for both beginners and veterans alike 
- Light-hearted and whimsical humor
- Fantastic sound-track & audio effects
- Over 100 different weapons and almost 100 hats to collect
- Impressively artistic aesthetics
- Countless hours of missions plus bosses to battle
- Full controller support
- Plenty of game options to adjust
- Non-buggy & plays very optimized
- Steam achievements + trading cards

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- Not a particularly big fan of the indecipherable robotic speech effect (this is a relatively minor quibble though)

23675938.review:
Well, first things first. Play with a controler, if you do not, the game is a lot more complicated and far strenous than it is with the controller. Played over steam link and directly at a desktop, controls are intuitive and do not require any changes. 

So, what can I say about this gem of a game: for me it brings back the old days, the really old days. Intuitive gameplay, skills, story development, treasure and the urge to get all missions done with all stars.
You might need more tries, but the game rewards you for every ounce of time you invest. "Why grab all those tiny treasures, only the legendary ones are interesting?" A big NO! Items are well spread within a mission, to get them all is really a hassle some times, but this is the fun part. 

The mission gameplay is the same - a shoot to kill, loot and thrill - but the setting and  circumstances of all missions are changing. They make you rush, think twice about movement, and once you retry a mission, you sometimes want to change the weapons loadout or the steambot. Now the tiny, useless grenade becomes a mighty tool, the 'I hit a brontosaur - but with only one of four shells' grenade launcher is perfectly that what you need. Sometimes you have a perfect heist, sometimes you are happy to evacuate before the next wave arrives. Epic treasure, I will get you later. Rewards for stars are also part of the general progress. You want them, you crave for them.

Every single steambot, despite some having the same "class", has his/her/its own flair, gamestyle, weapon-set and skill-tree that makes every single one a tool, an asset, a rusty old friend you do not wanna see go down. And if one, two, three or the whole barding party went down, you cry tears of H2O (you loose currency). 

The onboard dialoges are well written, rejuvenate from time to time. You can grind, you can go casual, you might say "just one or two games" - and there you are fighting evildoers all the time - and three hours are gone by.

To steam up: get it. Enjoy it. Enjoy it again. If you like it, get the DLC. Pretty fun, merges well, a "good" dlc. More than the  average €/hour fun ratio !!! Despite the BOOMS, this is still no brutal game =3

Oh my, I forgot the hats. Beautiful hats! What is a steambot without his/her/its hat?

Steamworld Heist is a 2D XCOM-like turn based game where you strategically commandeer spaceships with a team of robots to pilfer any valuables. The combat is immensely satisfying as you manually aim each shot, Worms-style, ricocheting bullets around the room to get around enemy cover placements and line up all kinds of fancy trickshots. 

You can recruit a bunch of funny looking robots for your crew and kit them out with a huge variety of unlockable gear and utilities. Best of all every robot wears a hat. 23553744.review:
[h1]Turn-based steampunk Firefly[/h1]

It's a testament to how well nailing an aesthetic can produce such an engrossing and enjoyable experience. Steamworld Heist conjures up a lot of fond memories for a Firefly fan, it wears it's influence proudly, and there are obvious analogues, the main character Piper Faraday is the captain of a small smuggling vessel, the villainous Scrappers who are pieced together from parts of dead robots are this verse's Reaver counterpart, and Royalists being the obvious stand in for the Alliance. The game permeates a Firefly vibe, but it's all got enough of it's own identity that it is far more than just trying to be Firefly: The Game and is very much it's own space western, there's some obvious love for the Western genre as characters will spout references to movies like The Good, The Bad and The Ugly. The music is also terrific, and I'd be remiss not to mention it, seeing as the band Steam Powered Giraffe who provided the soundtrack were an initial draw for me, and right from the title theme you can tell why their talents were sought.

Gameplay wise, it's been touted by many as XCom meets Worms, that's a fairly succinct way of putting it but I really don't like this trend of comparing nearly every turn-based strategy game to XCom, that's fairly reductive and the differences are more than apparent. But that aside, the gameplay is indeed extremely competent turn-based strategy, and landing some critical shots with bullet ricochet can be incredibly satisfying, or for that matter firing a grenade that bounces with a metalic ping before hitting it's mark doesn't seem to lose it's spark. You'll have many different crewmembers being recruited for you to take on various missions, each with their own particular traits and abilities, as well as unique personalities. It's a hell of a lot of fun.

Well recommended if you like turn-based gameplay, and if you are a fan of Firefly, this'll be right up your alley.

Совершенно другой жанр, но тот же запредельный уровень геймдизайна, концентрирующий лучшее из геймплея, провоцирующий на неимоверно приятное ачиверство и всё это абсолютно гармонично переплетено с контекстуальным добрым юмором, тёплым душевным сеттигом, замечательной историей, полной отличных персонажей и просто бесконечной любви к своему проекту, игровой индустрии и геймерам. 23529398.review:
This game is extremely good. I wholeheartedly recommend it. It's like the developers took X-Com's combat system and made it 2D.

Pros:
-The Combat System
 SteamWorld Heist was able to take everything good about X-com's combat system and make it 2D. It also made some tweaks that I like more than X-com. One example is that shots are not based off of dice rolls. What that means is that when I line up a shot, it will hit whatever I'm aiming at. If you line up the shot correctly, you can shoot enemies that are behind cover.

-The Art Design
The game looks amazing. The robots are detailed and cool looking. Space looks awesome and colorful. My favorite part has to be that you can collect a bunch of different hats for your characters to wear.

-The Soundtrack
The music is really good. It's well composed and it fits the space western theme that the game is going for. I really wish that it was available to purchase.

-Boss Fights
I was honestly surprised when I came across the first boss. The games that I have played similar to SteamWorld Heist did not have what I would call bosses. The bosses that I have fought each have had special abilities and multiple phases.

Cons:
-The Story
Let's get this out of the way first, I'm NOT saying that the story is bad. What I'm saying is that the story is the weakest part of the game. The beginning, middle, and end of the game felt really disconnected to me. I can't go into more detail without spoiling the plot, but know going in that it's not the best.

-Lack of Mission Variety
My biggest problem with the game is that a lot of the missions feel the same. Most of the time it's go in, kill bad guys, collect loot, escape. The game adds things like doors that won't open until you destroy a generator, but it never feels any different. I can't tell you which mission would be my favorite (excluding boss fights) because they all feel so similar. This is somewhat solved with The Outsider DLC, but that felt more like a bandage instead of a fix.

There you have it. Like I said earlier, I recommend SteamWorld Heist. The Cons section is a bit nitpicky because there is honestly not a lot wrong with the game. 

I hope this review was helpful to you,
D2

23528103.review:
[b] Zusammenfassung: [/b] (Auf Schwierigkeitsgrad "Normal" nach ca. 14,5 Std. durchgespielt)
SteamWorld Heist ist ein netter rundenbasierter Taktikshooter in 2D mit einem äußerst hübschen Aussehen und schöner Musik. Ich hab mich jetzt schon 1-2 mal dabei ertappt, wie ich einfach nur in einer Bar (im Spiel) stehe und der Musik zuhöre... Die ist echt Klasse! Alles wirkt perfekt zusammen zu einer super Atmosphäre. Wer die Musik von "Flame in the Flood" mochte, wird diese ebenfalls mögen. Klare Kaufempfehlung! Die 20€ sind super angelegt und halten auch das was versprochen wird.


[b] Pro: [/b]
+ Schöner Grafikstil (es wechseln sich verschiedene Umgebungsstile ab, da man durch verschiedene Universen reist und jedes dieser Universen hat einen anderen Look; Grade wenn man denkt, dass der Look langsam nervt, kommt man in ein anderes Universum)
+ Herausfordernd (Es ist wie XCOM in 2D und das ist NICHT schlecht! Ich liebe XCOM und ich liebe dieses Spiel. Man muss abwägen, welche Charaktere man mit nimmt, welche Items und welche Waffen. Super!)
+ Angenehme Atmosphäre (Das Spiel hat eine schöne und angenehme Atmosphäre, ich kann nicht genau beschreiben wieso, aber es ist einfach nur schön dieses Spiel zu spielen)
+ Motivierende Missionen/ Niedriger Frustfaktor (Ich spiele auf Schwierigkeit "Normal" und bin selten gefrustet. Natürlich verliere ich den ein oder anderen Einsatz, aber ich fühle mich immer so, als würde ich diese Mission wieder machen wollen. [b]"Jetzt erst recht!"[/b] ist da das Motto.)
+ Musik (Wer die Musik bei "Flame in the Flood" mochte, wird diese Lieben! Countrymusik im Hintergrund, schön untermalend, welche fließend wechselt wenn man die Locations wechselt. Wunderbar ♥)
+ Keine Ladezeiten (Ja! Klingt komisch, ist aber so. Alles wechselt fließen, also Location zu Location und das ohne Ladezeiten. Toll!)
+ Charaktere (Ich habe bis jetzt [i](Knapp 6 Std. gespielt)[/i] schon 9 verschiedene Charaktere in meinem Team. Alle haben andere Skills, Waffenfähigkeiten und sehen KOMPLETT unterschiedlich aus. Von den Gegnern ganz zu schweigen. Es gibt so viele Charaktere, das ist einfach nur schön! Man hat immer was für das Auge)
+ Entschleunigtes Spiel, trotzdem knackiges Gameplay (Es ist ein ruhiges Spiel, Taktikshooter eben. Trotzdem ist es knackig und man muss häufiger auch mal nachdenken. [i] Laufe ich nach rechts und schieße mit dem Granatwerfer, der Splash-Damage macht und evtl. meine Leute trifft oder schieße ich von hinten mit dem Sniper und kille nur einen?!"[/i] So in etwa ist es meist. Man nimmt sich Zeit, muss kurz überlegen, aber es ist nie langweilig langsam!)
+ Viele Eastereggs/ Liebe zum Detail (Ich habe bis jetzt 3 Andeutungen auf "Zurück in die Zukunft" gefunden. Jedes Item hat einen eigene Beschreibung. SO VIEL LIEBE ZUM DETAIL IST SUPER!)
+ HÜTE
+ "Stimmausgabe" (Jeder Roboter macht andere Töne, da es keine richtige Sprachausgabe gibt. Das ist echt cool gemacht!)

[b] Neutral: [/b]
-/+ Repetetive Missionen (Es sind häufig die gleichen Missionen, aber die Jagd nach besseren Waffen, mehr Wasser und Geld treibt einen an, die Missionen auch nochmal und nochmal zu spielen, bis man überall 3* hat.)
-/+ Manchmal "doofe" KI (Manchmal macht die KI auf der Schwierigkeit "Normal" schon komische Sachen, aber manchmal trifft sie mit 4 Abprallern den Kopf. Fühlt sich manchmal etwas unfair an, erinnert mich aber immer wieder daran: MAN SUCH DIR DEKUNG VERDAMMT)
-/+ Man kann die Missionen öfter hintereinander machen. (Ja... Das ist so eine Sache. Na klar, wenn ich meinen Rang von 1* auf 4* aufbessern will, ist das super, aber wenn ich schon die Volle Punktzahl hab, dann kann ich da immer und immer wieder rein um Geld (Wasser) zu sammeln... Machs selbst auch, deshalb find ich es nicht schlimm, aber irgendwie stört es mich dann nach dem 10ten Run schon etwas.)

[b] Contra: [/b]
[i] Wow, du liest echt immernoch?! Krass.. :D[/i]
- KI (Ja grade hab ich es schon bei Neutral angesprochen, aber manchmal ist die KI echt unfair. Trotzdem ist dieser Punkt nicht ganz neutral und nicht ganz negativ, irgendwas dazwischen halt.)
- So kleines Inventar (Ja das ist jetzt Erbsenzählerei, aber manchmal nervt es schon, dass da nix mehr reinpasst in das Inventar, aber andersherum muss man dann halt den Platz managen den man hat. Was auch nicht schlimm ist.)

[b] Fazit: [/b]
Die Positiven Dinge überwiegen ganz klar. Das Spiel ist super gelungen und macht mir echt Spaß und gute Laune. Ich bin zwar erst knapp 6 Std. dabei, aber der Grafikstil, die Atmosphäre, die Musik und alles drum herum haben diese 20€ auf jeden Fall verdient. Ich kann nur jedem Empfehlen, es wenigstens mal zu versuchen und ihr könnt es ja nach 2 Std. wieder zurück geben, aber ich glaube nicht, dass ihr das tun werdet. Mich hat es voll und ganz in seinen Bann gezogen und ich komme nicht mehr raus. 
Ein Wunderbares leichtes Spiel, was man gut zwischendurch, aber auch länger am Stück spielen kann. 
[h1] ♥ ♥ [/h1]

23511639.review:
[h1]A Tip o' The Hat[/h1]
SteamWorld Heist is a fantastic turn-based strategy game sporting vibrant and polished aesthetics. This steampunk space adventure focuses on skill rather than chance, and is jam-packed with bullet-bouncing, turret weaving, robot commanding fun.

[h1]Story[/h1]
[u][b]SteamWorld’s Narrative[/b][/u]
Following the events of a shattered planet, Cowbots farm leftover land for moisture and water. These resources are a precious commodity used by all bots, excluding the diesel-driven Royalists. With a new danger lurking in the depths of space, gentlebots have so much to worry about. Not wanting undue attention from the Royal Space Force, Piper Faraday, notorious smuggler and occasional pirate, leads a crew of seemingly misfit mercenaries on a quest to drive the bad-for-business Scrappers gang away from her domain. Little does she know what the universe has in mind for her and her crew.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[u][b]Starting the Adventure[/b][/u]
Piper’s journey begins upon selecting one of three available game slots, then choosing a preferred difficulty level. These difficulties are listed as: Casual < Regular < Experienced < Veteran < Elite. Each tier provides various changes to: enemy damage, enemy quantity, mission failure punishment and bonus XP earned. SteamWorld Heist’s gaming structure is comprised of missions (primary and side/challenge missions) that must be unlocked with a reputation requirement (stars). Losing or aborting a mission will result in a loss of water (currency) at any difficulty level above Casual.

[u][b]Missions & Loot[/b][/u]
Every mission rewards the player with reputation which is used to proceed further into the game and unlock additional characters/weapons. Most missions are scored on a 3-star rating system; however, there will be missions that score differently. On each mission, various opportunities are presented to obtain loot in the form of loot bags, epic loot (chests), or hats. Perfecting a mission requires completing the objectives (clear the ship, defeat X, destroy X, retrieve all loot etc.) without having any casualties and retrieving the epic loot(s). Before beginning any mission, a loadout screen is presented where the player will choose the participating characters and their equipment. Due to a crew limitation on missions, it is advised to change up which characters go on each mission regularly to keep levels relatively even; however, this is definitely not required. 

Each mission environment is procedurally generated, providing a unique experience for every player. Heist never feels repetitive because of this, along with the fact that random missions will have a theme (turret factory, explosive carrier etc.). Boss fights also introduce eccentric characters with unique abilities. If that’s not enough, alarms that trigger infinitely spawning enemies/turrets or countdown timers with difficult consequences may be included. 

[u][b]Combat[/b][/u]
Heist’s combat utilizes a turn-based strategy system with a unique mechanic where the weapons are manually aimed and shot by the player. This removes a chance or hit % mechanic that many other similar turn-based strategy games use, and promotes skill-shots or ricocheting around objects to reach the target(s). The entire crew will individually perform their turns before the enemy performs theirs. Each turn is comprised of a movement phase, and a sprint/action phase.

[b]Movement & Sprint Phase[/b]
Positioning is crucial in successfully attaining reputation. Each mission is littered with destructible barrels and walls for partial cover; however utilizing complete cover will be necessary at times. Typically averaging about 6 move spaces per turn, characters can move further using a sprint mechanic. Although it is not split into discrete phases, transitioning from the movement phase into the sprint phase is marked with a differently colored marker or floor space. If the player moves a character into a space beyond the movement range and requires sprinting, no further action can be made by that character. Sprinting is useful for running to partial cover, hiding from turrets, or eluding spawning enemies.

[b]Action Phase[/b]
If the player chooses to keep a character within their movement range, that character can perform an action. An action would either constitute firing that character’s weapon after aiming it, using a special utility item’s free action, or performing a melee attack if an enemy is adjacent to the prioritized character. There are many different weapon types in Heist, and some weapons have specific requirements for use, such as a particular sniper rifle’s “move or shoot – pick one” specification. A rarity and tiered weapon system also promotes loot-based progression. Rare weapons will generally have higher base damage/critical damage stats, or attachments equipped (laser sight). 

Aiming provides the primary game mechanic that sets Heist apart from other turn-based strategy games. If the player chooses to fire a weapon, it must be manually aimed to deal efficient damage. Depending on the weapon attachment or gun type, the projectiles may travel in an arc, bounce multiple times with or without subsequent damage reduction per bounce, travel in a straight line, or scatter. The characters have the ability to shoot directly straight above or below, 90 degrees from the horizontal; however, each character breathes, adding another level of skill required to hit the target(s).

[u][b]Character Progression[/b][/u]
Each character utilized in a mission gains XP after successful completion of that mission. At each level up, a passive ability will be gained. Some characters have unique abilities, while others gain more stats. A couple unique abilities that are very crucial in deciding team composition include:

[list]
[*]Kill Shot: upon delivering a fatal shot, the character gets one additional shot
[*]Inspire: Increase adjacent allies’ damage by +1, along with your own if Inspired
[/list]

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
[u][b]Art[/b][/u]
Even though Heist is a steampunk world, it is very colorful and glossy. The artwork is extremely well polished, providing a truly immersive role-play. As opposed to using the traditional rustic, dull or textured color palettes seen in many steampunk artwork, bright blues, pinks and greens are employed. The settings used for the ships can also vary from oil-crusted rigs to royal and elegant cruisers. The pit stops/bars/social hubs in Heist are very active, filled with neon signs and questionable characters.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u][b]Current State of the Game[/b][/u]
SteamWorld Heist was just recently released on Steam (Dec. 10th 2015 for the PS4, 3DS, Vita, WiiU and Xbox One versions). The developers have shown active and continued interest in Heist, as can be seen in the Steam Discussions board. With a desire to receive input on support and feature requests, SteamWorld’s popularity is still growing.

[b]Advised Suggestions[/b]
Although Heist is in a near perfected iteration of its development cycle, there are a couple suggestions that would improve gameplay; these are listed below.

[list]
[*]Allow loadout changes from the “Start” button menu, or upon item acquisition instead of [i]only[/i] at mission startup
[*]Mark what difficulty a mission was beaten in to aid with achievement tracking
[/list]

[u][b]Verdict[/b][/u]
With everything taken into consideration, SteamWorld Heist is definitely recommended to any fan of strategy games, especially turn-based ones. Kind to newcomers or veterans alike, there isn’t much left to be desired from Heist. It truly deserves to be a contender for 2016's indie game of the year.

23504954.review:
A game that reminds me very much of Fire Emblem in terms of gameplay. 

It is a game about the battlefield you are presented and how you will use it your advantage. Perma-death isn't there, but in order to complete each level to its fullest you have to do it without casualties. You need to play around not only the enemies that you can see, but also the ones you can't, and the ones that will spawn soon. 

I never felt like I was cheated out of a win, and when I did win I felt I had deserved it. 

There are character classes, but each character inside those classes has effects unique to them. Vanguards get a damage bonus if they were damaged the previous turn, but some man get single turn invuln they can activate and some get other bonuses.

Steam powered robots and an engaging story, each hirable crew mate has a backstory, even if it isn't super fleshed out.

I readily recommend this game to strategy gamers, or to those who are trying to get into playing strategy games, five difficulty levels that you can change before every battle really helps everyone get the level of difficulty they want out of the game.

23502163.review:
Almost 9h into the game I think it's time for a review. For me, the first thing that came to my mind after playing this game was that it reminded me of one of my favorite games: XCom. You could call this game a funnier, friendly 2D version of XCom(at least gameplaywise). As hardcore as I am, I'm playing on the veteran difficulty which is honestly quite challenging. In more than one instance did I have to go back and play a level 4x so I could get all rating stars. 
Personally I love having a challenge in such a game. Due to the lack of a (basically) infinite supply of soldiers like in XCom, even if your Steambots die during a run, they are revived as soon as you make it back to the ship (or abort the mission/fail) and just lose the EXP they would've gained. Maybe it's just me, but I'd love to see something like an "insane mode", where your steambots stay dead. But again, I just love frustration. 
Great game though! Really nice graphics/style, cool music and awesome tactical round-based strategy. Would recommend to everyone enjoying the genre!

23456630.review:
Сразу скажу что обзор будет стандартным и просто подчеркнет главное в игре, и что могло бы получиться лучше...
Итак, SteamWorld Heist - игра про роботов, точнее, про паровых автоматизированных машин обладающих, так скажем характером, которые стали осваиватьт наполнять космос своим металлоломом после разрыва на мелкие астероиды планеты Земля. У этих  роботов есть свои так сказать группировки, банды, торговлю и подобие государства... Но говорить вам это не весть как важно. 
Здесь вам предстоит нанимать паровых роботов, покупать шмот, убивать других жестянок и собирать с их кораблей лут.
Найм и покупка арсенала производиться с помощью воды (это местные деньги которые, и нужны паровым машинам для создания пара) и звезд репутации для некоторых сюжетных и квестовых персонажей. У каждого персонажа есть своя история и сток. оружие в зависимости от класса, который не сильно влияет на игру, и, своя шапка...
На любого персонажа можно налепить другое оружие которое он может взять (питолет, пистоле-пулемет, штурмовое оружие, крупнокалиберное) и два тринкета, типо аптечки, бронежилета, кастета, гранаты и конечно же шапку.
Каждый персонаж имеет уровень и за каждое повышение левела дается какая-то активная или пассивная способность.
Вы летаете по глобальной карте от коробля к короблю, попутно зачищая вражеские корабли.
Игра является пошаговой стратегией, которая по моему схожа с XCOM'om по геймплею, в игре хорошо сделана система попаданий и прицеливания, противники приятно разлетаются направо и налево на все части

Пока я ставлю игре 7.5 /10
P.S 
Игра все же наскучивает своим однообразием и некоторыми недоработками, что утомляет..

23450257.review:
Бодрый и красочный эпигон серии "Worms" на тему разумных роботов в космосе.

Ну как разумных. Они не употребляют пищу, но выращивают сельскохозяйственные культуры на  [strike]стероидах [/strike] астероидах. Есть роботы-фермеры и роботы-газонокосильщики. Они подвержены коррозии, но в качестве валюты используют воду. Но тут это объясняется тем, что главные герои как бы паровые роботы и используют воду как ресурс движения. При этом во вселенной есть дизельные роботы и электрические роботы. И они тоже используют воду как валюту. Хм. Ну да ладно, это все придирки и не главное.

	[b]Главное	[/b]
Это походовый смачный экшен в духе классического тайтла "Worms". У нас есть глобальная стратегическая карта со множеством точек входа на тактические карты. По стратегической карте мы свободно перемещаемся в реальном времени на [strike]ржавой консервной банке [/strike] нашем космическом корабле от [strike] бара к бару[/strike] ... стоп, почему зачеркнуто?.. так и есть - от бара к бару. Бары здесь главные рассадники квестов. Именно в них можно взять квест, нанять робота в команду, купить шмоток. После чего лететь к нужной точке для "зачистки местности". Перед входом на карту для выполнения квеста подбираем исполнителей из числа нанятых роботов. От 1 до 4 (на текущий момент). Одеваем на них шмот, пушечка + два тринкета, и идём наслаждаться выпилом всего сущего. Вернее железного лязгающего  листами обшивки. Дальше все как в "Worms" на случайно генерируемых картах: бабах, бджжж, тра-татата, пиууууу-бум, хлюп-хлюп, тртртртртррр, пыщь, БАМ!  Целью миссии может быть сбор всех ресурсов на карте, захват точки, запуск тригеров, выпил всех врагов, убийство босса. Не очень разнообразно, но и повторов не много.

	[b]Компания	[/b]
В лучших традициях походовых тактических стратегий для вашей команды завезли специализации. Где абсолютно ничего нового. Ваши паровые катки могут быть: снайпером, штурмовиком, гранатометчиком/подрывником, специалистом ближнего боя. Роль саппорта выполняет капитан команды. Гранатометчики и штурмовики оп на данный момент. Так же роботы набирают опыт и при левел апе рандомно получают абилку, активную или пассивную, в рамках своего класса. Абилки почти один в один повторяют икс-комовские. 

	[b]Сопровождение	[/b]
Нарисовано отлично. Смачно, ярко, с отдачей. Много деталей, смена света, эффектов. Музыка отличная. Композиции длительностью 4-5 минут, играющие в барах, прослушал полностью, не смотря на то что все дела уже закончил там. Просто оставил героя и сидел слушал в наушниках. Атмосферны и безотносительно хороши. Игра "бегает быстро", ещё бы  - плоское 2Д, ничего лишнего. Багов не замечено.

	[b]Разочарование	[/b]
Несмотря на то, что в игре абсолютно всё хорошо, хоть и вторично местами, она не станет одной из любимых. Всему виной главные герои. Они самобытны, харизматичны, неплохо продуманы. Но за них неитересно играть. Они - роботы. Трудно себя ассоциировать с паровым роботом. После первого часа игры, стал ловить себя на мысли, насколько бы планка игры взметнулась вверх, будь вместо роботов люди. Потому что ассоциация со "Светлячком", "Космическими дальнобойщиками" и иже с ними появляется с первых же миссий. Поиск разномастных колоритных персонажей в свою команду, общения с ними, реплики во время миссий, личные квесты. Всего этого здесь нет. Роботов дают по сюжету в барах, иногда подсовывают в миссиях. Но заморачиваться с их поиском не приходится. И они просто функциональны. Молчаливы и исполнительны. У них нет души. *Банальщина, да*
Поменять роботов на людей и можно было бы провалится в игру и влюбится в неё. Но это субъективно, и скорее для влюбчивых, типа меня. Для тех кто употребляет игры на уровне реакции это не проблема.)

	[b]Получилось	[/b]
Удачное переосмысление игровой механики серии "Worms" в иной вселенной с хорошим сеттингом и шикарной реализацией. Не смотря на пошаговые бои, действие очень динамичное и красочное. Геймплей просчитан и выверен на ура.

///В английской версии игры лут называется "SWAG". Yeaaah
